prompt: Plans to convert a disused underground bunker into a music centre have been backed by Wiltshire councillors.
HWT: Harnham bunker, officially known as Salisbury Urban District Control Centre, has been empty for years. Youth group The Sound Emporium plans to convert it into its new base and said, being underground with thick walls, it's the ideal place for a music venue. But concerns were raised about potential noise, vibration and litter by some of those living nearby. Council officers advised the impact would not be "unduly harmful" and there were also letters of support. The plans for a change of use were approved at a meeting of Wiltshire Council's southern area planning committee on Thursday. Ross Sanderson, of the Sound Emporium, told the BBC the venue was "unique" and "inspiring". "What better place to have a music venue than underground, with the natural soundproofing of the earth plus between 5ft-10ft thick concrete walls?" Salisbury City Council owns the bunker, once an old military telephone exchange which became the council's control centre in 1963. The bunker still has some of its old typewriters and fittings - and an escape hatch.
MGT:
Wiltshire councillors have approved plans to transform a disused underground bunker into a vibrant music centre. The proposal aims to breathe new life into the historic structure, which has remained vacant for years, by repurposing it into a cultural hub for music lovers and aspiring musicians. The development will include rehearsal spaces, recording studios, and performance venues, offering a unique underground experience.

The transformation project, supported by local government, envisions creating a community-focused space that encourages artistic expression and collaboration. It is expected to provide valuable resources for local musicians while also attracting visitors from across the region. The centre will host workshops, concerts, and events, fostering a thriving music scene.

The initiative is part of a broader strategy to revitalize the area, leveraging its rich historical backdrop to promote cultural engagement. The bunker's strategic location and existing infrastructure make it an ideal candidate for such a venture. Local music groups and educational institutions are already expressing enthusiasm about the potential opportunities the centre will offer.

With construction set to begin later this year, the project is anticipated to create jobs and stimulate the local economy. The Wiltshire music centre is poised to become a landmark destination for cultural enrichment, embodying the community's commitment to preserving history while embracing the arts.

prompt: Gary Locke has left his post as Cowdenbeath manager to become an ambassador for Hearts, with Billy Brown named the Blue Brazil's new boss.
HWT: Locke was in charge at Central Park for the second half of last term and guided the club to a play-off win over East Kilbride that kept them in League Two. Brown, who has worked alongside Locke in the past, helped out at Cowden towards the end of last season. The club say their aim remains to secure promotion next season. Cowdenbeath chairman Donald Findlay told the club website: "I am sorry to see Gary leave. However, in his time at Central Park we have become friends and I always made it plain to him that I would not stand in his way if the opportunity came along to join a bigger club. "I am well aware of his affection for Hearts, who have acted with absolute propriety in this matter, as I would expect. I will always be grateful for what he and Billy Brown did for the club at the end of the season and I have every confidence that Billy will carry on the good work." Locke, who becomes the Tynecastle outfit's principal ambassador, is taking up the post in the "club's commercial department" and will also "work alongside director of football Craig Levein in assisting to monitor the numerous loan players the club have across the country". The 42-year-old, who played for Hearts from 1992-2001, also managed the Edinburgh side in the 2013-14 season. Hearts chairwoman Ann Budge told the club's website: "We are thrilled that Gary is back working with us in such an important role."
MGT:
Gary Locke has stepped down from his role as Cowdenbeath manager to take on a new position as an ambassador for Hearts. The announcement marks a significant shift for Locke, who has been at the helm of Cowdenbeath, guiding the team through challenging circumstances. His departure comes as a surprise to many, given his dedication and recent efforts to improve the club's performance.

In his time with Cowdenbeath, Locke worked tirelessly to foster a competitive spirit and instill a sense of resilience within the squad. Despite facing numerous obstacles, including financial constraints and a demanding schedule, Locke's leadership was instrumental in keeping Cowdenbeath competitive in the league. His commitment to the club was evident in his strategic approach and his ability to motivate players, earning him respect from both colleagues and fans.

With Locke moving to a role at Hearts, the club has appointed Billy Brown as the new manager of Cowdenbeath. Brown, a familiar face in Scottish football, brings a wealth of experience to the Blue Brazil. Having previously managed Airdrieonians and Arbroath, Brown is well-versed in the challenges of top-tier football management, particularly in nurturing talent and fostering team cohesion.

Cowdenbeath's chairman expressed confidence in Brown's ability to lead the team forward. "Billy is a highly capable manager with a proven track record," he stated. "We are excited to have him on board and are optimistic about the future."

Brown, eager to make an impact, emphasized his commitment to building on Locke's legacy. "I am thrilled to be joining Cowdenbeath at this crucial time," he remarked. "My focus will be on maintaining the hard work put in by Gary and his team, while also bringing my own ideas to the table."

As Locke transitions to his new role with Hearts, he expressed gratitude for the opportunity to work with Cowdenbeath and optimism for the club's future under new management. The move is seen as a win-win for both parties, with Locke taking on an ambassadorial role that leverages his connections and passion for the game, while Cowdenbeath embarks on a new chapter under Brown's leadership.

prompt: Cuba returned to the United States an inert Hellfire missile that had been wrongly shipped to Havana in June 2014.
HWT: The missile, which did not contain explosives, had been shipped to Spain for a Nato training exercise, the Wall Street Journal said. It was then taken to Germany and eventually to Charles de Gaulle Airport in Paris for onward delivery to Florida. It was instead loaded on to an Air France flight to Havana. The incident could have led to a serious loss of military technology, officials told the Wall Street Journal. The whole affair has been embarrassing for the Americans, who have had to ask the Cubans if they could have their highly sensitive missile back, says the BBC's Will Grant in Havana. The missile arrived on a flight from Paris "by mistake or mishandling in the country of origin," said a Cuban Foreign Ministry statement. "Cuba acted with seriousness and transparency and co-operated to find a satisfactory solution to this issue," it added. The AGM 114 Hellfire is a laser-guided missile that can be deployed from an attack helicopter or an unmanned drone. US officials were worried that Cuba could share the advanced technology inside the missile with countries such as North Korea, China or Russia, sources close to the investigation told the Wall Street Journal. The US and Cuba, old Cold War enemies, restored diplomatic relations in July last year after more than 50 years. The two countries have been working to rebuild their economic and trade ties. An announcement is expected on Tuesday about the reinstatement of scores of commercial flights between US cities and Havana.
MGT:
In a diplomatic move marking the end of a long-standing dispute, Cuba has returned to the United States an inert Hellfire missile that had been mistakenly sent to Havana in 2014. The incident, which involved the shipment of the missile to Cuba without the knowledge of either government, highlighted the complex and often tense relations between the two nations.

The Hellfire missile, a type of air-to-ground missile commonly used by the U.S. military, was discovered in a cargo shipment by Cuban authorities in June 2014. After initial confusion and investigations, it was confirmed that the shipment was an error, and that the missile had not been intended for Cuba. The incident sparked a series of diplomatic exchanges between the two countries, as both sought to resolve the situation amicably.

The return of the missile was facilitated by the U.S. State Department, which worked closely with Cuban officials to ensure its safe and secure handover. This resolution comes as part of broader efforts to normalize relations between the United States and Cuba, which have seen gradual improvements in recent years.

The return of the missile was seen as a positive step towards building trust and cooperation between the two nations. It underscored the potential for constructive engagement and dialogue, despite the historical tensions that have long characterized U.S.-Cuba relations. Both countries have expressed a commitment to continuing their diplomatic efforts, aiming to address outstanding issues and explore new areas of collaboration.

While the incident served as a reminder of the complexities inherent in U.S.-Cuba relations, the successful resolution reflects a mutual willingness to move beyond past grievances. It is hoped that this gesture will pave the way for further diplomatic breakthroughs, contributing to a more stable and cooperative future between Cuba and the United States.

prompt: The sequel to 2009 hit Avatar has been delayed a year and will not be released until 2017, James Cameron has revealed.
HWT: The Oscar-winning director of Aliens and Titanic said he is working on three new Avatar films at the same time. The first film was supposed to be out in December 2016, but Cameron said writing the stories had become "very involved". "There's a layer of complexity in getting the story to work as a saga across three films," he explained. Cameron said the goal was to have the scripts for the three movies completed by the end of this month so that filming can begin. "We're writing three simultaneously and we've done that so that everything tracks throughout the three films," he told the Associated Press. "We're not just going to do one and then make up another one and another one after that. "And parallel with that, we're doing all the design. So we've designed all the creatures and the environments." Cameron said he thought it was important that each film linked forward to the next one in a satisfying way, but also came to a resolution that did not leave the audience hanging. The three films will be shot in New Zealand, where some of the original film was also made. Avatar is the highest-grossing film in history, with box office takings of almost $2.8 billion (Â£1.8 billion). Set in the 22nd Century on a distant planet inhabited by a humanoid race, the sci-fi epic went on to win three Oscars. Cameron, 60, was speaking at an event in Wellington on Wednesday to promote the New Zealand film industry.
MGT:
In a surprising turn of events, the highly anticipated sequel to the blockbuster 2009 film "Avatar" has been delayed by a year, with a new release date set for 2017. The delay was announced by director James Cameron, who cited the need for additional time to perfect the ambitious project. The original film, known for its groundbreaking visual effects and immersive storytelling, captivated audiences worldwide and became the highest-grossing movie of all time.

Cameron has been working tirelessly on the sequel, which promises to push the boundaries of cinematic technology even further. The director emphasized that the delay is necessary to ensure that the film meets his high standards and delivers the immersive experience audiences expect. The sequel is set to continue the story of Pandora and its indigenous Na'vi people, exploring new territories and expanding the universe initially introduced in the first film.

Fans of the original movie have been eagerly anticipating the sequel, with excitement building around the film's innovative use of 3D technology and its potential impact on the future of filmmaking. Despite the delay, Cameron reassured fans that the wait will be worthwhile, promising a cinematic experience unlike any other. He also hinted at an expanded storyline and deeper exploration of the characters and cultures that made the first film so captivating.

The decision to delay the film has sparked mixed reactions among fans and industry insiders. While some express disappointment over the longer wait, others understand and support Cameron's commitment to quality and innovation. The director's track record of delivering visually stunning and narratively compelling films has earned him a loyal following, and many are willing to wait for what promises to be an unforgettable cinematic journey.

As the production team continues to work on the sequel, Cameron has not revealed specific details about the plot or new characters. However, he has expressed his excitement about the creative possibilities of the project and his eagerness to share them with audiences worldwide. With the release now set for 2017, fans are eagerly counting down the days until they can once again be transported to the lush, alien world of Pandora.

prompt: A charity whose office was destroyed when a bus ploughed into it has a new home after a fortnight of staff working on laptops and mobile devices.
HWT: Thirteen people were hurt when the single-decker hit the building used by Guide Dogs UK in the centre of Peterborough on Christmas Eve. The charity has moved into an office in the Orton Southgate area of the city. Helen Sismore, community engagement manager, said: "We should be back in our repaired office by April." The bus went through the bay windows on the front of the charity's regional office on Broadway. Passengers had a variety of minor injuries but no-one was injured in the office where three people were in back rooms. Ms Sismore said: "We heard and felt the crash and it was horrific and the timing on Christmas Eve didn't help. "We've been working using laptops wherever we can find wi-fi, such as our homes, cafes and libraries. "No clients have suffered because we've been in telephone contact using our mobiles and we've had a lot of support from our volunteers and the local community." She said the repair of the rented Broadway offices was being covered by the landlord's insurance and they were renting the temporary office on Cully Court at the market rate.
MGT:
A local charity, which recently suffered a devastating blow when a bus careened into their office, has found a new home just two weeks after the accident. The organization's staff, who were temporarily working from laptops and mobile devices, are now settling into their new premises. The incident occurred when the bus unexpectedly veered off the road, causing significant damage to the charity's office. Despite the setback, the charity's resilience and commitment to their cause remained unwavering.

Quickly adapting to the challenging situation, staff members mobilized to continue their essential services without interruption. They utilized laptops and mobile devices to maintain operations, ensuring ongoing support for their beneficiaries. The community rallied around the charity, offering support and assistance during this trying time.

Thanks to the generosity of local businesses and community members, a new space has been secured for the charity. The swift response and collective effort have allowed the organization to resume its work from a better-equipped environment. As they move into their new office, the charity is grateful for the overwhelming support and is eager to continue making a positive impact in the community.

This incident not only highlights the charity’s determination but also underscores the strength and compassion of the community that surrounds it.

prompt: A man who defrauded a 98-year-old woman he befriended of £170,000 has been jailed for five years and one month.
HWT: Russell Joy, 45, of Shapwick, Dorset, set up direct debits, withdrew money and cashed bonds on behalf of Mary Brady, from Broadstone. Bournemouth Crown Court heard Joy won the trust of the pensioner, who died earlier this month, when she hired him as her gardener in 2008. He was entrusted to withdraw money for her daily living expenses. In December 2014 he made the first of 107 withdrawals without her knowledge, totalling £32,100. The following November Ms Brady cashed five bonds in the sum of £230,000 and wrote Joy a cheque for £100,000. In March 2016, he received a further £20,000 cheque. He also withdrew money to buy a Land Rover car and set up a direct debit to pay his vehicle insurance. The offences came to light when the pensioner's relatives checked her finances while she was in hospital. In a statement, Ms Brady's family said they were "desperately sad" about the "ugly end" to her life. Det Insp Andy Dilworth said: "Russell Joy is nothing more than a callous fraudster. He befriended his victim over a period of many years and quickly earned her trust." He said Joy ,who pleaded guilty at a previous hearing to six counts of fraud by abuse of position, would be subject to action under the Proceeds of Crime Act.
MGT:
In a recent court ruling, a man was sentenced to five years and one month in prison for defrauding an elderly woman of £170,000. The victim, a 98-year-old woman, was deceived by the scammer, whom she had befriended, exploiting her trust to carry out the fraudulent activities.

The fraudster, who initially gained access to the elderly woman’s home under the guise of friendship, systematically manipulated her, convincing her to part with substantial sums of money over time. The court heard how the victim, who had no close family, was particularly vulnerable due to her age and isolation.

During the trial, it was revealed that the man exploited the victim's loneliness and lack of family support, using deceitful tactics to make her believe that her money was being used for legitimate purposes, including non-existent medical treatments and care-related expenses. The fraudulent activities continued for several years before being uncovered.

The judge condemned the defendant's actions, highlighting the calculated and unscrupulous nature of the crime. The elderly woman's lack of immediate family meant that she had few advocates to help her during this time, further exacerbating the impact of the fraud.

The victim's plight came to light when a concerned neighbor noticed unusual activity and raised the alarm. Following an investigation, authorities were able to trace the fraudulent transactions and secure a conviction.

Legal representatives expressed hope that the sentence would serve as a deterrent to others who might consider exploiting vulnerable individuals for financial gain. The case has also sparked calls for increased community vigilance and support networks for the elderly to prevent similar incidents in the future.

prompt: Protesting opposition MPs in Kosovo have released tear gas in parliament for the sixth time in just over two months, disrupting a vote on the government's 2016 budget.
HWT: Outside, opposition supporters threw stones and smashed windows before they were dispersed by riot police. Protesters have been trying to disrupt parliament over an EU-brokered deal to improve relations with Serbia. Kosovo unilaterally declared its independence from Serbia in 2008. The opposition first released tear gas in parliament on 8 October, causing two MPs to faint. US Secretary of State John Kerry, on a visit to the capital, Pristina, earlier this month, called for an end to violent scenes in parliament, saying it was "not the place for tear gas and... not the place for intimidation". However, opposition MPs released gas canisters again in the parliamentary chamber on Monday, forcing a suspension of proceedings. A large group of plainclothes police officers donned gas masks as the chamber was cleared. One of the MPs who released the gas, Glauk Konjufca, said it was "a collective action by the opposition". "Others have done this too, and we will continue to do this in the future. Our breaching of the law is nothing compared to the damage that is being done by these agreements." The opposition is particularly opposed to a deal to give more autonomy to Kosovo's ethnic Serb minority, which they say could increase Serbia's influence. The vote on next year's €1.67bn (£1.1bn) budget resumed in a side room, with only MPs from the governing coalition present and was approved, Reuters news agency reported. The US ambassador to Kosovo, Greg Delawie, condemned the disorder, saying it was "very disappointing" that Mr Kerry's calls had gone unheeded.
MGT:
In a dramatic escalation of political tensions, opposition MPs in Kosovo have once again disrupted parliamentary proceedings by releasing tear gas, marking the sixth such incident in just over two months. The protest unfolded during a crucial vote on the government's 2016 budget, highlighting the deepening rift within the country's political landscape.

The opposition, led by the Democratic League of Kosovo (LDK), has been staging these protests to voice their grievances against what they describe as the ruling coalition's unilateral decisions and perceived authoritarian tendencies. The latest incident saw MPs dousing the parliamentary chamber with tear gas canisters, forcing an immediate evacuation and suspension of the session. 

The unrest stems from a series of controversial decisions taken by the coalition government, including the recent establishment of a special court tasked with investigating war crimes. Critics argue that the court, which is to be funded by the European Union and the United States, undermines Kosovo's sovereignty and targets former Kosovo Liberation Army members, including Prime Minister Ramush Haradinaj.

In response to the unrest, the government has condemned the opposition's tactics, accusing them of undermining democratic processes and stability in the country. "Such actions are unacceptable and only serve to destabilize our democratic institutions," stated a government spokesperson. "We urge all parties to engage in constructive dialogue and work towards the common good."

The repeated use of tear gas in parliament has drawn criticism from both domestic and international observers, who are concerned about the implications for Kosovo's fledgling democracy. The European Union, which has been instrumental in supporting Kosovo's post-war development, has called for restraint and dialogue among all political actors.

As tensions continue to simmer, the future of Kosovo's political stability remains uncertain. The opposition has vowed to continue their protests until their demands are met, while the government insists on proceeding with its legislative agenda. The international community, particularly the EU and the US, will likely play a crucial role in mediating the conflict and ensuring that Kosovo remains on a path toward democratic governance and reconciliation.

prompt: Manufacturing sales from Northern Ireland were worth £13.3bn last year, the highest value on record.
HWT: External sales were up by 3.2% over the year, a rise of £415m. The biggest market for those goods is Great Britain which accounts for £8.1bn - just under half the total value. The Republic of Ireland is the next single biggest market at £1.3bn, followed by the rest of the EU at £1.2bn. Sales to all other parts of the world were £2.6bn. The figures suggest that Northern Ireland manufacturing may be benefiting from the recoveries in the wider British and Irish economies. Sales to GB were up by 6.2% while sales to the Republic of Ireland were up by 5.3%. However sales to other EU countries fell by 13%. The figures are produced by the  Northern Ireland Statistics and Research Agency (NISRA). Richard Ramsey Ulster Bank chief economist in Northern Ireland said one of the key themes from the figures is the growing importance of the GB market for NI's manufacturing firms. He said: "Whilst there have been huge efforts by policymakers to encourage local firms to export to markets outside of the UK, Great Britain has been the fastest growing market for NI's manufacturers following the downturn. "Since 2007/08, NI's manufacturing sales to GB have increased by almost one quarter (+23%) or £1.5bn. "In 2012/13 NI's manufacturers sold six times more goods, in value terms, to the GB market than they did to the Republic of Ireland. "Back in 2007/08,  local manufacturers sold just over three times more goods to the GB market than they exported to the Republic of Ireland."
MGT:
Northern Ireland's manufacturing sector has achieved a landmark milestone, recording its highest-ever sales value at £13.3 billion last year. This remarkable achievement underscores the region's robust industrial performance and economic resilience, marking a significant growth trajectory in the manufacturing landscape.

The surge in sales is attributed to a combination of factors, including increased domestic demand, strategic investments in innovation, and the sector's adaptive response to global market challenges. prompt: A racehorse has survived a two-hour swim, covering 11km, after being scared during a training run on a beach in Brisbane, Australia.
HWT: Rebel Rover was being trained in chest-high water at Sandgate beach when he unseated his rider and headed deeper. The five-year-old gelding was picked up by the Brisbane Water Police and a marine rescue unit. "He was in about four metres of water and he was swimming quite freely," said Volunteer Marine Rescue's Glen Philip. Rebel Rover, with a track record of misdemeanours, has only recently made a comeback after being banned for misbehaving in the stalls. Trainer Brad Smith told ABC News that horses could swim, but did not normally do so very much. "Any other horse, 20 minutes would probably see them out, but this horse - he must have a pretty amazing lung capacity," he said. "The vet looked at him yesterday and again this morning and he's pretty well amazed with how he's coped with it all. Brisbane's Courier Mail reports he still had enough energy to head butt one of his support team, knocking them unconscious and putting them in hospital. Rebel Rover has won three of his 12 races.

The incident occurred during a routine training session on the beach in Brisbane, Australia. Thunderbolt's unexpected aquatic adventure began when he was spooked by something on the beach, causing him to bolt into the ocean.

prompt: Trainer Kevin Ryan has been suspended from running horses after a case of equine herpes was found at his yard.
HWT: Only one case has been discovered in Ryan's string but the yard near Thirsk has been placed under quarantine by the British Horseracing Authority (BHA). The nearby stables of trainers Bryan Smart and Michael Herrington have also been quarantined as a precaution. The BHA said they are working with Ryan and staff to ensure the correct disease control measures are in place. "The risk of the virus being transmitted in a controlled race-day environment is relatively small," said David Sykes, the BHA's director of equine health and welfare. "[But] it is in theory possible that horses from the yard in question may have been infectious some time before the disease was diagnosed. "For this reason we have taken measures to alert trainers, as well as racecourses and veterinary surgeons, to be vigilant to the clinical signs." The equine herpes virus can cause respiratory disease and abort foetuses, while a less common neurological form of the virus can cause co-ordination problems and paralysis, and is potentially fatal. The National Stud breeding site in Newmarket was closed last year following the discovery of the neurological herpes virus infection. Ryan won the French Derby and Irish Champion Stakes in 2014 with The Grey Gatsby and is a four-time winner of the Ayr Gold Cup, including the 2016 edition with Brando.

Equine herpesvirus (EHV) is a highly contagious virus that can cause respiratory disease, neurological issues, and abortion in pregnant mares. The outbreak has raised significant concerns within the horse racing community due to the potential risks posed to other equine populations.

The suspension is part of a broader effort to contain the spread of the virus and ensure the safety of all horses involved in racing and training activities. Authorities have implemented strict quarantine measures and are conducting thorough testing to identify any additional cases.

Ryan's yard will undergo a rigorous cleaning and disinfection process before any horses are allowed to return. During this period, all horse movements have been halted to prevent further transmission.

The racing industry is closely monitoring the situation, with officials emphasizing the importance of biosecurity measures to protect against such outbreaks. The suspension serves as a reminder of the need for vigilance in the management of equine health and the swift action required to address any incidents of contagious diseases.

The racing community has expressed its support for Ryan, acknowledging the challenging circumstances while prioritizing the welfare of the horses. As investigations continue, the focus remains on ensuring the health and safety of all equine athletes and preventing future outbreaks.

prompt: The Environment Agency is reviewing the flood risk around the English coastline from high waves.
HWT: It says some of its existing maps may underestimate the risks to coastal communities. It is updating its National Flood Risk Assessment which informs members of the public and local authorities about the likelihood of flooding. The Environment Agency grades coastal areas at risk of flooding from very low to high. Environment Agency flood risks: High: Greater than one in 30 chance in any given year Medium: One in 30 to one in 200 chance in any given year Low: One in 200 to one in 1000 chance in any given year Very low: Less than one in 1,000 chance in any given year Last winter massive storms hit the South West coast with waves up to 15m (50ft) high, destroying part of the main railway line out of the region at Dawlish. Marcus Salmon, planning liaison technical specialist with the agency, said: "The storms have definitely reflected areas where our maps are not as representative as they can be. "That is something that we are working to address as quickly as possible. "Last winter's storms showed the susceptibility of our coastal communities and infrastructure to flooding and erosion. "The challenges presented by flooding and coastal erosion are expected to become more acute as a result of climate change, due to a combination of sea level rise, increased storminess and increased wave heights. "So as to better understand the risks we are updating the National Flood Risk Assessment to take account of wave, wind and storm surge which are underrepresented in our current mapping."
MGT:
The Environment Agency has announced a comprehensive review of flood risks along the English coastline, focusing on the impact of high waves. This initiative is part of a broader effort to enhance coastal resilience in the face of increasingly unpredictable weather patterns, attributed to climate change.

The review will assess the vulnerability of coastal communities to storm surges and high tides, which have become more frequent and severe. Coastal infrastructure, including sea walls, flood barriers, and drainage systems, will be evaluated to determine their effectiveness in current conditions and to identify areas needing reinforcement.

Local authorities, emergency services, and environmental experts are collaborating with the Environment Agency to gather data and insights. The review aims to provide a detailed understanding of how rising sea levels and intensified storms could affect different regions of the coastline.

Communities living in at-risk areas have been urged to participate in the review process by sharing their experiences and concerns. This community engagement is crucial for developing tailored strategies that address specific local needs.

The findings from the review will inform future policy decisions and investment in flood defense infrastructure. The Environment Agency is committed to ensuring that the measures implemented will protect both people and property while preserving the natural environment.

This proactive approach underscores the importance of preparing for the long-term challenges posed by climate change. By understanding and mitigating flood risks, the Environment Agency aims to safeguard coastal regions for future generations, ensuring that they remain vibrant and sustainable communities.

prompt: A young Syrian man has gone on trial in Germany, accused of being deployed by so-called Islamic State to scope out potential targets in Berlin for attack.
HWT: Identified under German privacy laws as Shaas al-M, he claimed asylum in August 2015 and is now 20 years old. Federal prosecutors say before that he fought with the Islamist militants for two years in his home country. He is being tried by a special security court in Berlin, but reports suggest he refused to testify. He has been in custody since his arrest on 22 March. Shaas al-M's trial comes two weeks after Anis Amri ploughed a truck into a Christmas market in Berlin, killing 12 people. IS later released a video showing him pledging allegiance to its leader Abu-Bakr al-Baghdadi. A year of terror in Germany Berlin attack: Islamic State claims responsibility How attacks are forcing Germany to examine civil freedoms Dressed in a blue pullover and a black cap, he hid his face behind a folder as he took his seat in the courtroom, reported AFP news agency. Officers armed with machine guns were stationed outside the court. Shaas al-M faces charges of being a member of a foreign terrorist organisation, which carries up to 10 years in jail, and violating laws governing military weapons. In a previous statement (in German), the court detailed allegations of Shaas al-M's involvement in IS operations in Syria, including participating in the siege of the airport at Deir al-Zour, handling a Kalashnikov gun and helping supply fighters with food. Once he had arrived in Germany, he maintained intensive contact with IS superiors, it says, and began to undertake visits to Berlin where he explored landmarks including Alexanderplatz, the Brandenburg Gate and the Reichstag parliament building, reporting his findings back to his contacts. He is also accused of arranging for at least one person to travel to Syria to fight, and offering his services to assist would-be attackers travelling to Germany. The court has scheduled some 25 hearings to run until April.
MGT:
A young Syrian man, identified as 24-year-old Ahmad A., has begun his trial in a German court, facing serious charges linked to the Islamic State (IS). He is accused of being sent by the extremist group to survey potential targets in Berlin for terrorist attacks.

According to prosecutors, Ahmad A. traveled to Germany in 2018 under the guise of seeking asylum, a common tactic reportedly used by IS operatives to infiltrate Western countries. While in Berlin, he allegedly conducted reconnaissance missions, meticulously gathering information on various locations, including transportation hubs and public events, which could have been potential targets for attacks.

The prosecution argues that Ahmad A. was part of a broader strategy by IS to carry out attacks in Europe, exploiting the freedoms and openness of Western societies. They have presented evidence suggesting that Ahmad communicated with IS operatives via encrypted messaging apps, receiving instructions and sharing his findings.

Defense lawyers, however, contend that Ahmad A. never intended to carry out any attacks and was merely seeking a better life in Europe. They argue that his communications with alleged IS members were taken out of context and that he had no operational role or direct involvement with the group.

The trial has drawn significant attention, highlighting the ongoing threat posed by extremist ideologies and the challenges faced by European countries in balancing security with the rights of refugees and asylum seekers. Authorities have emphasized the importance of vigilance and cooperation across borders to prevent terrorism.

As the trial progresses, experts are closely watching the proceedings, which could set a precedent for how similar cases are handled in the future. The outcome could influence not only Germany's counterterrorism strategies but also broader European policies on immigration and security.

The case underscores the complex interplay between national security and humanitarian obligations, as countries strive to protect their citizens while upholding the principles of asylum and refuge.

prompt: The director of one of Wales' leading social care providers has said the sector's inspection regime is no longer fit for purpose.
HWT: Anne Thomas, of Linc Care, made the comments in light of Welsh government plans published on Tuesday to strengthen care homes regulations. A new law will make care home owners more accountable for their services. Health Minister Mark Drakeford said lessons had been learned from previous care sector scandals. These include the collapsed Operation Jasmine, the UK's biggest investigation into alleged neglect at nursing homes in south Wales, which was carried out by Gwent Police. The operation ended after the owner of some of the care homes concerned, Dr Prana Das, suffered a brain injury and could not stand trial. Ms Thomas said: "The level of acuity and dependency in nursing homes has changed dramatically over the past few years and the current regulation really looks at the wrong things and so it's great to have something that looks at the kind of evidence that we need to provide [to show] that we're looking after people well." According to the Welsh government, the Regulation of Social Care Bill will: Health Minister Mark Drakeford said: "We have learned lessons from Southern Cross, Mid Staffs, Winterbourne Operation Jasmine and other scandals where people being cared for were badly let down by services."
MGT:
The director of a prominent social care provider in Wales has raised serious concerns about the current inspection regime, describing it as "no longer fit for purpose." The sector, which plays a crucial role in supporting some of the most vulnerable members of society, has been under increasing pressure due to a variety of challenges, including funding constraints and workforce shortages.

The director, speaking at a recent industry conference, highlighted that the existing inspection framework fails to adequately capture the complexities and nuances of providing care in today's environment. Instead of offering constructive feedback or support, they argued that the inspection process can often be overly punitive and bureaucratic, diverting valuable resources away from direct care provision.

This critique comes at a time when social care providers across Wales are grappling with the need to adapt to rapidly changing circumstances, including the ongoing impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic and evolving care needs within the population. The director emphasized the importance of a more flexible and supportive inspection system that encourages innovation and improvement rather than merely compliance.

The call for reform has been echoed by other stakeholders in the sector, including care home operators and advocacy groups, who argue that a more collaborative approach with regulators could lead to better outcomes for both service users and providers. They urge policymakers to engage in meaningful dialogue with the sector to develop an inspection regime that truly reflects the needs of modern social care.

As the debate continues, there is a growing consensus that the current system needs a comprehensive review to ensure it can effectively support the sector in delivering high-quality care in challenging times.

prompt: A man struck by a rush-hour Tube train when it is believed he bent down to pick up a bag is in a stable condition in hospital, police have said.
HWT: The man, in his 20s, suffered life-threatening injuries when he was hit by the train at Stockwell, south London, on Friday. British Transport Police said that while he remained critical, his condition was now considered "stable". Transport for London (TfL) said the station was not overcrowded. Nick Brown, from TfL, said the accident involved a train entering the Northern Line platform of the underground station at about 09:00 BST. He said the organisation had "established that, while the station was busy, the platform was not overcrowded". Eyewitnesses described the incident as "horrific". Twitter user Super D said he saw the man get hit by the train "as he bent over to get his bag". Others said people were screaming when they heard the impact and saw others attempting to help him before paramedics arrived.
MGT:

London's Metropolitan Police and the British Transport Police were called to the scene shortly after 8:30 AM. According to witnesses, the man appeared to be attempting to retrieve an item from the track when the train approached. Despite immediate response efforts, the train driver was unable to prevent the collision.

Emergency services arrived swiftly and provided urgent medical attention to the victim, who was then transported to a nearby hospital. Police have confirmed that he remains in a stable condition, with no life-threatening injuries reported.

Transport for London (TfL) has urged commuters to exercise caution around train platforms and to refrain from placing any items on the tracks. They are working closely with police to investigate the circumstances leading up to the incident. Regular service is expected to resume shortly, though delays may continue as investigations proceed. TfL also reminds passengers to stay behind safety barriers while on platforms.

prompt: A 10-year-old child was injured by a museum's vintage trap, which was once used to catch large animals.
HWT: The boy had to be freed from the metal device by a fire crew at Torquay Museum on Thursday afternoon and was taken to hospital. Its director said the trap was in a closed position and setting it would have taken "a considerable effort". Basil Greenwood said he believed it had been "tampered with" and the museum has now been assessed as safe. "It's called a spring trap and they were used in Victorian times for catching large animals," Mr Greenwood said. Devon Fire and Rescue Service said it was called to the museum at 15:30 BST to free the child and attended for more than an hour. Mr Greenwood said he believed the boy's hand had been punctured and he had been discharged from hospital. "I believe the child was the innocent party in this," he continued. "Somehow, this object was made into a dangerous state and I do not believe that would have been the child. "It is very heavy and would have taken two strong individuals to set it." He said there was a possibility that the boy tripped and hit the trap, although the circumstances remained a mystery and CCTV was being reviewed.
MGT:

The trap, historically used to catch large animals, had been part of the museum's collection for several years. The incident occurred when the child accidentally triggered the device, which was not fully secured to prevent activation.

Emergency services were called to the scene, and the child was quickly attended to by medical professionals. They sustained minor injuries and were transported to a nearby hospital as a precautionary measure. Thankfully, the child was released shortly after treatment.

Meanwhile, the museum remains temporarily closed to the public as they address safety concerns and enhance precautionary measures. Members of the community and museum patrons are encouraged to stay informed through the museum's official channels for updates on reopening and safety guidelines.

prompt: Taunton Deane's MP has asked for government funding to help restore the Wellington Monument, ahead of the 200th anniversary of the Battle of Waterloo.
HWT: Conservative MP Rebecca Pow asked Commons Leader Chris Grayling for a "little pot of money", during business questions. The tower was built to mark the battle, but since 2005 it has been fenced off because of falling stone debris. Mr Grayling said there would be a chance to lobby colleagues for cash. The 175ft (53m) high tower was built in 1817 to mark the Battle of Waterloo which took place on 18 June 1815. Celebrations to mark the 200th anniversary of the battle are due to take place in Wellington. Ms Pow called for a debate to be held to "celebrate and discuss this wonderful anniversary". "Perhaps he [Chris Grayling] might find a little pot of money to restore the wonderful Wellington Monument which is in so need of an upgrade," she said. In response Mr Grayling said he did not have the budget to pay for the work but "there will be many opportunities to lobby those of my colleagues who do have such a budget".

Community leaders and historians have expressed strong support for the initiative, urging swift action to ensure the monument is restored in time for the bicentennial celebrations. prompt: Huge crowds gathered in towns and cities across the UK as firework displays were held to celebrate the arrival of 2015.
HWT: Tens of thousands of people flocked to Edinburgh and London to attend the annual parties there, and other events took place across the UK to welcome the new year. Read more about the celebrations. Edinburgh held its customary Hogmanay street party, culminating in a shower of fireworks over the castle. Around 75,000 people from across the world could be heard counting down the final moments of 2014 in Edinburgh before joining in a mass rendition of Auld Lang Syne. The traditional torchlight procession through the streets of the Scottish capital included men dressed as Shetland vikings. Revellers also flocked to London in their thousands to see the fireworks display along the Thames. The sky was illuminated in pink over the London Eye. It was the first year attendees have had to buy tickets to watch the fireworks in central London - a step which London Mayor Boris Johnson said would help ensure the safety of the 100,000-strong crowd. Although attendance was kept at lower levels than in previous years in London, the clean-up operation in London will last well into 1 January. Fireworks marked the unveiling of a Rugby World Cup 2015 emblem over the River Tyne in Newcastle, one of the tournament's 11 host cities. Lisa Williams sent in this photo of her partner, her two sons and her father celebrating in her garden in Macclesfield.
MGT:

In London, the iconic River Thames was the focal point of celebrations, with fireworks illuminating the city's skyline. Spectators lined the riverbanks, bridges, and nearby parks, capturing the vibrant colors and patterns that painted the night sky. The display, which included synchronized music and choreography, was broadcasted to millions across the globe, showcasing the city’s grandeur.

Manchester and Liverpool also hosted impressive displays, drawing thousands to their respective venues. In Manchester, people cheered from Albert Square and other vantage points, while Liverpool's waterfront became a sea of lights and sound, enhanced by its stunning waterfront fireworks.

prompt: Japan's authorities have seized the passport of a journalist planning to travel to Syria, local media say.
HWT: It was necessary to confiscate Yuichi Sugimoto's passport in order to protect his life, the authorities said. The 59-year-old photographer, who had planned to enter Syria on 27 February, described the move as a threat to the freedom of press. Two Japanese hostages were killed by Islamic State (IS) militants in Syria in January. However, Mr Sugimoto told reporters that he had no intention to visit areas controlled by IS. It is said to be the first time the Japanese government has taken such a step. The foreign ministry says it is in accordance with a provision in the country's passport law, that allows a confiscation in order to protect the passport holder's life. Mr Sugimoto, who has covered conflict zones in Iraq and Syria before, insists he has always taken precautions and retreated when in danger. "What happens to my freedom to travel and freedom of the press?" he told the Japanese paper Asahi Shimbun. He said he was planning to travel to Turkey before entering Syria with a former soldier who had previously worked for Kenji Goto, a fellow journalist who was taken hostage, and killed in Syria last month. A second Japanese citizen, Haruna Yukawa, was also kidnapped and killed by IS militants. After the handling of the hostage crisis, approval ratings for the government of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe have gone up, recent polls show. Two separate surveys conducted by the Yomiuri newspaper and Japan's news agency Kyodo indicate that up to 60% of people approve of the way the government dealt with the crisis. A similar percentage also said Japan's support to countries affected IS should continue to be non-military. In January, Mr Abe promised $200m (Â£130m) in non-military aid for countries fighting Islamic State. Officials said that much of the $200m fund would be focused on helping refugees displaced from Syria and Iraq.
MGT:
Japan's authorities have recently seized the passport of a journalist who was planning to travel to Syria, according to local media reports. This development has sparked discussions about press freedom and the government's stance on journalists reporting from conflict zones.

The journalist, whose name has not been disclosed, was reportedly preparing to travel to Syria to cover ongoing developments in the region. However, before the trip could commence, Japanese authorities intervened, confiscating the passport under unspecified security concerns. This action has raised eyebrows within the media community, with many questioning the balance between national security and the freedom of the press.

The incident has been met with criticism from various media organizations and press freedom advocates. They argue that such actions could set a concerning precedent for journalists who wish to report on international conflicts firsthand. Reporters Without Borders, a prominent organization advocating for press freedom, has called for transparency from the Japanese government regarding the reasons behind the passport seizure.

Japanese officials have not publicly commented on the specifics of the case, citing security reasons. However, they have emphasized their commitment to ensuring the safety of their citizens and maintaining national security. The government has previously expressed concerns about the potential risks associated with traveling to conflict zones, particularly in regions like Syria, where the situation remains volatile and unpredictable.

The journalist in question has not publicly responded to the incident but is reportedly considering legal action to challenge the seizure of their passport. Legal experts suggest that this could become a landmark case, potentially influencing how similar situations are handled in the future.

This incident comes at a time when press freedom is under scrutiny globally. Many journalists face significant challenges and risks when reporting from conflict zones, including restrictions imposed by governments and the dangers posed by the conflict itself. The seizure of the journalist's passport has highlighted the ongoing tension between ensuring security and upholding the rights of the press to report on critical issues.

As the situation develops, the international community will be closely watching how Japan navigates these complex issues. The outcome could have broader implications for journalists worldwide, particularly those reporting from areas of conflict where access is often restricted or fraught with danger.

prompt: Scotland centre Mark Bennett has returned to training and has a "good chance" of playing in their Six Nations opener against England on Saturday.
HWT: Glasgow's Bennett, 23 on Wednesday, was due to resume contact work on Monday after suffering a shoulder injury against Racing 92 three weeks ago. "It's his first day in terms of contact, so he's back in the mix," said Scotland assistant coach Matt Taylor. "I think he has a good chance but he'll have to put his best foot forward." Bennett has scored six tries in 13 Tests and was one of the stand-out performers in Scotland's World Cup campaign last autumn. With fellow Glasgow centres Alex Dunbar, Peter Horne and Richie Vernon all ruled out of at least the start of the Six Nations - or in Vernon's case, the entire Championship - Bennett's possible availability would be a major boost. "A fully-fit Bennett is a very good player," Taylor noted. "There is a reason he played so well in the World Cup, so it is great he is back in the mix." Scotland wing Sean Maitland has also been declared fully fit after coming through a full game for London Irish on the weekend. But Harlequins wing Tim Visser is still a "couple of weeks off" and unlikely to be available before Scotland's third Six Nations match against Italy in Rome. With Matt Scott likely to start at inside centre, Bennett is competing with Saracens' Duncan Taylor for the number 13 jersey against England. The in-form Taylor has been a vital source of intelligence on England's likely defensive set-up, with new Red Rose assistant coach Paul Gustard set to bring his famed 'wolf-pack' approach from Saracens into the national squad. "I think Duncan is caught between a rock and a hard place," grinned Taylor. "He feels like he has been giving out all this information on how Saracens, and now England, are defending. That is hard when there are other guys in our group from the likes of Gloucester and Bath who can benefit. "But that is international rugby. We have been talking about how they defend and Duncan gives us an insight into what to expect. But we will be trying to concentrate on what we do."
MGT:
Scotland's rugby team has received a significant boost as centre Mark Bennett has returned to training, putting him in contention for a spot in their Six Nations opener against England this Saturday. Bennett's recovery has been closely monitored, and the Scottish squad is optimistic about his chances of making a comeback in what promises to be a thrilling encounter at Twickenham.

Mark Bennett, known for his creativity and pace, has been a vital component of Scotland's backline. His ability to break the line and create opportunities for his teammates has made him a standout performer in recent seasons. Unfortunately, his absence due to injury was felt during the latter stages of last year's tournament, when Scotland was pushing hard to secure a spot in the upcoming World Cup.

The news of Bennett's return comes at a crucial time for the Scottish team. They are eager to make a strong statement against England, a team they have historically found challenging to defeat. Scotland's head coach, Gregor Townsend, expressed optimism about Bennett's recovery, stating that he is "fit and raring to go" and that there is a "good chance" he will be available for selection.

Bennett's return adds depth and options to Scotland's backline, particularly in the centre position where he has formed a formidable partnership with Huw Jones. His presence could prove pivotal in Scotland's strategy to outmaneuver England's defense, which has been robust and disciplined. The Scottish team is known for its attacking flair, and Bennett's inclusion could enhance their ability to exploit gaps and maintain pressure on the English defense.

In preparation for the game, Bennett has been working closely with the medical and coaching staff to ensure a seamless transition back into competitive play. His progress in training sessions has been promising, showcasing his fitness and sharpness. This has been a relief for the coaching staff, who have been keen to reintegrate him into the squad without risking further injury.

While Bennett's participation is not guaranteed, his potential inclusion adds an exciting dynamic to the team's preparations. Scotland's strategy will likely involve a balanced approach, combining physicality with tactical ingenuity. Bennett's ability to read the game and execute skillful plays will be crucial in disrupting England's defensive setup.

As the match approaches, anticipation builds among fans and players alike. Scotland is determined to make a mark in this year's Six Nations, and Bennett's return could be the catalyst they need. Whether or not he takes the field, his recovery is a positive development for the team, signaling resilience and depth in their squad.

In conclusion, Mark Bennett's return to training is a welcome development for Scotland as they prepare to face England. His potential participation in the Six Nations opener underscores the team's determination to compete at the highest level and sets the stage for what promises to be an exhilarating match at Twickenham.

prompt: Walsall striker Amadou Bakayoko has signed a new one-year contract with the League One club.
HWT: He follows the lead of midfielder Kieron Morris, who signed a new deal on Wednesday. Bakayoko, 20, who has been with the club since he was 16, missed the end of the season with a knee injury. "It's about getting fit through the summer now because next season is a big season for me," Bakayoko told the club website. "There are high expectations at this club and I really want to step up and become a big part it. "There's lots of young players who have been given a chance here. I'm in the same age group as Liam Kinsella and Rico Henry and we really push each other on." Bakayoko has had three separate loan spells with non-league clubs, first at Southport, then last season at AFC Telford United and fellow National League North side Worcester City. Highly-rated Henry, 18, has been called up to represent England Under-19s against Mexico in June, replacing Manchester United's Cameron Borthwick-Jackson. This third international call for the Saddlers' young player of the season comes on top of his three goals in 44 appearances as a first-team regular during the 2015-16 season.

prompt: A woman who pocketed over £50,000 by claiming false benefits and targeting vulnerable people has been ordered to pay back a token amount of £1.
HWT: Maria Pridmore, 36, was jailed for three years in August after she admitted a string of frauds. They included obtaining more than £16,000 in housing benefit, council tax benefit and income support. Pridmore, who was described in court as a "Walter Mitty" fraudster, also stole over £30,000 from four women. She appeared by video-link at Lincoln Crown Court from Drake Hall prison in Staffordshire where she is serving her sentence. The court heard Pridmore, a former drug addict, benefitted by £56,679 from her crimes but had no available assets which could be confiscated to pay back her victims. Judge Simon Hirst ruled that in the circumstances a nominal sum of £1 should be paid. Pridmore made news in 2012 when she gave birth to a daughter after previously suffering 14 miscarriages, a stillbirth and the death of an infant son. At her sentence hearing, the court heard the former nurse had been claiming to be a lone-parent with dependent children in order to get benefits, but at various times failed to declare she had moved or was living with her then partner as man and wife. Pridmore also pocketed more than £30,000 from friends and two elderly women, and used the bank details of one of her victims to pay for a £60 taxi fare to attend a court hearing. She stole almost £8,000 from one victim, an 84-year-old vulnerable woman. Pridmore, of Angel Lane, Holbeach, Lincolnshire, previously admitted seven charges of benefit fraud between August 2010 and March 2013, 19 charges of fraud and theft between January 2013 and May 2016 and stealing her father's flat-packed kitchen in April 2015.
MGT:
In a controversial court decision, a woman who siphoned off more than £50,000 through fraudulent benefit claims and exploitation of vulnerable individuals has been ordered to repay just £1 of the stolen funds. The case has sparked outrage among community members and advocacy groups, who argue that the minimal repayment undermines the severity of the crime.

The defendant, who has since been identified only by her initials, J.K., conducted her fraudulent activities over several years. Authorities discovered that J.K. manipulated the system by submitting false claims and exploiting loopholes to accumulate a substantial sum of money. Furthermore, she targeted individuals in vulnerable positions, exacerbating the harm caused to those already struggling.

Despite the evidence presented, her defense argued for leniency, citing personal hardships and previous good conduct. The court, however, determined that the crime's impact on the community and the victims warranted a sentence that included a token repayment as a symbolic gesture of accountability.

The judge's decision to mandate a £1 repayment has been met with widespread criticism. Advocates for justice and social welfare reform argue that the negligible repayment fails to reflect the gravity of J.K.'s actions or provide adequate restitution to the affected individuals and society. They stress that such outcomes may set a concerning precedent, potentially undermining trust in the justice system's ability to address economic crimes effectively.

Community leaders have expressed disappointment, emphasizing that the decision does not align with the values of fairness and accountability. They are calling for a review of sentencing guidelines to ensure that penalties for fraud more accurately reflect the harm caused and serve as a deterrent to future offenses.

As the debate continues, victims and their families are left feeling marginalized, with little recourse for the financial and emotional distress inflicted by J.K.'s actions. The case highlights ongoing challenges within the judicial system in balancing rehabilitation and justice, particularly in cases involving economic crimes and exploitation of the vulnerable.

prompt: The media reflect the linguistic and cultural split between Latvian and Russian speakers.
HWT: TV is the leading medium and the sector is dominated by top commercial station TV3, two public networks and the Baltic variants of Russian networks. TV3's owner, Sweden's MTG, is a major player in the broadcasting sector. Russian-language media is dominated by pro-Kremlin, Russia-made content. In response, Latvia has given closer official scrutiny to media policy and in 2016 temporarily banned a Russian TV network for "inciting hatred". Public Latvian Radio (LR) dominates the radio market, thanks partly to the popularity of music station Radio 2. Public radio and TV are financed by state subsidies and advertising. The BBC World Service in English is relayed in Riga on 100.5 FM. Newspapers - all of them privately-owned - reflect a variety of political views. Many titles have suffered declining circulations. By late 2015, more than 1.6 million Latvians were online (Internetworldstats). Latvian social network Draugiem.lv rivals Facebook in popularity. Inbox.lv portal, offering email, dating and photo services, is one of the most-visited sites.
MGT:
In Latvia, the media landscape continues to highlight the linguistic and cultural divide between Latvian and Russian speakers. With a history shaped by both Latvian and Russian influences, the country has two dominant language groups, each with its own media outlets and cultural expressions. This linguistic split is evident in the variety of newspapers, television channels, and radio stations that cater specifically to either Latvian or Russian-speaking audiences.

Latvian media primarily focuses on content that resonates with the Latvian-speaking majority, promoting national culture, language, and political perspectives. Meanwhile, Russian-language media often serve the interests of the Russian-speaking minority, offering news and entertainment that align more closely with their linguistic and cultural experiences. This differentiation extends beyond content to the platforms themselves, with separate networks and publications for each language group.

The division is not merely about language but reflects deeper cultural identities and historical contexts. While efforts have been made to bridge these divides, such as bilingual programming and cross-cultural initiatives, the media landscape remains a mirror of the broader societal dynamics. As Latvia continues to navigate its post-Soviet identity, the media remains a crucial arena where these linguistic and cultural tensions play out, shaping public discourse and national cohesion.

prompt: After months of speculation ITV has confirmed that Cold Feet will return, with filming due to start in Manchester in February.
HWT: The much-loved comedy drama ended in 2003 after five series. The new eight-part series will reunite stars James Nesbitt, Robert Bathurst, Hermione Norris, John Thomson, Fay Ripley and creator Mike Bullen. The transmission date has not yet been announced. Starting in 1997, the show followed the ups and downs of three 30-something couples. It won numerous awards and made household names of the cast. More than 10 million people tuned into the final episode, which featured the funeral of one of the central characters, Rachel, played by Helen Baxendale. The new series will rejoin characters Pete and Jenny, David and Karen and widower Adam. Creator and writer Mike Bullen, said it felt like "the right time to revisit these characters, as they tip-toe through the minefield of middle age". "They're 50, but still feel 30, apart from on the morning after the night before, when they really feel their age. "They've still got lots of life to look forward to, though they're not necessarily the years one looks forward to." ITV has also announced the commissioning of two other series. The Good Karma Hospital, set in Goa in India, will follow the lives of a team of British and Indian medics and is described as "a feel-good drama". Filming on the six hour-long episodes will begin next year and casting has yet to be announced. Also commissioned is Him, by award-winning screenwriter Paula Milne. The three-part drama is described as a "domestic horror" about a teenage boy, caught between his parents' two new families, who discovers he has supernatural powers. Described as "bold, surprising and emotional", filming will start in January in suburban London.
MGT:
ITV has officially confirmed the much-anticipated return of the beloved drama series "Cold Feet," with filming set to commence in Manchester in February. The announcement comes after months of speculation and excitement among fans eager to reunite with their favorite characters.

"Cold Feet" initially aired in 1997 and quickly became a staple of British television, capturing the hearts of viewers with its relatable storylines and dynamic characters. The original series spanned nine successful seasons, concluding in 2003. A revival in 2016 reignited the series' popularity, further cementing its place in the canon of classic British dramas.

The upcoming return promises to delve deeper into the lives of the original cast—James, Rachel, and Matt—as well as introduce a new generation of characters facing contemporary challenges. The revival has been eagerly awaited by fans who have long called for a continuation of the series, with social media buzzing with anticipation and nostalgia for the show's iconic moments.

Filming in Manchester not only brings the production back to its roots, where much of the original series was shot, but also highlights the city's vibrant culture and dynamic setting, which perfectly encapsulates the gritty yet hopeful tone of the series. This return is expected to drive significant economic benefits to the region, with local businesses and cinemas eagerly anticipating the influx of production activity.

The announcement has been met with widespread approval from critics and fans alike, who are excited to see how the series will evolve to address modern issues while retaining the charm and wit that made it a beloved classic. The return of "Cold Feet" is poised to offer a fresh take on friendships, relationships, and the trials of balancing personal and professional life in today's world.

In addition to the original cast, the series will introduce new characters to the mix, promising new storylines and dynamics that will appeal to both long-time fans and a new generation of viewers. This blend of nostalgia and innovation is expected to give the series a fresh edge while staying true to its roots.

As filming approaches, fans are eagerly counting down the days until they can once again step into the lives of their favorite Manchester-based characters. The return of "Cold Feet" is not just a revival of a classic; it's a celebration of enduring storytelling that continues to resonate with audiences across the globe.

prompt: Cardiff council needs to find £25m to balance its books next year, the authority has said.
HWT: Councillor Graham Hinchey said the authority still faced a real terms cut to its budget despite its grant from the Welsh Government rising by 0.3%. The authority is looking at increasing council tax by 3.7% and making cuts of £17m. Costs for burials as well as births, deaths and marriage registration and school meals could all rise in 2017-18. Along with the proposed cuts, £1.5m from reserves, £1.9m from school budgets and £4.4m from the planned increased in council tax would help make up the shortfall. The cuts are smaller than 2015-16, when £32m in savings was proposed, and 2016-17, when the shortfall was £45m. Proposals include: Cardiff council saw its Welsh Government grant rise by 0.3% to £428m. The overall budget for 2017-18 is £578m. Mr Hinchey, cabinet member for corporate services and performance, said: "The provisional settlement from Welsh Government is slightly more favourable than we bargained for. "However, it is still a cut in real terms because of price and pay inflation." The council is asking residents to share their views on the proposals in a consultation, which runs from 10 November to 11 December.
MGT:
Cardiff Council has announced that it needs to find £25 million to balance its budget for the upcoming year. This significant financial challenge stems from a combination of rising costs and reduced funding from central government, pressures that have been exacerbated by the economic impacts of the ongoing pandemic.

The council is currently in the process of exploring various measures to address this shortfall. These include cutting non-essential services, restructuring operations for greater efficiency, and potentially increasing certain fees and charges. Council leaders have emphasized their commitment to protecting front-line services, particularly those that support the most vulnerable members of the community.

In response to the financial situation, the council is also seeking additional funding through grants and is actively lobbying for more support from the Welsh Government. Despite these efforts, the reality remains that difficult decisions will need to be made to ensure the council's financial sustainability.

Residents are assured that the council will engage in a transparent consultation process as it develops its budget proposals. The aim is to strike a balance between fiscal responsibility and the provision of essential services that meet the needs of the city's residents. As the council finalizes its budget for next year, the focus will be on minimizing the impact on Cardiff’s communities while securing its financial future.

prompt: The editor-in-chief at The Scotsman Publications has announced he is leaving the post.
HWT: Ian Stewart is set to leave the newspapers where he has spent the majority of his career in March. The announcement comes just three weeks before The Scotsman is due to celebrate its bicentenary. Mr Stewart is in charge of The Scotsman and Edinburgh Evening News, as well as sister title Scotland on Sunday. He first joined The Scotsman in 1991. He has edited The Scotsman since 2012 and Scotland on Sunday since 2009. Mr Stewart said: "It has been an honour and a privilege to have been editor of these titles through what has been a truly significant time in Scotland's history. "I leave with the greatest respect and admiration for my colleagues who do an extraordinary job day in and day out." Jeremy Clifford, editor-in-chief of owners Johnston Press, said they would be recruiting for Mr Stewart's successor "immediately". He said: "I would like to thank Ian for his leadership of The Scotsman in challenging times and during one of the most important eras in modern Scottish history. "As well as the editorial director, he also served on the editorial board as my deputy chairman when it was first set up just over four years ago. "I would like to thank him for everything he has achieved and wish him every success for the future."
MGT:
The editor-in-chief of The Scotsman Publications, Michael Stewart, has announced that he will be departing from his position. The decision comes after a decade of leadership during which the publication experienced significant growth and transformation.

Stewart joined The Scotsman Publications in 2013 at a time when the media landscape was undergoing rapid changes due to digital advancements and shifting consumer habits. Under his guidance, the publication successfully navigated these challenges, expanding its digital footprint while maintaining its reputation for quality journalism and in-depth reporting.

During his tenure, Stewart played a pivotal role in steering the publication through the complexities of the modern media environment. He championed innovative approaches to storytelling and audience engagement, ensuring that The Scotsman remained relevant and respected in an increasingly competitive market.

"Leaving The Scotsman is a difficult decision for me," Stewart remarked. "The team here has been exceptional, and I am proud of what we have achieved together. My goal has always been to elevate our journalism and serve our readers with integrity, and I believe we have made significant strides in that direction."

As Stewart prepares to step down, he expressed his gratitude to the staff, colleagues, and readers who have supported the publication throughout his time as editor-in-chief. He also expressed confidence in the abilities of his successor to continue the legacy of excellence.

The search for a new editor-in-chief is underway, with the aim of finding a leader who can build on the foundation laid by Stewart and drive the publication forward into the next chapter of its storied history. The exact timing of Stewart's departure is yet to be confirmed, but he plans to remain involved with the publication in an advisory capacity until a suitable replacement is found.

prompt: A United Nations enquiry into the mysterious death of its former head Dag Hammarskjold is due to open.
HWT: Mr Hammarskjold died in a plane crash in what is now Zambia in 1961, but the cause of the crash has been disputed. There have been claims that the plane was shot down, but a previous UN enquiry did not reach a definitive conclusion. The Swedish diplomat was on his way to negotiate a ceasefire in the breakaway Congolese state of Katanga. He was trying to mediate between Congo's Soviet-backed government and Moise Tshombe, who had declared independence for the mineral-rich province of Katanga. He was flying to Ndola, in what was then Northern Rhodesia, to meet Mr Tshombe, who was backed by former colonial power Belgium and some Western mining interests. The UN set up this new enquiry after a group of independent investigators said that there was significant new evidence concerning Hammarskjold's death. They said the evidence was "persuasive" that "the aircraft was subjected to some form of attack". The commission said that the US National Security Agency (NSA) might hold crucial evidence. It said that given the NSA's worldwide monitoring activities at that time, "it is highly likely" that the radio traffic on 18-19 September 1961 was recorded by the NSA and possibly also by the CIA. The report said: "Authenticated recordings of any such cockpit narrative or radio messages, if located, would furnish potentially conclusive evidence of what happened." The UN panel will now assess this new information and report back by the end of June.
MGT:
The United Nations is set to reopen an investigation into the mysterious death of its former Secretary-General, Dag Hammarskjöld, with proceedings scheduled to begin soon. The inquiry aims to shed light on the circumstances surrounding his death in 1961, which has long been shrouded in mystery and speculation.

Hammarskjöld, who served as the UN's second Secretary-General from April 1953 until his untimely death in a plane crash near Ndola, in what is now Zambia, was on a peacekeeping mission to the Congo at the time. The circumstances of the crash have been a subject of controversy and debate for decades, with various theories suggesting possible foul play.

The renewed investigation, commissioned by the UN, is expected to scrutinize previously undisclosed information and documents. It intends to provide a definitive account of the events leading up to the crash, which claimed the life of Hammarskjöld and all 15 others on board. The investigation will also assess the historical context of the mission, considering the geopolitical tensions of the Cold War era and the complex situation in the Congo during that period.

The decision to reopen the inquiry comes amid calls from international figures and historians who have long argued for greater transparency and accountability. Hammarskjöld's legacy as a diplomat and his efforts in advancing the UN's role in peacekeeping remain influential, and clarifying the details of his death is seen as crucial to honoring his memory and the principles he stood for.

As the investigation proceeds, the UN aims to ensure that the truth is revealed and that any lingering questions surrounding one of its most enigmatic figures are finally answered, bringing closure to a chapter that has puzzled the international community for over six decades.
