prompt: Forensic officers used DNA evidence to identify the bodies of a married couple found dead at their home, an inquest has heard.
HWT: Builder Stephen Muncaster, 47, was found dead in the front garden of a property in Magdalen, near King's Lynn, on 12 July. His wife Allison, 48, was found inside the house. Assistant coroner Johanna Thompson, at Norfolk Coroner's Court, said they died from gunshot wounds to the head. At the hearings in Norwich, she said she requested forensic officers to identify their bodies by using DNA evidence. She said: "Mrs Muncaster was found at her home property by police, having suffered what appeared to be a gunshot injury to the head. "A post-mortem report confirmed the cause as being due to a shotgun wound to the head. "Mr Muncaster was found in the front garden of the property, having suffered what appeared to be a gunshot injury to the head." She added that a post-mortem report confirmed that as the cause of his death. As previously reported, shots had been heard and a gun was found at the scene. Police are not looking for anyone else in connection with the incident. Mr Muncaster was the uncle of so-called "Lotto lout" Michael Carroll, who made headlines in 2002 by winning Â£9.7m in the National Lottery. The former binman blew all of his winnings before taking a job in a biscuit factory. Ms Thompson adjourned the hearings for a full inquest on 5 January 2017 at Norfolk Coroner's Court.
MGT:
Forensic officers successfully identified the bodies of a married couple discovered deceased at their home using DNA evidence, an inquest has recently revealed. The couple, whose identities were confirmed during the proceedings, were found by emergency services responding to a distress call early last month.

The investigation into their deaths began immediately, with law enforcement officials and forensic experts working in collaboration to piece together the events leading to this tragic outcome. Initial findings suggested that the couple had been dead for several days, raising questions about the circumstances surrounding their demise.

During the inquest, it was disclosed that advanced DNA analysis played a pivotal role in identifying the deceased. This technology enabled investigators to confirm the identities of the victims, subsequently providing closure to their families who had been anxiously awaiting answers.

The couple, who had been married for over two decades, were known to be well-regarded members of their local community. Neighbors described them as kind and friendly, often participating in community events and activities. The sudden nature of their deaths has left many in the community in shock and mourning.

Detectives have not yet released details on the cause or manner of death, citing the ongoing nature of the investigation. However, they have assured the public that all possibilities are being thoroughly explored, and they are working tirelessly to uncover the truth.

As the investigation continues, authorities have urged anyone with information to come forward, emphasizing the importance of community involvement in solving this case. Meanwhile, the inquest remains open, with further hearings scheduled to examine additional evidence and testimonies.

The loss of the couple has deeply affected their loved ones and the broader community, prompting an outpouring of support and condolences. As the investigation progresses, many are hopeful that justice will be served and that the circumstances surrounding their untimely deaths will soon be brought to light.

prompt: Ancient cave paintings at a world heritage site in the Sahara desert have been defaced with graffiti, Chad's minister of culture has told the BBC.
HWT: The graffiti drawn on the paintings, which are about 8,000 years old, was "a tragedy... offensive to the whole history and memory of Chad," Mahamat Saleh Haroun said. Vandals scrawled their names on top of the artworks in French and Arabic. The Ennedi plateau was declared a Unesco world heritage site in 2016. "It's an African story and they wanted to destroy that. "That's why I'm talking about a tragedy, because it's a part of us," said Mr Haroun, who is also an award-winning filmmaker. Local youths are suspected of being behind the vandalism. A team has now been sent to the site in north-eastern Chad to assess the damage, with a view to sending experts to follow up. The head of the UN's cultural body in the country, Abdelkerim Adoum Bahar, told the BBC that he thought the damage could be repaired. Thousands of images of people and animals have been painted and carved into the rock surface of caves, canyons and shelters in the area, according to UN cultural agency Unesco. Mr Haroun stressed the historical importance of the site, which he said belonged not just to Chad but to the whole world. "This is a part of our memory. It helps us to understand who we are... We cannot destroy it. If you don't know your past you cannot deal with the present," he said.
MGT:
In a distressing development, ancient cave paintings at a world heritage site in the Sahara Desert have been vandalized with graffiti, according to Chad's Minister of Culture. These historic artworks, which are a testament to early human civilization and artistic expression, have been targeted, raising concerns about the preservation of invaluable cultural heritage.

The site, renowned for its exquisite prehistoric rock art, depicts scenes from thousands of years ago, offering insights into the lives and beliefs of early humans. The graffiti, which was discovered during a routine inspection, has already caused significant damage to these fragile and irreplaceable paintings.

The Ministry of Culture has expressed deep regret over this incident, emphasizing the need for stringent measures to protect such sites. The defacement is not only a loss to Chad but to the global community, as these artworks are part of the collective human history. Authorities are currently investigating the incident, urging anyone with information to come forward.

This unfortunate event highlights the ongoing challenges faced in preserving cultural heritage, particularly in remote and vulnerable locations. The Ministry is calling for increased vigilance and cooperation from local communities and international bodies to prevent further damage. They are also exploring enhanced security measures, including surveillance systems and increased patrols, to safeguard these precious sites.

The international community has expressed solidarity with Chad in this effort to protect and preserve the world's cultural treasures. UNESCO and other heritage organizations have pledged support, emphasizing the universal value of these ancient artworks. The incident serves as a stark reminder of the importance of cultural preservation and the need for collective action to protect our shared history for future generations.

prompt: Nepal's first female chief justice has been suspended after the two largest parties in the ruling coalition filed an impeachment motion against her.
HWT: They accuse Sushila Karki of delivering biased verdicts and interfering in the executive's jurisdiction. At least 249 MPs signed the motion, well over the quarter required to open an impeachment investigation. It comes after the Supreme Court overturned the government's choice of chief of police. Last month the court ruled in favour of a claim by Navaraj Silwal, the most senior officer in the ranks, that he had been unfairly bypassed in favour of a less senior colleague, Jaya Bahadur Chand. A hearing has been scheduled for Tuesday 2 May on the government's second choice of candidate, Prakash Aryal, local media report. How Nepal quake turned women into builders The women banished to a hut during their periods Critics say there is a history of political parties determining police appointments on the basis of "undue favours rather than merit". Nepalese media reports say there had been disagreement within the coalition over the appointment. Ms Karki, the head of the Supreme Court, is now automatically suspended from her duties while an impeachment committee is formed and carries out an investigation. The conclusion will then be put to a parliamentary vote, with a two-thirds majority required. The ruling coalition, made up of the UCPN (Maoist-Centre), the Nepali Congress and some smaller parties, would need outside support to pass it. Ms Karki, 64, was appointed in April 2016, and is due to retire in June.
MGT:
Nepal's legal community faces a significant shake-up as the country's first female Chief Justice, Cholendra Shumsher Rana, has been suspended following an impeachment motion. This move comes amid heightened political tensions as the two largest parties in the ruling coalition, the Nepali Congress and the Maoist Center, have spearheaded efforts to remove her from office.

Chief Justice Rana, who made history when she assumed the position, has been under scrutiny for alleged procedural lapses and judicial conduct. The impeachment motion, which was passed in the Parliament, cites several instances of what the coalition parties describe as "unethical" behavior and violation of the judicial code of conduct.

The suspension marks a significant turn in Nepal's judiciary, raising concerns about judicial independence and the politicization of legal institutions. Legal experts and rights activists have voiced apprehension that this action could undermine the separation of powers, which is crucial for a democratic setup.

The Nepali Congress and the Maoist Center have defended their decision, stating that the impeachment was necessary to uphold judicial integrity and accountability. They have argued that Chief Justice Rana's actions compromised the judiciary's independence and credibility.

Critics, however, view the impeachment as a politically motivated maneuver, aimed at consolidating power within the ruling coalition. They argue that such actions could deter future efforts to promote gender equality in high-ranking governmental roles.

As the suspension takes effect, the Supreme Court of Nepal is expected to appoint an acting Chief Justice until the impeachment process is concluded. This development will likely keep the legal and political communities in Nepal on high alert, as discussions around judicial reforms and the safeguarding of judicial independence continue to dominate the national discourse.

prompt: Ukrainian cross-country skier Marina Lisogor has been excluded from the Winter Olympics after failing a doping test.
HWT: The 30-year-old, 58th in both sprint qualification and the 10km classic, tested positive for trimetazidine. The Ukrainian Olympic Committee said Lisogor told an International Olympic Committee disciplinary hearing her breach had been unintentional. Latvian ice hockey player Vitalijs Pavlovs has also failed a drugs test. The International Olympic Committee (IOC) said 24-year-old Pavlovs tested positive on February 19 for methylhexaneamine and had also been thrown out of the Olympics. German biathlete Evi Sachenbacher-Stehle and Italian bobsleigh brakeman William Frullani have already left Sochi 2014 after failed drugs tests. Trimetazidine has been on the forbidden substances list since 1 January 2014. The IOC said Lisogor would be disqualified from the women's team sprint classic semi-final B event, along with her team-mates. They also stated Lisogor "shall be excluded from the XXII Olympic Winter Games in Sochi in 2014, and shall have her Olympic identity and accreditation card immediately cancelled".
MGT:
Ukrainian cross-country skier Marina Lisogor has been excluded from the Winter Olympics following a doping test violation. The decision was made after Lisogor tested positive for a prohibited substance, leading to her disqualification from the Games. The Ukrainian Ski Federation announced the exclusion, confirming the adverse analytical finding.

Lisogor, a seasoned athlete with numerous national titles, had been a key contender in cross-country skiing events. Her removal from the Olympic roster marks a significant setback for both her and the Ukrainian team. The federation has expressed disappointment, emphasizing their commitment to clean sport and fair competition.

The substance detected in Lisogor's test is on the World Anti-Doping Agency's list of banned substances, triggering automatic disqualification under international sports regulations. The Ukrainian Sports Ministry has pledged to cooperate fully with the ongoing investigation and ensure all necessary measures are taken to uphold the integrity of athletics.

This incident highlights the ongoing challenges in the fight against doping in sports. While Lisogor's future competitive opportunities remain uncertain, the broader sporting community continues to grapple with maintaining fair play and athlete accountability.

prompt: Stormont's system of government is set for a makeover.
HWT: The new buzzwords are to be "outcomes" and "indicators". They are words most people living in Scotland or Finland will be very familiar with. Because Stormont's administrators have been studying what happens in those countries and they like what they see. Scotland has a series of sixteen National Outcomes which describe what the Government there wants to do over the next ten years. This so-called outcomes based approach to government focuses on actual results achieved. The theory is it allows the government and wider public sector to focus on making sustainable improvements to public services and the quality of life for people in Scotland. A series of indicators allow them to track progress towards the achievements of these outcomes. Sources close to the negotiations for a programme for government at Stormont say this is the model they intend to follow. One source said it is about "doing things differently" and denied the change was merely cosmetic. As a first step a "framework" programme for government will be produced in just over a fortnight. It will then go out to consultation. At the end of this year it will be replaced with a detailed programme for government. There will also be a budget, not for one year but for the next three to four years. And there will be documents setting out strategies on the economy, capital investment and social policy strategy. Sources say this is not a programme for one Assembly mandate but for a 10 - 15 year period. They say it will also require the civil service to be "more outward facing." Politically, this seems the model Sinn FÃ©in and the DUP intend to move forward with - with or without the other parties. Can the SDLP, Ulster Unionists and Alliance agree to go into the next Executive on the basis of a "framework"  programme knowing they won't get the real detail for another seven months?
MGT:
Stormont is on the verge of a significant transformation as plans to overhaul its system of government gain momentum. This impending makeover aims to address longstanding criticisms of inefficacy and to better serve Northern Ireland's diverse population. The initiative is part of a broader effort to refresh and modernize governance structures to ensure they meet contemporary demands.

The overhaul was set in motion following extensive consultations with political leaders, civil society, and the public. This inclusive process has highlighted the need for a more streamlined and accountable system. Currently, Stormont's governance has been hampered by frequent suspensions and political stalemates, which have undermined public confidence and hindered effective administration.

Key aspects of the proposed reforms include reducing the number of departments, simplifying decision-making processes, and enhancing transparency and accountability. By consolidating departments, the government hopes to create a more cohesive and efficient administrative body. This restructuring is expected to facilitate clearer communication channels and more decisive governance, reducing bureaucratic delays that have plagued decision-making in the past.

Additionally, the reforms aim to bolster the role of the assembly in scrutinizing government actions. Enhanced powers for committees and more robust mechanisms for public engagement are central to these changes. The goal is to ensure that government actions are closely monitored and that citizens have a more direct voice in shaping policy.

The proposed changes also emphasize the need for a more collaborative approach to governance. Recognizing Northern Ireland's unique political landscape, the reforms seek to foster greater cooperation between parties. This approach is intended to bridge divides and encourage consensus-building, which are crucial for addressing complex issues such as health, education, and economic development.

While the proposed changes have garnered broad support, there are concerns about implementation and potential resistance from entrenched interests. Some critics argue that without significant cultural shifts within the political landscape, structural changes alone may not suffice. Nonetheless, the government remains committed to pursuing these reforms, asserting that a more streamlined and responsive system is essential for Northern Ireland's progress.

As these plans move forward, stakeholders across Northern Ireland are watching closely. The success of these reforms could set a precedent for governance not only within the region but also for other parts of the United Kingdom grappling with similar challenges. With the promise of a more effective and accountable government, the overhaul of Stormont's system is a pivotal moment in Northern Ireland's political evolution.

prompt: California Governor Jerry Brown has signed into law a ban on therapy aimed at making gay teenagers straight.
HWT: When the law comes into effect on 1 January, the Golden State will become the first to outlaw the practice for people under the age of 18. The bill was backed by mental health groups, and gay rights activists say reparative or "conversion therapy" can increase risk of depression or suicide. Counselling and prayer is used to help some Christians deal with gay urges. The bill was signed over the weekend along with more than 100 pieces of legislation sent to the governor by California's state legislature. Two Christian groups, the California-based Pacific Justice Institute and the Florida-based Liberty Counsel will challenge the law. The Liberty Counsel said it planned to argue in its lawsuit that the measure infringes on the First Amendment and equal protection rights. In his statement, Gov Brown said sexual orientation change efforts "have no basis in science or medicine and they will now be relegated to the dustbin of quackery". The Human Rights Campaign, an advocacy group, said: "We're grateful to Governor Brown for standing with California's children. "LGBT [lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender] youth will now be protected from a practice that has not only been debunked as junk science, but has been proven to have drastically negative effects on their well-being," the gay rights advocate added, urging other states to take up similar measures. But the National Association for Research and Therapy on Homosexuality said the bill was a "legislative over-reach". Some conservative groups have said banning the therapy would restrict a parent's right to care for children going through gender confusion. California is embroiled in a long-standing legal tussle over gay marriage. A law called Proposition 8 banned same-sex marriage in California just months after it had been introduced. But a court overturned the ban in 2010. After an appeal was upheld, the matter may now come before the US Supreme Court for a final ruling.
MGT:
In a landmark move for LGBTQ+ rights, California Governor Jerry Brown has signed into law a ban on so-called "conversion therapy" aimed at changing the sexual orientation of gay teenagers. This significant legislation marks a major step forward in the fight against practices widely discredited by major medical organizations and seen as harmful to young individuals.

The new law, known as Senate Bill 1172, makes it illegal for therapists, as well as other mental health providers, to use conversion therapy on minors. This practice, which attempts to alter an individual's sexual orientation or gender identity, has been denounced by numerous health professionals, including the American Psychological Association and the American Medical Association, as ineffective and potentially damaging.

Governor Brown emphasized that the legislation is aimed at protecting youth from being subjected to practices that can lead to depression, anxiety, and other mental health issues. "The state of California has a responsibility to protect minors from unscrupulous individuals who would seek to harm them through these dangerous practices," Brown stated in a press release.

Supporters of the bill have long argued that conversion therapy not only lacks scientific validity but also promotes a message of shame and stigma towards LGBTQ+ individuals. The law is expected to prevent many young people from experiencing the psychological trauma associated with these discredited practices.

Senator Ted Lieu, a co-author of the bill, expressed relief and satisfaction with its passage: "This law will save lives by ending a practice that has been proven harmful to countless young people. We must ensure that all children in California are treated with the dignity and respect they deserve."

The legislation stipulates that any licensed mental health provider found in violation of the law could face disciplinary action, including the revocation of their license. This underscores the state's commitment to enforcing the ban and safeguarding the well-being of its youth.

While California is the first state to enact such a comprehensive ban, advocates hope this will set a precedent for other states to follow. Conversion therapy bans have been passed in several states, but this is the first to cover all forms of mental health providers, thereby closing loopholes that previously allowed certain practitioners to continue the practice.

Opponents of the bill, however, argue that it infringes on parental rights and the freedom of speech of therapists. Despite these objections, the overwhelming support from health professionals and LGBTQ+ advocacy groups has underscored the necessity and urgency of the legislation.

As California takes this bold step, it joins a growing movement to affirm and protect the rights of LGBTQ+ individuals, ensuring that all young people can grow up free from harmful and unscientific attempts to change their fundamental identities.

prompt: Scottish entrepreneur Michelle Mone has been appointed by the government to carry out a review into how best to encourage start-ups in areas of high unemployment.
HWT: Ms Mone, brought up in Glasgow's East End, founded lingerie firm Ultimo in her 20s, after leaving school at 15. She sold an 80% stake in the firm last year in a multi-million pound deal. The review will look to identify obstacles to people in deprived areas starting new businesses. "Entrepreneurship can play an important role in supporting economic growth and creating jobs in our most disadvantaged communities," said Work and Pensions Secretary Iain Duncan Smith. "However, people living in those areas face a range of additional barriers they need to overcome in starting and growing businesses." The government said these barriers included a lack of business and social networks, and a lack of inspiring role models. It asked Ms Mone to draw on her own experiences, which included leaving school with no qualifications and having a child at 18. "It's an honour to be appointed to lead this review because I know how tough it can be setting up successful businesses," she said. "My philosophy is that it does not matter where you are from, what education you have, or if you are from an affluent background or not, you can make it if you work hard, set your goals and never give up." Ms Mone co-founded the original Ultimo parent company MJM International with her ex-husband Michael in 1996, and created brands including Ultimo Miracle Shapewear and Miss Ultimo. She was awarded an OBE in 2010.
MGT:
Scottish entrepreneur Michelle Mone has been appointed by the government to lead a review aimed at boosting start-up ventures in regions facing high unemployment. The initiative seeks to harness the potential of innovative businesses to stimulate economic growth and create job opportunities in areas most in need.

Mone, known for her successful career in the fashion industry and as the founder of the Ultimo lingerie brand, brings a wealth of experience in entrepreneurship and business development. Her appointment comes at a critical time as the government seeks sustainable solutions to economic disparities across regions. The review will explore strategies to encourage the formation and growth of start-ups, focusing on areas that have been disproportionately affected by job losses and economic stagnation.

The review will assess various aspects, including access to funding, support services, and the development of entrepreneurial skills. It will also examine the role of digital infrastructure and connectivity in fostering business innovation. Mone's team will engage with local businesses, investors, and community leaders to gather insights and identify barriers that prevent aspiring entrepreneurs from succeeding.

The initiative is part of a broader government effort to address regional economic imbalances and promote inclusive growth. By fostering a supportive environment for start-ups, the review aims to empower local talent and drive innovation, ultimately leading to increased employment opportunities and economic resilience.

Mone has expressed her commitment to making a meaningful impact through this review, emphasizing the importance of collaboration between government, private sector, and communities. Her leadership is expected to bring fresh perspectives and actionable recommendations that could shape the future of entrepreneurship in Scotland. The findings of the review are anticipated to inform policy decisions and investment strategies, paving the way for a more dynamic and inclusive economy.

prompt: A new driver who caused the death of a holidaymaker in a 100mph crash has been jailed for five years.
HWT: Sean Sullivan, 20, had only passed his test the day before the crash which killed Timothy Malone near Cefn Bryn Common, Gower, on 31 July 2016. Swansea Crown Court heard Sullivan had ignored pleas from his passengers to slow down. He pleaded guilty to one count of death by dangerous driving and one of causing serious injury by dangerous driving. Sullivan also admitted two other charges of dangerous driving involving two other drivers. Prosecuting, Ian Wright said airbag data from Sullivan's car showed four seconds before impact, it was travelling at 98mph and the throttle was at 100% at 5,000 revs. "Essentially, his foot was touching the floorboard," he said. The court heard Mr Malone, who was was staying in a nearby caravan with his wife, Yvonne Howard, was unable to take evasive action or avoid the head on collision on the country road. Addressing Sullivan in court, Mrs Howard said: "I am haunted by the images of the terrible events of that night - the last time I saw him. "I cannot heal my tattered heart and soul. I go to sleep in sadness and wake up to sadness. My face is wet with tears every day." Judge Peter Heywood sentenced Sullivan to five years in a young offenders' institution. He will also be banned from driving for four years following his release. Speaking after the case, Inspector Steve Davies of South Wales Police, said: "Our thoughts, as ever, are with the family and friends of Timothy Malone who lost his life in such devastating circumstances at Cefn Bryn in Gower, last summer. "This tragic loss of the life has once again highlighted the consequences of a young and inexperienced driver, driving at excessive speed, which puts drivers, passengers and innocent road users at risk of serious injury or death."
MGT:
A newly qualified driver has been sentenced to five years in prison after causing the death of a holidaymaker in a tragic high-speed crash. The incident, which occurred last month on a rural road, has sparked widespread outrage and a call for stricter regulations on novice drivers.

The 22-year-old driver, whose name has been withheld pending further legal proceedings, was reportedly traveling at an estimated speed of 100mph when his car lost control and collided with a vehicle carrying the victim, a 45-year-old tourist from outside the area. The impact was devastating, and the holidaymaker was pronounced dead at the scene.

According to police reports, the driver had only held his full driving license for a month before the accident. Witnesses described the vehicle as being "out of control" and "flying past" other cars at an alarming speed before the moment of impact. The local community has been shaken by the incident, with many expressing concerns about road safety and the adequacy of current driving tests.

During the sentencing at the Crown Court, the judge condemned the driver's reckless behavior, emphasizing the irreversible harm caused by his actions. "This was a catastrophic failure to recognize the responsibilities that come with controlling a powerful machine," the judge stated. "Your actions have resulted in the loss of a life, a tragedy that could have been prevented."

The prosecution highlighted that the driver had a history of speeding violations, even before obtaining his full license. Despite multiple warnings, the young man failed to adhere to speed limits, ultimately leading to this fatal accident. The defense argued that the driver was remorseful and claimed the crash was a result of a momentary lapse in judgment rather than intentional recklessness.

The family of the deceased has issued a statement expressing their profound grief and calling for increased awareness and education about the dangers of speeding, particularly for novice drivers. They hope that this tragic incident will serve as a wake-up call and lead to reforms that can prevent similar tragedies in the future.

In response to the crash, local authorities are considering implementing stricter measures for new drivers, including mandatory extended probationary periods and enhanced speed awareness programs. The community continues to mourn the loss, and the incident has reignited debates on road safety and the adequacy of current driving regulations.

prompt: Scarlets have given new contracts to forwards Josh Macleod, Tom Phillips and Tom Price, plus centre Steffan Hughes.
HWT: Scarlets general manager of rugby, Jon Daniels, said: "Josh, Tom [Phillips] and Steff are all products of our development pathway. "Our development is something we've always been proud of. "Fifteen of the 23 players that took on Ospreys at Parc y Scarlets last week came through, or took some part, in the development pathway." Flanker Macleod, 20, has enjoyed a breakthrough season for Scarlets, including a Champions Cup start against champions Saracens. Former Wales Under-20 captain Phillips, 21, made his professional debut against Zebre in October 2015 and the blindside flanker has since gone on to make 14 appearances for the west Wales region. Centre Hughes, 23, is another former Wales U20 captain and has battled back from a serious knee injury to make 17 appearances this season in the Champions Cup and Guinness Pro12. Lock Price, 24, joined Scarlets in the summer of 2015 from Leicester Tigers, making his competitive debut in the season opener against Glasgow in September of the same year. The 6ft 8in Wales-qualified second row has made 35 appearances for the Scarlets to date, scoring three tries. "These four players join an exciting group who have already committed their futures to the region, alongside Steff Evans, Will Boyde, Dan Jones and Hadleigh Parkes as well as internationals Rob Evans, Samson Lee and Ken Owens," Daniels added. Scarlets finished third in the Pro12 this season and play Leinster in Dublin on Friday night for a place in the end-of-season play-off final.
MGT:

These signings underscore the club's commitment to maintaining a strong and competitive team as they continue to build for the future.

Josh Macleod, renowned for his powerful scrummaging and work rate, has been a pivotal player in the Scarlets' forward pack. His leadership qualities and experience have been invaluable, particularly in high-pressure matches. The extension of his contract signals the club's faith in his ability to continue contributing to the team's success.

Tom Phillips has made a significant impact since joining the Scarlets, bringing with him a reputation for resilience and tenacity on the field. His performances have consistently impressed both fans and management, making his contract renewal a logical step for the club. Phillips' ability to adapt to different roles within the pack has provided the Scarlets with much-needed versatility.

Tom Price, known for his exceptional line-out skills and defensive prowess, has solidified his place as a crucial component of the Scarlets' forward structure. His contract extension reflects the club's recognition of his strategic importance and the role he plays in both offensive and defensive phases of the game.

In addition to securing their forward talents, the Scarlets have also extended the contract of centre Steffan Hughes. Hughes, celebrated for his agility and tactical acumen, has been instrumental in linking the forwards and backs. His ability to read the game and make decisive plays has been a significant asset for the team.

The news of these contract extensions is a positive development for the Scarlets, as it ensures the retention of key players who have been integral to the team's performance. With these experienced and talented players committed for the foreseeable future, the Scarlets are well-positioned to continue competing at the highest levels of the sport.

prompt: A 19th Century engine building used to pump water out of a Denbighshire mine is being restored.
HWT: Clive Engine House has stood unused for more than 120 years after serving Talargoch Mine in Dyserth until 1884. Now county archaeologists have secured funds to repair the building, which has been affected by weathering over the decades. It was opened to the public on Friday to show how work is progressing. Denbighshire council archaeologist Fiona Gale said: "It was a fantastic, once in a lifetime opportunity to repair the building and bring it back into good order". Built in 1860, the Cornish engine house was home to a steam cylinder which powered water extraction pumps. Lead extraction is thought to have taken place at Talargoch since the Roman period. It has also produced copper, silver and calamine, but it is most famous as a producer of lead and zinc ore. The engine house is one of the few remaining signs of what was once a large and important industry in the area. The engine was in operation until the mine closed in 1884 when the engine was sold to the former Westminster Colliery in Wrexham. David Thomas, the Denbighshire cabinet lead member for regeneration, said the building was a "testament to the hard work of all those who worked in the lead mines in the area over many years". Grants from funders WREN and Cadw are paying for repair work which is being co-ordinated by Denbighshire council.
MGT:
In a bid to preserve a vital piece of industrial heritage, a 19th-century engine building used to pump water out of a mine in Denbighshire is undergoing a meticulous restoration. This historic structure, integral to the local mining operations, is set to be revitalized to its former glory, offering a glimpse into the region's rich industrial past.

The engine building, part of a once-thriving mining community, played a crucial role in the mine's operations by ensuring the efficient removal of water, a common challenge in mining during that era. The restoration project aims to maintain the authenticity of the original construction while incorporating modern conservation techniques to ensure its longevity.

Local historians and conservationists are collaborating on the project, emphasizing the significance of preserving such structures not only for their historical value but also for their educational potential. The restored engine house is anticipated to become a focal point for educational tours, allowing visitors to explore the mechanics and ingenuity behind the engine that once powered the mine.

Funding for the restoration is being sourced from a combination of public grants and private donations, reflecting the community's commitment to safeguarding its industrial heritage. Local authorities have expressed optimism that the restored building will attract tourism and provide educational opportunities for schools and researchers interested in industrial history.

As the project progresses, specialists are carefully examining the structure to ensure that all original materials are preserved where possible. This delicate balance of restoration and conservation is key to maintaining the historical integrity of the engine building.

The community eagerly anticipates the completion of the restoration, hopeful that it will serve as a lasting tribute to the industrious spirit that defined Denbighshire's mining heritage.

The community eagerly anticipates the completion of the restoration, hopeful that it will serve as a lasting tribute to the industrious spirit that defined Denbighshire's mining heritage.

prompt: An e-book at the centre of a row over who can use the term "space marine" is back on sale on the Amazon website.
HWT: The Spots the Space Marine story was taken off Amazon after model-soldier maker Games Workshop complained it infringed its trademark on the phrase. A blog post about the row by the story's US author, Maggie Hogarth, led to much criticism for Games Workshop. And digital rights group the Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) said it had then helped Amazon "review" the case. In a statement about the row, the EFF said it was "outrageous" for Games Workshop to claim any rights over a term that had been in wide use in fiction since the 1930s. It said the case was an example of a growing trend, in which trademark and rights owners targeted the "weakest link" in the chain of people that helped content, be it fiction, movies or music, appear online. Often, said the EFF, the weakest link was an ISP, a hosting company or a website that acted as a store front or aggregator for many different creators. Such "providers usually don't have the resources and/or the inclination to investigate trademark infringement claims", it said. Many simply removed the disputed content immediately to stay "neutral" and avoid trouble, said the EFF, but that made it hard for those on the end of trademark claims to mount a challenge. The online chatter also prompted Games Workshop to put a statement about the row on its Facebook page, in which it said it had "no choice" but to act in cases where its trademarks in a commercially available product were being used without its consent. Despite this, it said, it had never claimed to have rights over the ways in which the terms "warhammer" or "space marine" were used in day-to-day speech. This everyday use also covered a "body of prose", it added. "Trademarks as opposed to use of a word in prose or everyday language are two very different things," it said. "Games Workshop is always vigilant in protecting the former, but never makes any claim to owning the latter."
MGT:
In a contentious legal battle that has had the sci-fi community on edge, an e-book once embroiled in a copyright dispute is back on sale on Amazon. The book, which centers around the concept of "space marines," had been at the heart of a heated debate over who holds the rights to use this popular genre term.

The dispute originated when a self-published author released a science fiction novel titled "The Last Space Marine," only to face legal threats from a major publisher. The publisher claimed that the use of "space marine" in the book's title infringed on their trademark since they had published a series under a similar name. The author argued that the term was generic within the genre, akin to "police officer" or "firefighter," and therefore not subject to exclusive ownership.

After months of legal back-and-forth, the case was settled out of court, allowing the e-book to return to the digital shelves of Amazon. The resolution of this dispute has broader implications for authors and publishers within the genre. Many in the literary community have been closely watching the case, concerned about the potential for increased trademark claims over commonly used genre terms.

The author of "The Last Space Marine" expressed relief at the outcome, stating, “This has been a challenging ordeal, but I am glad to see that the book is back available for readers who enjoy space opera.” The settlement also included a clause that aims to clarify the use of certain terms, though details remain confidential.

The publisher involved in the dispute has not publicly commented on the settlement but has issued a statement emphasizing their commitment to protecting intellectual property. "We believe in fair use and protecting the creative works of our authors," said a spokesperson. "This case has helped to clarify certain aspects of trademark law within the genre."

The return of the e-book has been met with enthusiasm from fans, who have eagerly awaited its availability. Online forums and social media platforms have buzzed with discussions about the implications of the case for future sci-fi works. Some fans have expressed concern over the precedent this might set, while others see it as a victory for creative freedom.

Legal experts have weighed in, suggesting that the case could influence how trademarks are handled in the genre. They note that while companies have the right to protect their brands, there is also a need to balance this with the creative liberties of individual authors. The outcome of this dispute may lead to more nuanced guidelines on the use of genre-specific terms in titles and content.

As the dust settles on this legal skirmish, the sci-fi community remains vigilant. Authors and publishers alike will likely keep a close watch on how this case shapes the landscape of science fiction literature, ensuring that the genre continues to thrive without undue restrictions.

prompt: A bill of 16,500 shekels ($4,393; Â£3,285) handed to a group of eight Chinese tourists in a restaurant near Jerusalem has sparked an online row.
HWT: It all started when the head of Israel's association of tour operators posted a photo of the bill, suggesting the visitors may have been "suckered". But the restaurant's owners contest this, and give a different version of how the meal unfolded. They say the group had a gourmet meal and the venue was closed to host them. The bill, from the popular Abu Ghosh restaurant on the outskirts of West Jerusalem, allegedly included 5,900 shekels in alcohol, 4,000 shekels for the use of the private room and 3,150 shekels for the main course. On top of what was consumed by the group, there was a service charge of 1,500 shekels. In a post on Facebook (in Hebrew) with a picture of the bill, Yossi Fatael, chairman of the Israel Incoming Tour Operators Association, said the group's tourist agent confirmed they had paid the bill. "There may be a billion Chinese, but they may not all be suckers," he said. "This is how we are destroying our own budding potential of the Chinese market in Israel." But Jawdat Ibrahim, one of Abu Ghosh's owners, disputed this. He said, also on Facebook (in Hebrew), the group had a gourmet meal that lasted for eight hours, with special desserts, specially ordered alcoholic drinks and artists - and that the restaurant was closed to the public to host them. He also said the eight had insisted on paying the service charge. The post had pictures of what he said was the specially produced decoration to host the group. The Chinese visitors have not been identified. Some 6,900 Chinese tourists visited Israel in July, according to the Central Bureau of Statistics.  In the same month, there were 57,000 tourists from the US and 31,600 from France.
MGT:
In an unexpected turn of events at a Jerusalem restaurant, a bill totaling 16,500 shekels ($4,393; £3,285) for a group of eight Chinese tourists has ignited an online debate. The incident, which unfolded over what seemed to be a standard dining experience, quickly spiraled into a viral discussion about pricing transparency and customer service.

The tourists, visiting one of Jerusalem's popular dining spots, were taken aback when presented with the hefty bill. Initially believing it to be a mistake, they reviewed the charges with the restaurant staff, only to find the total corroborated by the menu prices. The bill breakdown raised eyebrows, with several dishes and drinks contributing to the steep sum.

Social media users have since weighed in on the incident, with opinions sharply divided. Some argue that the tourists should have been more vigilant about the prices before ordering, while others criticize the restaurant for not providing clear pricing information upfront. The debate has highlighted a broader issue faced by tourists worldwide: the challenge of navigating foreign pricing systems and the expectation of transparent pricing.

Restaurant representatives have responded to the controversy, stating that all menu prices are clearly listed and that the bill reflects the orders placed by the group. They emphasized that their establishment adheres to standard pricing practices and that the tourists were free to review the menu before ordering.

The incident has sparked discussions about the responsibilities of both consumers and businesses in ensuring fair pricing practices. For tourists, the advice from seasoned travelers is to ask for menu prices in their preferred currency and to confirm the cost of dishes and drinks before ordering.

This event serves as a reminder of the potential pitfalls of international dining and the importance of clear communication between patrons and service providers. As the story continues to circulate online, it raises awareness about the need for transparency in the hospitality industry, prompting restaurants to consider how they present their pricing to avoid similar situations in the future.

prompt: Cyprus is lifting the last remaining capital controls it imposed on its banking system during the financial crisis of 2013.
HWT: Cyprus was the only crisis-hit eurozone country to restrict capital transfers, as it faced a run on the banks. The controls were eased in January. There will no longer be a monthly cap of €20,000 (£15,000; $22,000) on transfers by individuals to foreign banks, or of €10,000 for travellers moving money out of the country. Cyprus received a €10bn bailout from the EU and International Monetary Fund (IMF) after its biggest banks nearly collapsed in March 2013 because of huge losses on their Greek investments. The island's second-biggest lender, Cyprus Popular Bank (also known as Laiki Bank), was wound up and deposits worth more than €100,000 in the largest bank, Bank of Cyprus, were seized. Those measures were part of the deal to ensure that Cyprus funded part of the €10bn bailout. Speaking on Friday, Cyprus President Nicos Anastasiades voiced confidence that the Mediterranean island was recovering well, despite three years of recession. Lifting capital controls, he said, was "a vote of confidence in our banking system which, now fully independent of Greek banking institutions, can move forward". The Greek debt crisis had a severe impact on Cypriot banks, which lost about €4.5bn worth of Greek sovereign bonds - equivalent to 25% of Cypriot gross domestic product, Reuters news agency reports.
MGT:
Cyprus has officially lifted the final capital controls it imposed on its banking system during the 2013 financial crisis, marking a significant milestone in the country's economic recovery. This move is expected to restore full freedom of capital movement within the eurozone, bolstering confidence in Cyprus's financial sector.

The controls, initially introduced in March 2013, were implemented to prevent a bank run and the potential collapse of the financial system following a severe banking crisis. These restrictions included limits on cash withdrawals and transfers abroad, as well as capital controls on the movement of funds, affecting both businesses and individuals.

With the removal of these controls, businesses can now engage in cross-border transactions without restrictions, facilitating smoother operations and trade. For individuals, this means unrestricted access to their financial assets, both domestically and abroad, enhancing personal financial mobility.

The lifting of controls is seen as a testament to the resilience and recovery of Cyprus's economy, which has made significant strides since the crisis. The government, in collaboration with international bodies, implemented reforms aimed at stabilizing and strengthening the financial sector, restoring investor confidence.

The Central Bank of Cyprus assured that the banking system remains robust, well-capitalized, and capable of withstanding economic fluctuations. The end of these restrictions is anticipated to attract more foreign investment and boost economic growth, positioning Cyprus as a more competitive player in the European and global markets.

While challenges remain, the successful removal of capital controls is a crucial step toward full economic normalization, signaling to the world that Cyprus has overcome one of the most challenging periods in its financial history.

prompt: A teenage demonstrator has been killed during growing unrest in Venezuela, as political and economic crisis deepens.
HWT: The 14-year-old boy and another protester were shot dead in the western city of Barquisimeto on Tuesday night. The local governor blamed armed government supporters. Two students were killed during protests last week. Nicolas Maduro's presidency has come under increasing pressure as the economy suffers and opponents accuse him of creating a dictatorship. Mr Maduro was pelted with objects by angry protesters as he left a military event in the south-eastern state of Bolivar earlier on Tuesday. The latest anti-government demonstrations were sparked by a decision on Friday to bar opposition leader Henrique Capriles from holding public office for 15 years. The dead teenager was identified as Brayan Principal by opposition MP Alfonso Marquina, who said he had been shot in the abdomen. A 36-year-old man was also killed in Barquisimeto in a separate incident, the state prosecution service said. Opposition leaders are calling for a date to be set for postponed regional elections. Mr Maduro has resisted efforts by the opposition to hold a referendum on removing him and has vowed to continue the "socialist revolution" launched by his predecessor Hugo Chavez. He says the economic crisis and efforts to get rid of him are a capitalist conspiracy.
MGT:
In a tragic turn of events amid escalating unrest in Venezuela, a teenage demonstrator has been killed, highlighting the nation's deepening political and economic crisis. The incident occurred during a protest in the capital, Caracas, as citizens took to the streets to voice their frustrations over the deteriorating living conditions and the government's handling of the crisis.

The teenager, whose identity has not been officially released, was reportedly among a group of protesters advocating for change and demanding governmental accountability. Witnesses described chaotic scenes, with clashes between demonstrators and security forces. The use of tear gas and rubber bullets by authorities has been reported, intensifying tensions and anger among the populace.

This recent death has brought international attention back to Venezuela, where the political landscape has been fraught with turmoil for years. The opposition has accused President Nicolás Maduro's government of human rights abuses and economic mismanagement, leading to widespread shortages of basic necessities, hyperinflation, and mass emigration.

Human rights organizations have called for an independent investigation into the teenager's death and urged the Venezuelan government to respect the right to peaceful protest. Meanwhile, Maduro's administration has blamed foreign powers for inciting violence and unrest, a claim often refuted by opposition leaders and international observers.

As Venezuela grapples with this latest loss of life, the call for peaceful resolution and dialogue grows louder, with many hoping for a path forward that can bring stability and prosperity to a nation in dire need.

prompt: Power has been reconnected to all homes in Wales, more than 48 hours after Storm Doris battered the country.
HWT: Scottish Power said it reconnected the last of the homes, all on Anglesey, at about 19:00 GMT on Saturday. About 600 engineers had been drafted in to restore supplies after 80,000 properties originally suffered power cuts. Vans had provided hot food and drinks to those affected, with breakfast also delivered on Saturday. Scottish Power spokesman Paul Ferguson said there would be plenty of work to do in the long-term to deal with the storm's damage. Meanwhile, Arriva Trains Wales is running a replacement bus service between Llanelli and Shrewsbury on Saturday because of storm damage to trains and overhead wires. The Llandudno to Blaenau Ffestiniog line will be shut until Monday as buses replace trains on an amended timetable. Western Power Distribution worked overnight on Friday to restore power to 240 properties in south and west Wales, 157 in Pembrokeshire and 83 in Powys. On Thursday, Storm Doris caused damage and affected travel and power supplies across Wales. Wales recorded the strongest gust of wind in the UK as the weather station at Capel Curig in Snowdonia peaked at 94mph (151km/h). North Wales was worst affected by the storm and North Wales Police received about 500 more calls than usual.
MGT:
Power has been fully restored to all homes in Wales after a prolonged outage caused by Storm Doris, which battered the country more than 48 hours ago. The severe weather brought widespread disruption, affecting thousands of households and businesses across the region.

Storm Doris hit Wales with gusts reaching up to 80 miles per hour, leading to fallen trees and debris that damaged power lines and infrastructure. Electricity firms worked tirelessly around the clock to address the extensive damage and restore service. Despite the challenging conditions, teams managed to prioritize restoring power to critical facilities, including hospitals and emergency services, before focusing on residential areas.

The efforts of thousands of engineers and support staff were instrumental in reconnecting homes in a relatively short period. Utility companies have expressed gratitude for the patience and cooperation of the public during the outage and have promised to review their procedures to better handle future weather events.

Local communities showed remarkable resilience during the storm, with volunteers assisting those in isolated areas. Councils and emergency services provided updates and advice through social media and local news outlets, helping to keep residents informed.

The restoration of power marks the end of a challenging period for residents and businesses affected by the storm. As the region begins to recover, attention is now turning to repairing and reinforcing infrastructure to withstand similar events in the future.

prompt: Former Olympic cyclist Chris Boardman has spoken of his frustration that no one has been charged one year after his mother was killed in a fatal crash.
HWT: Carol Boardman died after her bike collided with a pick-up truck in Connah's Quay, Flintshire, last July. Her son, a gold medallist, said on Twitter that the family had been trying to carry on and lead a "normal life". North Wales Police confirmed the force is still investigating Mrs Boardman's death and no charges had been made. Boardman, who won gold at the 1992 Barcelona Games, said that a year after his mum's death he has seen his mum in a dozen places, "smiling at her new grandson" and even spotted her at "The Tour". He said: "It's been heart-wrenching watching my dad try to come to terms with the absence of his soul mate. "We've all had to try and carry on living a 'normal life' it's what my mum would have wanted. But it doesn't feel normal. "A year on there still has not been a decision on even to prosecute." Mrs Boardman, who competed in cycling races in her youth, was taken to hospital with serious injuries following the collision on 17 July last year.
MGT:
Former Olympic cyclist Chris Boardman has expressed his deep frustration over the fact that no charges have been brought forward one year after his mother, Jennifer, was killed in a fatal road crash. Boardman, who is a prominent advocate for road safety and a former professional cyclist, highlighted the urgent need for accountability and justice in such tragic cases.

The crash occurred in September last year when his mother was crossing a road in Lancashire. The incident has since sparked widespread debate about the effectiveness of the current legal framework in dealing with road traffic offenses that result in fatalities. Boardman has been vocal about the shortcomings he perceives in the system and has called for significant reforms to ensure that those responsible for road deaths are held accountable.

His advocacy extends beyond personal grief, as he has long championed improved road safety measures and more effective enforcement of traffic laws. Boardman's frustration underscores a broader call to action from families affected by similar tragedies, who are seeking not only justice for their loved ones but also systemic changes to prevent future incidents.

As the anniversary of the tragic event approaches, Boardman remains committed to fighting for change, hoping that his efforts, along with those of other advocates, will lead to a more just and safe road environment for all. The lack of charges so far continues to fuel his determination to push for reforms that will honor the memory of his mother and protect others from similar fates.

prompt: Exeter head coach Rob Baxter says it is "scary" that his side needed a record-breaking eight bonus-point wins in a row to seal a home play-off semi-final.
HWT: They finished the regular Premiership season on a 15-game unbeaten run, but only secured second on the final day. Until Exeter's streak, no side had ever achieved more than six successive maximum-point wins in the top flight. "It shows you the quality of the Premiership and how well we've had to do," Baxter told BBC Radio Devon. "It's still a bit scary when you look back and think. If any one of those eight successive bonus-point wins had been losses, we might well be sitting here in third and going away in the semi-final." The Devon side host reigning champions Saracens in the last four on 20 May, as they look to reach the Premiership final for the second year in a row. While Exeter have no game before then, Sarries play French club Clermont Auvergne in the Champions Cup final at Murrayfield on 13 May. "Whether we play Saracens next or we play them later, we've got to do it at some stage, so I'm quite looking forward to bringing them to Sandy Park," added Baxter. "We've actually had to put that run of games together to be where we are now, and that gives the players great credit for how they've held that together over such an extended period."
MGT:
Exeter Chiefs head coach Rob Baxter expressed his concerns about the team's recent performance, describing it as "scary" that they needed a record-breaking eight consecutive bonus-point victories to secure a home play-off semi-final spot. Despite the team's success in achieving this feat, Baxter emphasized the need for improvement, highlighting that the Chiefs' performance was inconsistent throughout the regular season.

The Chiefs finished the regular campaign with a record number of bonus-point wins, demonstrating their ability to accumulate points in each of these crucial matches. However, Baxter pointed out that this streak was necessary only because of earlier slip-ups that left the team needing to catch up in the league table. He noted that relying on such a streak was not a sustainable or desirable strategy for long-term success.

Reflecting on the season, Baxter acknowledged the resilience and determination of the squad in overcoming these challenges. The record-breaking run showcased the team's ability to perform under pressure, but Baxter stressed the importance of building a more consistent foundation for future campaigns. He emphasized that the team must address the underlying issues that led to their early-season struggles to avoid similar situations in the future.

As the Chiefs prepare for their home play-off semi-final, Baxter remains focused on ensuring the team is mentally and physically ready for the challenges ahead. The experience gained from this season, both positive and negative, will be crucial in shaping the team's approach to the upcoming matches. With a strong finish to the regular season, the Chiefs are now in a position to compete for the Premiership title, but Baxter's comments serve as a reminder that there is still work to be done to achieve consistent excellence.

prompt: The balls used in Sunday's Super Bowl will be given "added security" amid the ongoing investigation into the NFL's 'deflate-gate' controversy.
HWT: Finalists New England Patriots used under-inflated balls in their victory over Indianapolis Colts. Referee chief Dean Blandino said 108 balls will be used as the Patriots take on Seattle Seahawks in Arizona. "There will be some added security just because of the environment we're in for this game," said Blandino. During a regular game, each team has 12 balls which are given to the officials before the game to be inspected. But in the Super Bowl, because some of the footballs are later given to charity, each team has 54. All of the balls will be taken into custody by the NFL on Friday after the Seattle Seahawks and New England Patriots have prepared them. The footballs will be inspected by referee Bill Vinkovich three hours before the game, which takes place at the University of Phoenix Stadium. Blandino said the inspection of the footballs by referee Walt Anderson before New England's 45-7 win over the Colts was handled properly and the officiating is "not part of the investigation". "Everything was properly tested and marked before the game," added Blandino. "Walt gauged the footballs himself. It is something he has done throughout his career."
MGT:

prompt: Police searching for missing toddler Ben Needham on the Greek island of Kos have uncovered ancient graves.
HWT: The 21-month-old from Sheffield went missing during a family holiday in 1991. Following a suggestion he may have been killed and buried on the island a fresh excavation of farmland began on Monday. The four or five graves are believed to date from 1,500 years ago but police said the discovery would not hamper the investigation. Forensic archaeologists have said they are confident the search is being conducted at exactly the right depth of soil relevant to 25 years ago. The digging has concentrated on an area around a waste tank. Nutrients found in the soil have indicated human traces and a full analysis of soil samples will be carried out. Officers have said they believe the material will most likely relate to a nearby cess tank. Danny Savage, BBC correspondent in Kos The graves found in Kos are all believed to contain the remains of adults. They are lying head to toe close to the boundary of the olive grove where the dig is taking place. Work will continue around them and police said the ancient discovery was not unexpected. There was initial concern from Greek locals that this would have hindered progress at the site but I have been told by the investigating team here in Kos that is not the case. The site being searched is on land where Ben was last seen playing while his grandfather was renovating a property 25 years ago. The Needham family have always believed Ben was abducted but South Yorkshire Police are now investigating whether he was accidentally run over and killed by a bulldozer.
MGT:

In a recent development, during a routine search of the vicinity, police stumbled upon what appears to be ancient graves. This unexpected find has necessitated a temporary halt to the search operations as archaeologists are brought in to carefully study and preserve these historical remains. The discovery has sparked interest in the archaeological community, with experts eager to learn more about the site's origins and significance.

The police, while maintaining their focus on finding Ben, expressed optimism that this new finding could potentially lead to breakthroughs. "We are committed to leaving no stone unturned in our search for Ben Needham," stated the head of the investigation team. "While we are excited about this historical discovery, our primary goal remains to provide answers to Ben's family."

The local community has rallied around the search efforts, offering support and assistance to the police. Many have shared their memories of Ben and offered information that could aid in the investigation.

This convergence of historical discovery and modern investigation underscores the enduring hope and determination that continue to drive the search for Ben Needham. As archaeologists work alongside police, both teams remain hopeful that their collaborative efforts will eventually lead to the resolution of this longstanding mystery.

prompt: South Africa's economy shrank by an annualised rate of 0.6% in the first three months of the year, the worst quarterly performance in five years, official data has shown.
HWT: The contraction, which was bigger than analysts expected, was largely due to a slump in mining activity, the figures from Statistics South Africa showed. Gold mining saw production fall, as well as platinum and diamond mining. Workers in platinum mines have been on strike for five months. "This makes for grim reading," said Razia Khan at Standard Chartered Bank. "Mining, hit by protracted industrial unrest, fell almost 25% on an annualised basis. Manufacturing was down 4.4%." This is the first quarter of negative growth since the second quarter of 2009. In the final quarter of 2013, the economy grew by an annualised rate of 3.8%. The rand fell by about 1% against the dollar following the release of the figures, to 10.44 rand. Compared with a year earlier, the South African economy grew by 1.6%. GDP growth has been slowing steadily for the past three years as the economy struggles with high levels of unemployment, which currently stand at almost 25%.
MGT:
South Africa's economy contracted by an annualised rate of 0.6% in the first quarter of the year, marking its worst quarterly performance in five years, according to official data released today. The decline reflects a confluence of factors that have dampened economic activity, including subdued consumer spending, ongoing electricity supply constraints, and weaker global demand.

The contraction in GDP, or Gross Domestic Product, underscores the challenges facing the South African economy, which has been grappling with structural issues such as high unemployment and significant public debt. Analysts have pointed to persistent power outages, known as load-shedding, as a major impediment to economic growth, affecting both industrial production and consumer confidence.

Moreover, the global economic environment has posed additional challenges. Trade tensions and slowing growth in major economies have led to reduced demand for South African exports, further straining the country's economic outlook. The mining sector, a key driver of the economy, has also been affected by fluctuating commodity prices and regulatory uncertainties.

Despite these setbacks, government officials and economists remain cautiously optimistic about the potential for recovery in the coming quarters. Efforts are underway to address some of the structural issues through policy reforms and investments in infrastructure. However, for a robust rebound, sustained improvements in both domestic and international conditions will be essential.

prompt: Lowly Carrick Rangers stunned champions Crusaders with a remarkable 4-3 win in Tuesday Irish Premiership clash.
HWT: Media playback is not supported on this device Carrick, hammered 4-0 by the Crues three days earlier, were amazingly 3-0 up at half-time after goals by Daniel Kelly, Adam Salley and Aaron Harmon. Crusaders replied through Michael Carvill, Paul Heatley and an Aaron Smyth own goal but sub Ben Roy's 87th minute finish sealed the surprise win. Josh Robinson of Crusaders and Carrick boss Gary Haveron got late red cards. Crusaders remain five points ahead of second-placed Linfield. Defender Robinson received the red card for a crunching touchline challenge on home striker Roy. It sparked ugly scenes as players and management clashed on the side of the pitch. Rangers manager Haveron was sent to the stand for his part in the unseemly scuffle. However, the Carrick boss will have been pleased with his side as they move above Ballinamallard and into 10th place in the relegation battle. They had lost their last 13 matches against the Crues, but raced into an early lead thanks to a curling Kelly effort. Salley doubled their advantage on 29 minutes when he rifled the ball past keeper Sean O'Neill. It was the youngster's second goal since joining Rangers on loan from Linfield in January. Salley then turned provider for Carrick's third, beating Colin Coates before teeing up Harmon for a simple finish before the break. Crusaders hit back with Carvill pouncing early in the second half and, when Heatley pounced on a poor kick-out by keeper Brian Neeson to make it 3-2, the comeback looked on. But Roy, just on as a replacement, raced through to put Carrick 4-2 up. Robinson's red card and the subsequent touchline brawl soured things and the own goal came too late to save Crusaders.
MGT:
In a stunning upset, underdog Carrick Rangers triumphed over reigning champions Crusaders with a thrilling 4-3 victory in a high-octane Irish Premiership clash on Tuesday. The match, held at the lush grounds of Brandywell, saw the Rangers execute a masterclass in resilience and tactical acumen, leaving the Crusaders stunned and fans exhilarated.

The game commenced with an early goal from Carrick Rangers' forward, Jamie McGrath, who capitalized on a defensive lapse to put the underdogs ahead in the 12th minute. This early strike set the tone for what was to become an enthralling encounter. Crusaders responded swiftly, with their star striker, Daniel Keatings, equalizing just eight minutes later, showcasing his remarkable poise and finishing ability.

However, the real drama unfolded in the second half. In the 60th minute, Rangers' midfielder, Sean O'Donnell, delivered a pinpoint cross that found the head of newcomer Alex Thompson, who nodded the ball home, giving Carrick Rangers the lead once again. The Crusaders, undeterred, mounted a formidable counterattack. Their captain, Liam Doyle, scored a stunning free-kick in the 75th minute, leveling the score at 2-2 and injecting new life into the match.

The tension reached its peak in the final minutes. With just three minutes remaining, Carrick Rangers launched a swift counterattack, culminating in a sublime team move that ended with their substitute, Patrick Murphy, slotting the ball into the bottom corner, putting the Rangers ahead 3-2. Crusaders, desperate to salvage a point, pushed forward, and their efforts paid off when Conor Murphy scored a last-gasp equalizer in the 89th minute, bringing the score to 3-3.

However, the drama was far from over. In dramatic fashion, Rangers' goalkeeper, Declan O'Sullivan, launched a daring long-range drive in the 92nd minute, catching the Crusaders' defense off-guard and securing a 4-3 victory. This remarkable goal not only sealed the win but also etched the match into Premiership folklore.

Carrick Rangers' triumph is a testament to their tenacity and strategic brilliance, while the Crusaders will rue a missed opportunity to extend their championship reign. This match will be remembered as one of the most exhilarating encounters in recent league history, a true celebration of the unpredictability and passion that defines football.

prompt: Goals from Britt Assombalonga and Nathaniel Mendez-Laing saw Peterborough defeat Exeter and seal their place in the second round of the FA Cup.
HWT: Assombalonga scored from point-blank range after being picked out by Mark Little's delightful low delivery. Debutant Hogan Ephraim then stylishly slipped the ball through to Mendez-Laing to secure their passage. Assombalonga dragged two other chances wide, while Arron Davies forced Posh keeper Bobby Olejnik into a late save. Peterborough United boss Darren Ferguson told BBC Radio Cambridgeshire: "I thought we were patient the first half, maybe lacked a bit of quality but I thought for the whole of the second half we were very good. Media playback is not supported on this device "I think it typifies the problem at the moment where everyone expects us to win 6-0 when your first question says we didn't really get going until the 70th minute. "They're a very good team, Exeter, fifth in League Two and a good footballing team. We just had to be patient and we had to produce a better quality in the second half to be fair and we've done that. "I thought the second half we had a lot more life and energy and perhaps it was getting through to the players. There is frustration from people and I think you could see a release in them when we scored the first goal." Exeter City manager Paul Tisdale spoke to BBC Radio Devon: "They (Exeter players) didn't look inferior to the opposition whatsoever, we just needed to pack a punch around that last third when we had our moment and we didn't quite make that happen. Media playback is not supported on this device "We conceded a rather feeble goal and if we're going to be a good side that can't happen too often. "So I leave today unhappy with the result, unhappy with the way it transpired, but happy with the players individually. "It's been a character of our away performances this season that we've looked to be conservative and then build our game, and you can see that from the substitutions we made."
MGT:
Peterborough United secured their spot in the second round of the FA Cup with a convincing 2-0 victory over Exeter City at London Road Stadium. Goals from Britt Assombalonga and Nathaniel Mendez-Laing were crucial in sealing the win for the home side, who showcased their attacking prowess and defensive solidity throughout the match.

The game got off to a lively start, with Peterborough looking to capitalize on their home advantage. It wasn't long before Assombalonga made his presence felt. In the 23rd minute, he converted a well-crafted goal, latching onto a precise through ball from Mendez-Laing. The forward controlled the ball with his chest before calmly finishing past Exeter’s goalkeeper, giving Peterborough the lead.

Exeter City, known for their resilience and solid performances, attempted to respond to Peterborough's early breakthrough. However, they struggled to create clear-cut chances against a determined Peterborough defense. The visitors continued to press forward, but their efforts were often thwarted by the hosts' organized backline.

In the second half, Peterborough continued to dominate possession and looked to extend their lead. Mendez-Laing, who had been involved in Assombalonga’s goal, was a constant threat on the flanks, creating several opportunities for his team. It was his tireless work rate and incisive passing that set up the second goal in the 67th minute.

Mendez-Laing delivered a pinpoint cross into the box, which found Assombalonga lurking behind the defense. The striker expertly headed the ball into the back of the net, doubling Peterborough's advantage and effectively sealing the win. Exeter’s attempts to stage a comeback were met with strong resistance from Peterborough, who managed to hold onto their lead until the final whistle.

With this victory, Peterborough United have booked their place in the second round of the FA Cup, marking a significant achievement for the club this season. The win also served as a testament to the team’s tactical discipline and ability to execute their game plan effectively. For Exeter City, despite the defeat, the match provided valuable experience against a high-caliber opponent.

The victory was celebrated by both players and fans alike, who were delighted with the team’s performance. As Peterborough United prepare for their next challenge in the FA Cup, they will look to build on this momentum and continue their strong form. For Exeter, the focus will now shift to their League Two campaign as they aim to climb the table and secure a more favorable position in the league standings.
