prompt: Etsy, the online marketplace known for handmade goods, said it is cutting 140 staff in a bid to sharpen focus and improve results.
HWT: The announcement comes after an earlier round of layoffs in May and the resignation of the firm's chief executive. Etsy, which became a public company in 2015, has struggled to turn a profit. Competition has also mounted from other firms, including Amazon, which has launched its own handicraft market. The two rounds of layoffs total about 230, or roughly 22% of the firm's workforce at the end of 2016. Most of the cuts announced on Wednesday will come at the firm's Brooklyn headquarters, in positions such as marketing, product management and administration. Founded in 2005, Etsy employed about 1,000 people globally at the end of 2016 and had about 1.7 million active sellers. The company made $365m in revenue in 2016, but it has posted a loss every year since at least 2012, according to its annual report. At least one of its shareholders has pressured the firm to consider selling itself. Two private equity firms - TPG Group and Dragoneer Investment Group - said last month they had taken a large stake in the company. The firm said the layoffs would lead to as much as $8.8m in charges.
MGT:
Etsy, the well-known online marketplace for handmade and vintage items, has announced that it will be reducing its workforce by 140 positions. This decision aims to streamline operations and enhance the company's overall performance. The move is part of a broader strategy to sharpen its focus and improve results amid a competitive e-commerce landscape.

In recent years, Etsy has faced challenges in maintaining its growth trajectory, prompting the company to reassess its operational strategies. The layoffs are expected to affect various departments, with a focus on roles that are not directly contributing to the core objectives of the platform.

Etsy's CEO, Josh Silverman, emphasized that the decision was difficult but necessary to ensure the company's long-term success. He stated that the company must become more agile and efficient to continue delivering value to its sellers and customers. "We need to be more focused on our core business and make the changes necessary to drive sustainable growth," Silverman commented.

The reduction in staff is part of a larger restructuring effort that includes revisiting Etsy's pricing model and enhancing its technology infrastructure. These changes are intended to better support the millions of sellers who rely on Etsy to reach a global audience.

While layoffs are never easy, Etsy is committed to supporting affected employees through severance packages and outplacement services. The company remains optimistic about its future, aiming to return to a path of growth and innovation that aligns with its mission to empower individuals to make a living by doing what they love.

prompt: Wales and Falkirk midfielder Owain Tudur Jones has retired from football because of ongoing knee problems.
HWT: Jones, 30, started his career at local side Bangor City and went on to play for clubs including Swansea, Swindon, Norwich and Hibernian. He won seven Wales caps after his debut against Luxembourg in March, 2008. "I have been advised by the knee specialist that it is in my best interests to retire from football due to a knee injury," Jones said. "I would like to go on record to thank Falkirk FC, in particular [director] Ronnie Bateman, [manager] Peter Houston and club physio Kris Robertson for all of their help during this time and I wish them the very best as they chase a play-off spot and Scottish Cup success." Falkirk said they are "saddened" by Jones' retirement and wished him well for the future. Jones' other clubs include Yeovil Town, Brentford and Inverness Caledonian Thistle, who gave the midfielder his first taste of Scottish football when they signed him in July 2011. He moved to Hibernian in 2013 and was snapped up on a free the following year by Falkirk, but unfortunately his injury problems limited him to five appearances for the Scottish Championship side.
MGT:
Owain Tudur Jones, the Wales and Falkirk midfielder, has announced his retirement from professional football, citing persistent knee issues that have plagued his career. At 29, Tudur Jones has ended his journey in the sport due to these ongoing problems, leaving behind a career marked by talent and resilience.

Tudur Jones, who began his career with Wrexham, went on to represent clubs such as Swansea, Cardiff City, and Nottingham Forest before joining Falkirk. He made a significant impact on the field, known for his work ethic, technical skills, and leadership both on and off the pitch. His international career with Wales also saw him earn 24 caps, showcasing his abilities on a larger stage.

Despite the challenges posed by his knee problems, Tudur Jones remains grateful for the experiences and opportunities football has provided him. He expressed his heartfelt thanks to teammates, coaches, and fans who supported him throughout his career. "Football has given me so much, and I am incredibly grateful for the memories and relationships I've built along the way," Tudur Jones said in a statement.

Falkirk and the wider football community have expressed condolences and support for his decision. The club acknowledged his contribution and wished him well in his future endeavors beyond football, highlighting his professionalism and determination as an inspiration to many. Tudur Jones leaves behind a legacy as a dedicated player whose career, though cut short, was filled with passion and commitment.

prompt: Acclaimed sculptor Antony Gormley has defended criticisms of his latest installation featuring life-size human statues on top of university buildings.
HWT: Some students at the University of East Anglia (UEA) in Norwich claimed the figures resemble people contemplating jumping off. But Gormley said all art should be "unsettling" and his work was "nothing to do with suicide". The work is part of a sculpture park being created on the campus. One student said: "I really did think it was someone who was going to jump off a building." Gormley is one the UK's leading artists and is probably best known for his Angel of the North. In defending the UEA installation, he said: "These works are nothing to do with suicide, they're actually to do with life and they're placed on the skyline in a way to make us think about space and distance. "Universities are places where people spend a lot of time thinking about the thoughts of others, "I think it's a wonderful place to balance that intellectual life with an object that is silent, it doesn't need to be read. It has to be felt, it has to be lived with," he added. Calvin Winner of the by the Sainsbury Centre for Visual Arts, which created the art trail, told the BBC: "Part of campus life is about debate and I would have been disappointed if there had been none." The Event Horizon work, which is a touring exhibition, also provoked fearful reactions when it displayed in New York and London. Normally shown in cities, Gormley said he chose to display the work at the UEA because of its Brutalist concrete architecture in natural surroundings. "It shows how human made things can co-exist with the elemental world," he added. The sculptures will remain at the UEA for five years.
MGT:
Acclaimed sculptor Antony Gormley has responded to criticisms of his latest installation, which features life-size human statues perched atop university buildings. The installation, part of a broader exhibition exploring themes of human presence and connectivity, has sparked debate and divided opinions within the academic community and the general public.

The statues, crafted from weathering steel, are positioned in a way that they appear to be surveying the landscape below, creating a powerful visual metaphor for observation and reflection. Gormley, known for his thought-provoking works that often explore the human form and its relationship with space, stated that the installation aims to provoke dialogue about the role of education and the future of societal development.

Critics, however, have raised concerns about the practical and aesthetic implications of placing such large, steel structures on historic university buildings. Some faculty members and students argue that the installation disrupts the architectural integrity of the campus and distracts from the educational environment. There are also logistical concerns regarding the maintenance and safety of the structures, particularly in adverse weather conditions.

In his defense, Gormley emphasized that the installation is a temporary exhibit, designed to challenge perceptions and encourage critical thinking. He argued that the statues serve as a reminder of the potential for human creativity and innovation, urging viewers to contemplate their place in the world. Gormley's previous works, including the famous "Angel of the North," have similarly pushed boundaries and sparked conversation, and he remains committed to using art as a medium for social and philosophical exploration.

Supporters of the installation praise its boldness and the conversation it stimulates about the intersection of art, education, and public space. They argue that the statues offer a unique opportunity for students and visitors to engage with contemporary art in a meaningful way, fostering a deeper appreciation for the role of creativity in academic settings.

As the debate continues, Gormley's installation stands as a testament to the power of art to challenge and inspire, inviting viewers to reflect on their surroundings and the broader implications of human progress. Whether seen as a disruptive force or a thought-provoking masterpiece, the installation undeniably succeeds in sparking dialogue and engaging a wide audience in discussions about the future of education and the evolving landscape of public art.

prompt: Bombardier has backed its CSeries plane to win new orders, following the release of fresh technical data on its performance at the Paris Air Show.
HWT: Enterprise Minister Jonathan Bell visited company executives in the French capital and said: "I have every belief in its success." The CSeries will enter service with airlines three years behind schedule next year. It is presently short of a 300-order target. Currently, firm orders are 243 and there has not been one since last September. It is also $2bn (£1.29bn) over budget. However, the Canadian aerospace company sees the CSeries Paris debut as a pivotal moment. "There's always a lot of pressure to come up with big orders," president of commercial aircraft Fred Cromer told the BBC. "But right now it's like the old-fashioned days - we are here to show off the equipment." The company's Belfast division makes the CSeries wings at a £520m factory in Queens Island. Full production of the two different sized versions of the aircraft would support 800 jobs in a workforce of 5,700. Invest NI chief executive Alastair Hamilton, who also attended the Paris launch, said:  "I believe they will kick on from today. There are many years ahead for this aircraft." Bombardier's familiar territory is executive jets and this is a major step up into larger passenger planes seating between 100 to 160 passengers. Its competitors are the big two firms Boeing and Airbus. Aviation analyst Mark Pilling of Flightglobal said "They're two great big gorillas. "Bombardier need to execute on this aircraft and get orders." The technical data announced in Paris revealed improved results on fuel economy, the main selling point of the CSeries. The larger CS300 will fly to Belfast on Friday for what is seen as a morale-boosting visit for workers.
MGT:
Bombardier has reaffirmed its confidence in the CSeries aircraft, predicting the jet will secure new orders as it presents newly released technical performance data at the Paris Air Show. The aerospace company is leveraging this prestigious platform to showcase the improvements and capabilities of its CSeries, aiming to attract airlines seeking efficient and reliable aircraft.

The CSeries has been a focal point for Bombardier as it seeks to capture a significant share of the single-aisle market. With its latest enhancements, the aircraft is positioned as a strong competitor, boasting fuel-efficient technology, advanced aerodynamics, and state-of-the-art avionics. These features are designed to meet the evolving needs of airlines, providing both operational cost savings and an enhanced passenger experience.

Bombardier's chief executive highlighted that the CSeries is a game-changer in the narrow-body segment, emphasizing its role in transforming air travel economics. The aircraft's advanced technology is expected to offer a 20% reduction in fuel burn compared to existing models, a critical factor for airlines striving to reduce operational costs amid fluctuating fuel prices.

At the Paris Air Show, Bombardier is showcasing not only the CSeries' technical prowess but also its commitment to sustainability. The company is actively engaging with potential customers, demonstrating how the CSeries can help airlines achieve their environmental goals through reduced emissions.

Industry analysts have noted that Bombardier's strategy at the air show is well-timed, as several airlines are in the market for new aircraft to replace aging fleets. The company is optimistic that the CSeries will be a top choice for these carriers, given its competitive advantages.

In addition to technical demonstrations, Bombardier is also hosting discussions and presentations with industry experts to further highlight the CSeries' benefits. The company aims to solidify its position in the market and build momentum for the aircraft's future success.

As the Paris Air Show progresses, Bombardier remains focused on converting interest into orders, with executives expressing confidence that the CSeries will emerge as a preferred option for airlines seeking innovative and efficient solutions. The company's efforts at the air show underscore its commitment to leading the industry in next-generation aircraft development.

prompt: Burnley manager Sean Dyche is relaxed about his side's wait for a Premier League win, saying "by no means are we at the bottom of the valley".
HWT: The Clarets lie bottom of the table after 10 games on four points, five from safety. "How many worries can you have?" said Dyche. "You could bog yourself down with that junk. Nobody's dead - we're playing football. "The players are motivated to win games and so am I." Burnley welcome Hull to Turf Moor on Saturday, with Steven Reid likely to be available after six weeks out with a groin injury. "Sometimes you've got be in the bottom of the valley to see the top of the mountain," added Dyche. "By no means are we at the bottom of the valley because it's a great journey for us." Burnley, Championship runners-up last season, spent modestly in the summer and have concentrated on improving the club's infrastructure, something Dyche says they do not regret despite their struggles on the pitch. "My job as manager depend on winning games," he said. "I'm not naive to that but there has to be a balance to how this club goes about it. "We had a supersonic journey last year to the Premier League so all the things that should be in place that are at other clubs were not in place." Burnley were beaten 3-0 at Arsenal last Saturday and Dyche revealed Gunners' manager Arsene Wenger invited him to his office after the game. "We had a good chat about everything," he said. "We'd had as many key passes into the box as they had at the stage of the season and we spoke about that. "The defining moment is we don't have (an Alexis) Sanchez - he didn't want to loan him to us."
MGT:
Burnley manager Sean Dyche has expressed his calm attitude regarding his team's ongoing wait for a Premier League victory this season, asserting that despite the lack of wins, the club is not in a dire situation. In an interview, Dyche emphasized that the team remains resilient and is not at the bottom of the league standings, suggesting a belief in the squad's potential to turn their season around.

Currently sitting in mid-table, Burnley has faced a challenging start to the season, having failed to secure a win in their opening matches. However, Dyche remains confident and is focusing on the positives, such as the team's performance and the individual improvements of his players. He noted that the squad has shown promise and competitiveness in several games, even if the results have not yet reflected their efforts.

Dyche highlighted that the club's recent history of bouncing back from tough starts should instill confidence in both the players and the supporters. He pointed out that Burnley has managed to secure good points and climb the table in previous seasons, even after a slow start. This resilience, he believes, is a testament to the club's character and the determination of the players under his management.

The manager also acknowledged the importance of patience and maintaining a long-term perspective. He stressed that while immediate results are crucial, the team must continue to work on their tactics, fitness, and cohesion. Dyche is committed to addressing any areas of concern and is optimistic that with continued hard work, the team will start converting their performances into the much-needed wins.

In terms of squad morale, Dyche is pleased with the team's spirit and unity. He has been working closely with the players to ensure that they remain focused and motivated, despite the pressure of the Premier League. The manager's approach is to foster a positive environment where players feel supported and encouraged to express themselves on the pitch.

As Burnley prepares for their upcoming fixtures, Dyche is confident that the team will soon find their rhythm and start climbing the league table. He remains steadfast in his belief that the club's current position is not a reflection of their true potential, and with continued effort and determination, Burnley will emerge as a competitive force in the league.

prompt: Italy have suffered another blow before facing Wales with centre Michele Campagnaro out injured.
HWT: Exeter's Campagnaro has started all Italy's 2016 Six Nations games and scored two tries on their 2014 visit to Cardiff. Twice-capped Zebre centre Giulio Bisegni, 23, has been called up. Italy earlier lost Edoardo Padovani, Lorenzo Cittadini and George Biagi through injuries suffered in defeat by Ireland. It means the Azzurri must make at least four changes with fly-half Padovani, prop Cittadini and lock Biagi joining Campagnaro on the sidelines. Racing92 prop Martin Castrogiovanni, 34, has been recalled to the 28-man squad following suspension. Perpignan fly-half Tommy Allen is also called up alongside uncapped pair Jacopo Sarto and Tommaso Castello. Italy will be playing their final Six Nations game under coach Jacques Brunel, with Harlequins boss and former Ireland full-back Conor O'Shea expected to take over. The Azzurri are winless in 2016 while Wales are hoping to finish second behind champions England, having lost in this year's tournament for the first time on Saturday.
MGT:
Italy's preparations for their Six Nations clash against Wales faced a setback as centre Michele Campagnaro sustained an injury, ruling him out of the upcoming match. The news came as a significant blow to the Azzurri, who are looking to bounce back from their recent performances. Campagnaro, known for his agility and defensive prowess, was a key component of Italy's backline, and his absence will be felt by the team and coach Franco Smith.

The extent of Campagnaro's injury has not been fully disclosed, but reports suggest it will sideline him for the Wales fixture. The Italian squad is now tasked with finding a suitable replacement to fill the gap left by Campagnaro. This unexpected turn of events puts additional pressure on the squad's depth and versatility as they aim to secure a victory.

Italy's coaching staff is expected to make tactical adjustments to compensate for the loss, potentially giving opportunities to younger players or adjusting their formation. The team's resilience will be tested as they strive to overcome this challenge and maintain competitive form in the Six Nations Championship. As they gear up to face a formidable Welsh side, the Azzurri will need to rally together and demonstrate their ability to adapt and succeed under pressure.

prompt: Visitors to Banksy's latest exhibition will be checked for ID after touted tickets appeared on sale on auction websites for up to £1,000.
HWT: Dismaland opened in Weston-super-Mare a week ago but tickets only went on sale on Tuesday after website problems. Dozens have now appeared on eBay and StubHub with some being sold for many times the face value of £3. A spokesman for the artist warned fans not to buy the touted tickets and to only buy from the official site. On Wednesday, tickets for the show were on sale for between £30 and £1,000 on eBay and an average of about £40 on StubHub. For the past week, visitors have had to queue outside the Tropicana, where the exhibition is based, while issues with online ticketing were resolved. The official Dismaland site went down several times as tickets for the first week went on sale on Tuesday. Those tickets quickly sold out. The show is due to run for another five weeks with further batches of tickets being sold on the official website. The Dismaland exhibition is a dark take on theme parks with a nod to Disneyland, featuring work by more than 50 artists including Bristolian Banksy. Among the exhibits are a distorted mermaid, a dilapidated fairy castle and a boat pond where all the boats are filled with models of migrants, as well as paintings and a beach ball hovering above upturned knives.
MGT:
Visitors to Banksy's latest exhibition will now face identity checks after tickets, which were meant to be free, surfaced on auction sites with prices soaring to £1,000 each. The unauthorised sales prompted the organisers to implement stricter entry protocols to manage the crowds and maintain the exhibition’s integrity.

The highly-anticipated exhibition, which features an array of the elusive street artist's works, has prompted a significant surge in interest. However, the appearance of tickets on auction websites has raised concerns over accessibility and fairness, prompting Banksy’s team to take decisive action.

As part of the updated entry process, attendees will be required to present a valid ID upon arrival. This measure aims to ensure that tickets are used by the rightful owners and to prevent any further resale attempts. Organisers have emphasised that the exhibition remains free, and they are committed to ensuring that the public can enjoy Banksy's art without financial barriers.

The artist, known for his guerrilla tactics and social commentary, has not made any public statements regarding the ticket situation. However, the swift response from the exhibition organisers highlights their dedication to preserving the inclusive nature of the event.

Despite the challenges, excitement continues to build as art enthusiasts and fans eagerly anticipate experiencing the exhibition. The organisers have urged potential visitors to remain vigilant about unauthorised ticket sales and to report any suspicious activity to the appropriate authorities.

In the meantime, the exhibition continues to draw crowds, with many expressing gratitude for the measures taken to keep the event accessible to everyone. Banksy's latest exhibition promises to be a remarkable showcase of his provocative and thought-provoking street art.

prompt: The dress worn by Marilyn Monroe as she sang "Happy Birthday Mr President" to John F Kennedy has been sold at auction for $4.8m (Â£3.9m).
HWT: The figure-hugging Jean Louis gown, with 2,500 crystals, was bought by the Ripley's Believe It or Not museum chain, exceeding the $3m guide price. The company's vice president said it was "most iconic piece of pop culture that there is". Monroe died from a drug overdose just three months after the performance. The sultry rendition for President Kennedy's 45th birthday at a 1962 Democratic fundraiser at New York's Madison Square was one of her last public appearances. President Kennedy was shot dead a year later. The dress, which the auction house said was so tight she had to be sewn into it, had previously been bought at auction for $1.3m in 1999 by the late business mogul and collector Martin Zweig. The sum raised is likely to set a new world record for the most expensive dress sold at auction. Marilyn Monroe's billowing white dress from the Seven Year Itch sold for $4.6 million (plus $1m in commission) in 2011. The largest collection of the screen star's possessions ever offered for auction is being sold by Julien's auction house in Beverly Hills over three days. Also sold on Thursday was the cocktail dress she wore in "Some Like it Hot", which fetched $450,000. Many of the 1,000 lots come from the estate of her acting coach, Lee Strasberg, who became a close friend of the actress. She bequeathed her personal effects and clothing to him in her will.
MGT:
In a landmark auction event, the iconic dress worn by Marilyn Monroe as she serenaded President John F. Kennedy with "Happy Birthday" fetched an impressive $4.8 million (approximately £3.9 million). The auction, held at a renowned auction house, drew significant attention from collectors and fans of Monroe, cementing the dress's status as a piece of cinematic and cultural history.

The dress, a stunning, beaded white halter gown designed by Jean Louis, became famous for the 1962 birthday celebration at the Ambassador Hotel in Los Angeles. Monroe's sultry performance has since been etched into American history, capturing the glamour and intrigue of the era.

The bidding war for the dress was intense, reflecting its extraordinary significance and rarity. The previous record for a piece of Monroe's clothing was set in 2011 when a figure-hugging, sparkly black dress sold for $4.8 million, identical to the price fetched by this iconic birthday ensemble. The dress, which had been stored in a vault for decades, became a symbol of the tragic and glamorous figure that Monroe represented.

The auction house highlighted the dress's impeccable condition, noting that it had been meticulously preserved over the years. The final price exceeded the initial estimates, underscoring the enduring allure of Monroe and her legacy in American culture.

Details about the buyer were not disclosed, adding an air of mystery to the sale. However, the purchaser can now lay claim to an item that is not only a piece of fashion and entertainment history but also a symbol of a pivotal moment in 20th-century American history. Monroe's legacy continues to captivate audiences, and this auction serves as a testament to her enduring impact.

prompt: England one-day captain Eoin Morgan hit the final ball for six to give Sydney Thunder a six-wicket victory over Melbourne Stars in the Big Bash.
HWT: Needing five to win, Morgan, 30, launched Ben Hilfenhaus down the ground as Thunder chased down Stars' 166-8. It was Morgan's final act before joining England in India for the one-day international series this month. His knock of 71 off 50 balls keeps the defending champions' hopes alive after their first win of this year's event. Former England international Kevin Pietersen earlier hit 60 off 37 balls before his dismissal sparked a late collapse for the Stars. The hosts slipped to 85-4 in response before Morgan combined with Australia international Pat Cummins in a partnership of 83 to see his side home with no further loss. Thunder beat Stars in last season's final, but have struggled so far this year, losing their first four games. England take on India in a three-match ODI series starting in Pune on 15 January, with a three-match T20 series to follow.
MGT:
In a thrilling final over of the Big Bash League match, England's one-day cricket captain Eoin Morgan delivered a spectacular performance, leading Sydney Thunder to a six-wicket victory over Melbourne Stars. The match, held at the iconic Sydney Cricket Ground, saw Thunder clinching a hard-fought win thanks to Morgan's dramatic six off the final delivery.

Morgan, who was brought into bat with Thunder needing 15 runs to win, faced the pressure with remarkable composure. With the match hanging in the balance, he connected with the ball beautifully, sending it soaring over the boundary. This audacious six sealed the match for Thunder, leaving the crowd in awe and the Stars scrambling in disbelief.

The victory was crucial for Thunder as they looked to maintain their position at the top of the league table. Morgan's leadership and ability to perform under pressure were praised by teammates and fans alike. His celebration on the field was a fitting tribute to a remarkable innings, highlighting his status as one of the game's elite finishers. This win not only boosted Thunder's standings but also showcased the thrilling unpredictability of T20 cricket.

prompt: The fate of five Picasso murals on buildings damaged in the Anders Breivik bombing in Oslo in 2011 has led to a heated debate in Norway.
HWT: A panel of experts has recommended demolishing the buildings and removing the murals. But art experts say that as the murals were designed by Picasso for those specific buildings, they should remain where they are. The artworks were Picasso's first attempts at concrete murals. The murals were drawn specifically for the government buildings known as H and Y block. Picasso's designs were sandblasted onto the concrete both outside and inside the buildings by the Norwegian artist Carl Nesjar. Both buildings were damaged when Breivik set off a van bomb at the foot of H block in July 2011. It was the start of a series of attacks that left 77 dead, mostly teenagers on the island of Utoeya. The blast in Oslo killed eight people and badly damaged the H block, along with neighbouring ministries. A panel of experts has decided the most economical solution would be to demolish the buildings, cut the murals out and place them elsewhere. A recent poll by Norwegian newspaper Verdens Gang showed public opinion was divided, with 39.5% supporting demolition, while 34.3% thought the buildings should be kept. Artist Dag Hol was widely quoted as saying it was a "golden opportunity" to get rid of "brutal, ugly and degrading architecture". But Joern Holme, head of the Directorate for Cultural Heritage, said the buildings were historically important - architecturally, politically and artistically. "We can't demolish the best (parts) of a cultural era just because we find it ugly today," he said. Norway's government has until early next year to decide what to do about the buildings. The rights to the murals are owned by the Picasso family and they must be consulted on what happens to them Claudia Andrieu, a legal expert with the Picasso Administration, said they have not been approached yet but are "open to dialogue".
MGT:
In Oslo, a contentious debate has unfolded over the fate of five Picasso murals that adorn the walls of buildings damaged in the 2011 bombing orchestrated by Anders Breivik. The artworks, created in 1949, are integral to Norway's cultural heritage and have sparked a passionate discussion about restoration and preservation.

On July 22, 2011, Breivik detonated a bomb in the government district of Oslo, causing significant damage and loss of life. Among the affected structures were the Oslo City Hall and the Norwegian Labour Party's youth organization building, both adorned with Picasso's celebrated murals. The destruction left these historic pieces of art in precarious states, raising immediate concerns about their preservation.

The murals, titled "The Fishermen" and "The Pioneers," are celebrated for their vibrant colors and dynamic composition, reflecting Picasso's post-war artistic phase. Their presence in Oslo is a testament to the city's rich cultural history and the enduring legacy of Picasso himself.

In the aftermath of the attack, the Norwegian government and cultural bodies have grappled with the challenge of restoring the murals to their former glory. Restoration efforts have been met with both support and opposition. Advocates argue that restoring the murals is essential to preserving national heritage and honoring the victims of the tragedy. They emphasize that the murals are not only artistic treasures but also symbols of resilience and unity in the face of adversity.

Conversely, some critics question the feasibility and ethics of restoration. They argue that the murals, having been part of a site of such profound tragedy, should be left in their current state as a form of memorial. This faction believes that restoration could inadvertently diminish the historical significance of the site, turning a somber reminder into a spectacle.

The debate has also delved into technical and financial considerations. The restoration of such large-scale murals is a complex and costly endeavor, requiring specialized expertise and significant funding. The Norwegian government has been evaluating various proposals, weighing the cultural importance against practical constraints.

As the discussion continues, the Norwegian public remains deeply engaged, reflecting on what these murals represent for the nation's collective memory. Whatever decision is reached, it will undoubtedly shape Norway's approach to cultural preservation in the years to come, balancing respect for history with the imperatives of restoration. The outcome will not only determine the future of Picasso's murals but also serve as a testament to Norway's commitment to honoring its cultural and historical legacy.

prompt: Two dogs stolen from a garden in West Lothian have died after being hit by a car.
HWT: The two Lurchers were stolen along with seven eight-week-old Shih Tzu puppies, from Glendevon Park, Winchburgh, between 07:30 and 18:00 on Wednesday. The Lurchers were hit by a Honda Civic at about 22:10 on Thursday on the B9020 near Tippet Knowe Road. One of the dogs died on impact and the other was taken to a vet, where it was put down with the owner's permission. PC John Jackson, of Police Scotland, said: "At this time, we believe the Lurchers may have been left to roam and as a consequence their owners have very sadly lost their dogs. "We are still appealing for anyone who may have information about the whereabouts of the seven Shih Tzu puppies to come forward, so we can reunite them with their mum and rightful owners. "The Shih Tzu puppies are worth around Â£650 each and if you are offered a puppy matching this description, which seems disproportionately cheap and the mother is unavailable to view, please get in touch."
MGT:
In a tragic incident in West Lothian, two dogs that had been stolen from a garden were killed after being struck by a vehicle. The dogs, a pair of beloved pets, were taken from their home last week, leaving the family devastated. Despite immediate reports to the authorities and extensive searches in the area, the pets remained missing until this heartbreaking discovery.

The dogs were reportedly seen in the vicinity of a local road when they were hit. The driver of the car involved in the collision, who stopped to assist, discovered the injured pets and contacted emergency services. Unfortunately, despite the prompt response, both dogs succumbed to their injuries at the scene.

The family is mourning the loss of their cherished companions and has expressed deep gratitude for the community's support during this difficult time. Police have urged anyone with information regarding the theft to come forward, as they continue to investigate the circumstances of the incident.

Authorities are also reminding pet owners of the importance of microchipping and ensuring their pets are securely contained to prevent such heart-wrenching events. The community has rallied around the family, offering condolences and support during this sorrowful period.

prompt: Reading manager Jaap Stam believes his three deadline day signings, Lewis Grabban, Reece Oxford and Jordan Mutch, will add "quality and experience".
HWT: The Championship side also strengthened their grip on third place with a 1-0 win at Birmingham City on Tuesday. "We needed to have extra bodies in the squad when you look at the number of games towards the end of the season," Stam told BBC Radio Berkshire. "Maybe we will have injuries and suspensions that will stretch us." Bournemouth striker Grabban, 29, West Ham defender Oxford, 18, and Crystal Palace midfielder Mutch, 25, have all joined on loan until the end of the season. "We're always looking for quality players in the squad and I think every manager wants that," Stam said. "Reece Oxford gives us an extra defender in the squad, he's a young and very talented player and he has the quality that we need in how we play. "He's highly-rated and everyone is happy to have him in the squad. Jordan Mutch has the experience that maybe other players in the squad don't have. "Maybe that will make my life more difficult or perhaps easier in terms of making selection choices."
MGT:
Reading manager Jaap Stam has expressed confidence that his three deadline day signings—Lewis Grabban, Reece Oxford, and Jordan Mutch—will contribute significantly to the team with their quality and experience. Stam emphasized the importance of bolstering the squad with players who can make an immediate impact, both on and off the pitch.

Lewis Grabban, a seasoned striker, is expected to enhance Reading’s attacking options. His experience in the Premier League, having previously played for clubs like Burnley and Bournemouth, brings a wealth of knowledge and a proven goal-scoring record. Stam highlighted Grabban's ability to provide leadership and mentorship to the younger forwards in the squad.

Reece Oxford, a versatile central midfielder, is anticipated to strengthen the midfield with his defensive capabilities and energy. Although relatively young, Oxford has already made a name for himself at West Ham United, and Stam is keen on harnessing his potential to improve Reading’s defensive solidity.

Jordan Mutch, another experienced midfielder, is set to offer depth and versatility. With a history of playing in the Championship for teams like Cardiff City, Mutch’s arrival is seen as a strategic move to bolster the squad’s midfield resilience and creativity.

Stam believes these acquisitions will not only enhance the team's performance but also boost morale as Reading aims to climb the table. The manager is optimistic that the new signings will integrate seamlessly and contribute to a successful campaign.

prompt: Temporary power provider Aggreko has said it is sticking to its full-year profit guidance, despite reporting a drop in sales in the third quarter.
HWT: The Glasgow-based company, which has been restructuring in order to improve efficiency, has forecast a pre-tax profit of between Â£250m and Â£270m. The figures match those given in the summer when it issued a profits warning. It also reported a 7% fall in underlying third-quarter revenue. In a trading statement, Aggreko said sales from its rental solutions division were down 1% on last year. It added that the ongoing weakness in the oil and gas and mining sectors had been largely offset by continued growth in other sectors, such as petrochemical and refining. Aggreko also reported an 11% fall in revenue from its power solutions arm, with the "continuing weak economic backdrop in Brazil" having an impact on its business. In August, Aggreko reorganised the group into two units following a business review. It also announced plans to add more engineering resources to its Dumbarton manufacturing facility as part of a consolidation process. Chief executive Chris Weston said Aggreko continued "to demonstrate its resilience against a challenging market backdrop". He added: "Whilst we are at an early stage in delivering the specific actions identified at our business review in August, I am encouraged with the progress we are making which, regardless of the prevailing market conditions, will strengthen Aggreko and position it well for the future." By lunchtime on Monday, Aggreko's shares were up by more than 7%.
MGT:
Aggreko, the leading temporary power provider, has confidently maintained its full-year profit guidance despite experiencing a dip in sales during the third quarter. The company, known for its role in delivering reliable power solutions across various industries, reported a drop in revenue, which many anticipated might impact its financial outlook. However, Aggreko's management remains optimistic about achieving its projected targets for the year.

In the third quarter, Aggreko saw a decline in sales, attributed to a combination of factors including lower project starts in certain regions and a slowdown in some key sectors that traditionally drive demand for their services. Despite these challenges, the company has emphasized its strong operational performance and strategic initiatives aimed at bolstering future growth.

Aggreko's commitment to its profit guidance is supported by a robust order book, which continues to show positive momentum. The company has secured significant contracts in various sectors, including energy, infrastructure, and events, underscoring its ability to diversify and adapt to changing market conditions. This diversified portfolio not only cushions against regional sales fluctuations but also positions Aggreko to capitalize on emerging opportunities.

Moreover, Aggreko's focus on innovation and sustainability is expected to drive long-term growth. The company is investing in renewable energy solutions and expanding its capabilities to meet the increasing demand for cleaner and more efficient power solutions. These strategic moves align with global trends towards sustainability and are likely to enhance Aggreko's competitive edge.

In conclusion, despite the third-quarter sales drop, Aggreko's strong order book, diversified business model, and strategic investments in innovation and sustainability provide a solid foundation for achieving its full-year profit targets. The company remains focused on delivering value to its stakeholders and continuing its trajectory of growth in the dynamic power solutions market.

prompt: Staffing in parts of Stafford Hospital is so threadbare that services could become unsafe if a single worker is lost, the chief inspector of hospitals has warned.
HWT: Prof Mike Richards has contacted health watchdog Monitor over his concerns. A Care Quality Commission (CQC) inspection between 30 June and 2 July found services were "only just" safe. The Mid Staffordshire Foundation Trust has already said about 60 beds will be cut - partly due to staffing. Prof Richards's letter, which was also sent to the Trust Development Authority and the Trust Special Administrator, said senior managers were having to spend "inordinate amounts of time" ensuring individual nursing shifts were adequately filled. "To date, they have been able to do this. But I would emphasise the word just," he said. The trust, which has been in administration since April 2013, is due to be dissolved in November with some services being moved to neighbouring hospitals. Prof Richards said uncertainty over the hospital's future was "contributing to the fatigue and fragility amongst staff". The full findings of the CQC inspection are due to be published next month,
MGT:
The chief inspector of hospitals has issued a stark warning about the critical staffing situation at parts of Stafford Hospital, where services are on the brink of becoming unsafe. The current staffing levels are described as "threadbare," with the hospital operating at a point where the loss of a single worker could compromise patient safety and the delivery of essential services.

This alarming situation has raised concerns about the hospital's ability to maintain adequate care and respond effectively to emergencies. The warning underscores the urgency of addressing the staffing crisis, as the hospital struggles to fill vacancies and retain existing staff.

The chief inspector's report highlights the pressing need for immediate intervention to bolster the workforce and prevent a potential safety crisis. Hospital administrators are being urged to take swift action to recruit and retain staff, ensuring that the hospital can continue to provide safe and effective care to its patients.

This situation at Stafford Hospital serves as a critical reminder of the broader challenges facing the healthcare system, where staffing shortages continue to pose significant risks to patient safety and service delivery. Efforts must be intensified to address these issues and support healthcare workers in delivering the care that patients deserve.

prompt: Captain Wayne Rooney will not face disciplinary action following his late-night conduct while on England duty.
HWT: The Manchester United striker apologised over "inappropriate" pictures of him a day after England's World Cup qualifying win over Scotland. The Daily Mirror has reported the FA found Rooney was invited to a wedding reception and that there was no curfew. Rooney, 31, has been assured from "high levels within the Football Association" that he will not be charged. An investigation followed the publication of images in The Sun which it said showed Rooney drunk at a party late on Saturday, 12 November. The FA is also looking into claims several England players were out until late on the same Saturday night after the 3-0 win over Scotland - less than three days before they drew 2-2 with Spain in a friendly. England's players all reported back at 11:00 GMT on the Sunday as they were instructed to, and attended training in the afternoon. England players have since been banned by the FA from having nights out while on international duty.
MGT:
Captain Wayne Rooney is set to avoid any disciplinary measures after an incident involving his late-night conduct during England's recent international duty. The Football Association (FA) concluded that there was insufficient evidence to warrant any formal action against the Manchester United forward.

prompt: Nine military officers have been sacked over last month's attack by militants on the military hospital in Kabul, the Afghan defence ministry says.
HWT: Those dismissed include a general and a colonel. All face prosecution for negligence, the ministry said. The attack was one of the worst in the conflict-hit nation in recent months. About 50 people are said to have died as militants armed with guns, grenades and knives targeted patients and staff at the hospital. The brutal assault caused shock and anger among the public. Many people are still demanding to know why a building that was meant to be secure was so vulnerable to attack. The hospital is heavily guarded and the government says the attackers got inside after exploding a car bomb at the gate. But other reports suggest some attackers were already inside the hospital when the violence began, meaning militants had infiltrated the high-security site. There is also a lack of clarity over how many people died. Some hospital workers quoted in local media said the toll was much higher than the figure of about 50 reported by the government. The so-called Islamic State group said it carried out the attack, but some eyewitnesses later told media the assailants shouted slogans in support of the Taliban. The deputy interior minister was sacked in the immediate aftermath of the attack.
MGT:
The Afghan Defence Ministry announced the dismissal of nine military officers following a recent militant attack on a military hospital in Kabul. This decision comes in the wake of last month's incident, which left scores injured and exposed vulnerabilities in the security protocols at the facility.

The assault, executed by a group of militants, highlighted significant lapses in intelligence and preparedness at the hospital. The Defence Ministry has stated that those dismissed were held accountable for their failure to prevent the attack despite having prior intelligence warnings.

The attack caused widespread panic and chaos, with numerous casualties reported among both military personnel and civilians seeking medical attention. The incident has raised serious concerns over the safety and security measures in place at critical infrastructure across the nation.

In response to the attack, the Afghan government has pledged to review and strengthen security arrangements at all military and civilian facilities. The Defence Ministry emphasized that ensuring the safety of military personnel and civilians is their utmost priority, and measures are underway to prevent such tragedies in the future.

This high-profile incident has drawn attention to the ongoing security challenges in Afghanistan, as the country continues to grapple with militant threats despite efforts to stabilize the region. The government remains committed to taking decisive actions to safeguard its citizens and infrastructure against such violent acts.

prompt: A team of Londonderry footballers with Down's syndrome has played its first match after featuring in a video with a Republic of Ireland player.
HWT: The Oxford Bulls took on Sion Sonics on Monday night - another local team featuring players with Down's syndrome. The friendly game - Oxford Bulls' first - was organised after the team featured in a video with winger James McClean that went viral. Manager Kevin Morrison said it was "a night to remember". "We started off with about six or seven players and things just blossomed from there," Mr Morrison told BBC Radio Foyle. "Things have been crazy the past couple of months since the video with James McClean went viral. "Footballer Paddy McCourt has also been to meet the boys. The good will and support has been phenomenal. "We've been training for two years and getting a match was a big thing for the boys." Sion Sonics have also been training for a year and hoping for a match, just like the Bulls. "There are different needs within the groups," said Mr Morrison. "Crowds, cheering and a different venue could have been an issue for the boys, so we took them to a parish hall for the match. "They really enjoyed it every minute and we didn't keep a score. "As JosÃ© Mourinho would say, it's not about the result. It was about our boys getting out into the community and they were amazing." The teams are now resting and players meet later in the week to discuss tactics and their next match. The Oxford Bulls club was established with the help of the Foyle Down's Syndrome Trust, which provides a wide range of activities for young people and adults with the condition. A mother, whose 10-year-old son plays for the team, said the club had given her 10-year-old son confidence and helped him make friends.
MGT:
In a heartwarming display of inclusivity and sportsmanship, a team of Londonderry footballers with Down's syndrome recently made their debut on the pitch. This milestone event followed their appearance in a video alongside Republic of Ireland football star, Caoimhin Kelleher. The initiative has been widely celebrated as a powerful statement for diversity and inclusion in sports.

The video, which had gone viral, featured the young athletes alongside Kelleher, who is the Liverpool goalkeeper. It showcased the team practicing and enjoying football, highlighting the joy and camaraderie that the sport brings to participants of all abilities. The footage was part of a larger campaign aimed at promoting inclusivity in sports and was funded by Sport Northern Ireland.

On the day of their first match, the atmosphere was electric, with supporters gathering to cheer on the new team. The match took place at a local community field, where the team played a friendly game against a local club. The support from the community was overwhelming, with parents, friends, and local residents coming together to celebrate this historic occasion.

The team, made up of young men and women aged between 10 and 18, demonstrated incredible teamwork and determination. Despite being their first official game, the players showed impressive skill and enthusiasm. The match was not just about competition; it was a celebration of inclusion and the breaking down of barriers that often limit participation in sports for individuals with Down's syndrome.

Sport Northern Ireland, along with local organizations, have been instrumental in making this dream a reality. They provided training, equipment, and support to ensure the team was well-prepared for their debut. The initiative is part of a broader effort to encourage more inclusive sporting opportunities across Northern Ireland.

Caoimhin Kelleher, who attended the match, expressed his delight at seeing the team in action. "It's incredible to see these players on the field, showcasing their talent and passion for football," he said. "This is a testament to what can be achieved when we come together to support and include everyone in sports."

The match concluded with a special ceremony, where the players received medals and certificates of participation. The event has sparked conversations about the importance of inclusivity in sports and has set a precedent for other teams and organizations to follow. As the players celebrated their victory, it was clear that this was just the beginning of an inspiring journey towards greater inclusivity in the world of sports.

prompt: A football coach who abducted and sexually assaulted a teenager has been jailed for 18 months.
HWT: Felix Reilly, 30, from Otterton in Devon, was caught on CCTV following a woman, 19, in his car before grabbing her off the street in Exmouth. The woman managed to free herself from the vehicle on her third attempt but was groped during the abduction. Police praised the courage of the victim in speaking about the ordeal, which lasted for several minutes. More on the football coach jailed for sex attack, and other news Reilly, of Maunders Place, trained to be a football coach as part of a community programme run by Exeter City Football Club. The court heard character references from the club's Head of Community Jamie Vittles as well as Exmouth Town manager Richard Pears. Reilly had been driving his car around Exmouth town centre for 10 minutes which Judge Graham Cottle of Exeter Crown Court said made clear he'd "obviously been following her". The judge said: "Eventually you tried to grab her. You grabbed her between the legs, pulling her into your car. I am not sure exactly how long she remained kidnapped but it was a few minutes before she was able to affect her release." Reilly had spent the afternoon looking at sex and prostitution websites before he went out in his car in the early hours of the morning. Prosecutor Peter Coombe said the evidence of Mr Reilly's internet use in the hours before the incident suggested he may have been planning an attack or abduction. Reilly was also placed on the sex offenders register for 10 years.
MGT:
In a sobering verdict, a football coach has been sentenced to 18 months in prison after abducting and sexually assaulting a teenager. The case drew significant public attention due to the breach of trust involved and the young age of the victim.

The 45-year-old coach, who had been a well-respected figure in the local community, was found guilty of both abduction and sexual assault following a court trial. The victim, a 16-year-old aspiring athlete, was lured away from a team training session under the pretext of discussing sports opportunities.

The court heard how the coach initially befriended the teenager, exploiting his position of authority to gain the young athlete's trust. This trust was then tragically violated when he abducted the teenager from a public area and subjected him to sexual assault.

During the trial, the defense argued for leniency, citing the coach's previously unblemished record and contributions to youth sports. However, the prosecution emphasized the severity of the crime and its impact on the victim, highlighting the breach of trust and the psychological trauma inflicted.

The victim bravely testified, recounting the traumatic experience and its lasting effects on his mental health. His courage was praised by both legal representatives and community members who have rallied to support him throughout the proceedings.

In handing down the sentence, the judge condemned the coach's actions, stating they represented a grave breach of the responsibilities placed upon those who work with young people. The judge also acknowledged the need for justice to be served, not only for the victim but to serve as a deterrent to others in positions of authority.

The community, while relieved at the verdict, remains shaken by the events. Local sports clubs have vowed to implement stricter safeguarding measures to prevent such incidents from occurring in the future. The victim's family expressed gratitude for the public support and hope that this case will raise awareness about the importance of child protection in sports.

prompt: Exeter Chiefs fly-half Gareth Steenson should be in the Ireland squad, according to team-mate Ian Whitten.
HWT: Steenson, 31, was capped at youth level by Ireland, but has spent most of his career in England and has been a key member of the Exeter team. "There aren't that many good 10's in Ireland," said Whitten, who has two caps for Ireland. "I have to say that Gareth Steenson's been very, very unlucky not to have been capped by Ireland." Steenson moved to Exeter from Cornish Pirates in 2008 and kicked the winning penalty that saw the Chiefs beat Bristol in the inaugural Championship play-off final in 2010, leading to their promotion to the top flight for the first time. Since then he has become Exeter's record Premiership points-scorer, with 953, and equalled the top flight record of nine penalties in a match in 2014. "I was lucky enough to get capped before I came over here," added Whitten, who agreed a new contract at Sandy Park last week. "But similar to the English, although they don't openly say it, they don't like to pick guys playing outside of Ireland. "That's fair enough, I accept that stance, and I enjoy playing here. I don't consider going back home as I didn't want to leave (the club)."

prompt: Holidaymakers from Northern Ireland have said they are "relieved" to be home following a failed military coup in Turkey on Friday.
HWT: More than 160 civilians lost their lives during the clashes. Some passengers returning to Belfast International Airport in the early hours of Sunday spoke to BBC News NI. Louise McMillan heard helicopters and jets overhead during her holiday, but she had to rely on reports from home to find out what was happening. "It scared the life out of us, but you've just got to get on and hope for the best", she said. Another passenger said her daughter was "in a state" at home worrying about her. The Foreign Office has relaxed its advice for British people travelling to Turkey. It says public places in Ankara and Istanbul, particularly demonstrations, should be avoided. British Airways will be providing a reduced service to Turkey today after cancelling all flights yesterday. A flight to Dalaman in the south-west of the country left Belfast International Airport on Saturday afternoon. Tour operator Thompson said most travellers had decided to continue with their holiday plans.

USA began the best-of-13 series with a one-point advantage after winning the earlier qualifying regatta, which was erased by New Zealand's race one win. Races three and four are on Sunday. Four years ago, New Zealand were eventually overhauled by an Oracle team that featured Britain's Ben Ainslie as tactician in what is regarded as one of sport's great comebacks. Ainslie's British team were knocked out at the semi-final stage this year, losing 5-2 to the Kiwis. The America's Cup, the oldest competition in international sport, was first raced in 1851 around the Isle of Wight and has only been won by four nations.

prompt: Sussex have signed Ireland spinner George Dockrell on a month-long loan from fellow Division One side Somerset.
HWT: Dockrell, 22, has been limited to seconds cricket at Taunton for much of this season in addition to his international commitments. "It's going to be an interesting few weeks in a new environment but it will be good to get some first-class cricket under my belt," Dockrell said. "I've played a lot of second XI cricket in the last few years but to develop my game I need to be playing first XI cricket and this will give me the opportunity." Somerset director of cricket Matt Maynard added: "George is a quality performer and has played a lot of international cricket but following the signing of Abdur Rehman he has had limited opportunities this year. "This will be good for him and good for Somerset too." Meanwhile, batsman Tom Abell has signed a four-year contract with Somerset, having progressed through the junior ranks to make his debut last season.

prompt: Shares in outsourcing group Capita have fallen more than 14% after the company issued another profit warning and said it would sell assets.
HWT: Capita said it expected profits of at least £515m this year, down from its prediction in September of £535m-£555m which itself was a downgrade. The company also said it would sell the majority of its Capita Asset Services division, as well as other assets. Despite Capita's fall, the FTSE 100 index closed up 30 points at 6,932. In the FTSE 250, shares in bookmakers were hit after MPs recommended that the maximum amount gamblers can stake on fixed-odds betting machines should be cut from £100 to £2. Shares in William Hill dropped 7% and Ladbrokes Coral shares fell 4.5%. Sports Direct shares were down 7.75% after the retailer reported a sharp fall in half-year profits. Reported pre-tax profits fell 25% to £140.2m, with the company partly blaming the weak pound for the decline. On the currency markets, the pound fell 0.49% against the dollar to $1.2564, and was 1.25% lower against the euro at €1.0618.

prompt: The death toll from a huge explosion in the centre of the Afghan capital Kabul on Tuesday has more than doubled to 64 people, the government says.
HWT: Interior Ministry spokesman Sediq Sediqqi tweeted that 64 "innocent Afghans" were killed and 347 wounded. A suicide attacker detonated a vehicle and a fierce gun battle followed in one of the deadliest attacks in Kabul for years. A Taliban spokesman said the group carried out the attack. It came a week after it said it was launching its "spring offensive", warning of large-scale attacks, although the group fights all year round. Why are the Taliban resurgent in Afghanistan? Tuesday's bombing happened during the morning rush hour in Pul-e-Mahmud, a busy neighbourhood where homes, mosques, schools and businesses nestle close to the ministry of defence, other ministries and military compounds. The blast shattered windows up to 1.6km (one mile) away. A police officer told the Associated Press it was one of the most powerful explosions he had ever heard, and he could not see or hear anything for 20 minutes after. It appears the initial blast cleared the way for Taliban fighters to enter the area - a commonly used tactic. It had previously been reported that at least 28 people had been killed and 329 injured. Mr Sediqqi told reporters that most of the 64 now reported dead were civilians. He said most of the wounded were in a stable condition. At least 71 Shia worshippers were killed in 2011 in a rare attack on a Shia shrine in Kabul. Afghan security forces regularly foil similar attacks, correspondents say, but with explosives easily available and bomb-making skills common, it is difficult to prevent all of them.
MGT:
A devastating explosion in the heart of Kabul on Tuesday has resulted in a tragic increase in casualties, with the death toll rising to 64, according to government officials. The powerful blast, which reverberated through the city's bustling streets, also left over 347 individuals wounded, causing chaos and panic in the area.

The explosion occurred near a highly populated area, exacerbating the scale of destruction and loss. Emergency services were swiftly mobilized, working tirelessly amidst the chaos to rescue victims trapped under debris and provide urgent medical care to the injured. Hospitals across the city were overwhelmed as they received a surge of patients, with many doctors and medical staff working around the clock to tend to the wounded.

The Afghan government has initiated a thorough investigation to determine the cause of the explosion and to identify those responsible. Preliminary reports suggest the possibility of a suicide attack, although authorities have yet to confirm any specific findings. The incident has heightened security concerns in the capital, prompting increased military and police presence in key areas to ensure public safety and prevent further attacks.

The explosion has struck a deeply scarred nation already grappling with the challenges of ongoing conflict and instability. The international community has expressed its condolences and offered support to the Afghan people during this difficult time. Humanitarian organizations are also stepping up efforts to assist those affected, providing essential aid and resources to help the victims and their families.

Residents of Kabul are mourning the loss of loved ones and neighbors, as the city comes to terms with another devastating blow to its community. The government has called for unity and resilience among its citizens, emphasizing the importance of solidarity in overcoming such tragedies. As the investigation continues, there is a collective hope for justice and a renewed commitment to peace and security in Afghanistan.

prompt: York climbed off the foot of the National League with an impressive win to leave Eastleigh still chasing their first win of the year.
HWT: In a hectic opening quarter-of-an-hour, City took charge with two goals from Jon Parkin. Sean Newton's long seventh-minute throw-in was headed on by Vadaine Oliver for Parkin to volley home at the far post, and the striker then finished off a similar move with another close-range finish six minutes later. York keeper Kyle Letheren had a moment to forget when he failed to deal with Ross Stearn's simple in-swinging free-kick and allowed the ball to bounce between his legs into the back of the net. After the break, Spitfires defender Gavin Hoyte somehow cleared Amari Morgan-Smith's close-range shot off the line. Substitute Tyler Garratt then hit the post at the other end with a bouncing 25-yard drive. Oliver nearly restored York's two-goal lead when his header from an Asa Hall corner was pushed against the bar by keeper Ryan Clarke. But the striker was not to be denied as he wrapped up the points with 10 minutes left, holding off Ayo Obileye's challenge before steering a shot into the bottom corner. Match report supplied by the Press Association. Match ends, York City 3, Eastleigh 1. Second Half ends, York City 3, Eastleigh 1. Ayo Obileye (Eastleigh) is shown the yellow card. Substitution, York City. Danny Holmes replaces Adriano Moke. Reda Johnson (Eastleigh) is shown the yellow card. Substitution, Eastleigh. Sam Matthews replaces Ben Close. Goal!  York City 3, Eastleigh 1. Vadaine Oliver (York City). Substitution, Eastleigh. Scott Wilson replaces Craig McAllister. Simon Heslop (York City) is shown the yellow card. Substitution, Eastleigh. Tyler Garrett replaces Ross Stearn. Second Half begins York City 2, Eastleigh 1. First Half ends, York City 2, Eastleigh 1. Goal!  York City 2, Eastleigh 1. Ross Stearn (Eastleigh). Goal!  York City 2, Eastleigh 0. Jon Parkin (York City). Goal!  York City 1, Eastleigh 0. Jon Parkin (York City). First Half begins. Lineups are announced and players are warming up.
MGT:
York City celebrated a much-needed triumph as they climbed off the foot of the National League standings with an impressive victory over Eastleigh. The win not only bolstered their confidence but also extended Eastleigh's frustrating wait for their first win of the season.

The match, held at Bootham Crescent, was a tense affair from the outset, with both sides eager to secure a vital three points. York, who have been struggling at the bottom of the table, showed great determination and resilience, playing with the kind of spirit that has been missing from their performances in recent weeks.

The decisive moment came in the 28th minute when York's quick counter-attack was finished off by a precise finish from their forward. The goal was a reward for York's persistence and tactical discipline, which saw them apply consistent pressure on the Eastleigh defense. The home crowd erupted in celebration, sensing that this could be the turning point in their season.

Eastleigh, on the other hand, looked desperate to break their duck and maintain their unbeaten record at home. Despite their efforts and several attempts to level the score, they were unable to break through York's resolute defense. York's goalkeeper made a series of crucial saves, ensuring that the lead was maintained until the final whistle.

In the second half, York continued to dominate possession and created several more scoring opportunities. Their midfield, in particular, was instrumental in controlling the tempo of the game, while their defense remained solid, repelling Eastleigh's advances. The visitors' frustration grew as time ticked away, with their fans growing increasingly restless as their team struggled to find an equalizer.

As the match approached its conclusion, York managed to double their lead. A well-worked team effort saw the ball find its way to a substitute who calmly slotted home from a tight angle, sealing the victory. The final whistle was met with jubilation from the York supporters, who had witnessed their team deliver a performance befitting a side looking to climb away from the relegation zone.

For Eastleigh, the defeat was a bitter pill to swallow, leaving them still in search of their first win of the year. Their manager will undoubtedly be looking to address the defensive lapses and find a way to ignite their attacking prowess in upcoming fixtures.

This victory is a significant morale booster for York City as they look to build on their performance and gain further points in their quest for survival. The match demonstrated their potential when playing with unity and purpose, and with continued displays like this, they could very well turn their fortunes around this season.

prompt: India's national carrier Air India is set to ground 125 "overweight" cabin crew members.
HWT: An Air India official told the BBC that the order had been made on the basis of a document issued by the civil aviation authority last year. The airline had warned 600 of its crew to "shape up" last year, but 125 had not managed to maintain the required weight, the official said. The airline says however that the issue is not one of weight, but "fitness". Airline officials confirmed to the BBC that the directive had been issued, but said it was part of an internal document which they could not comment on publicly. They said the basis for the recommendation was concern that "unfit" cabin crew would not be able to operate efficiently in emergency situations. Aviation regulations state that a Body Mass Index (BMI) of 18-25 is normal for a male cabin crew member, while for a female it is 18-22. Aviation expert Kapil Kaul told the BBC: "An overweight crew is a signal the airline is not fit. You need a smart friendly agile crew that can complement the image of the airline." However, national union leader Tapan Sen denied that service rules mention any firm weight restriction for cabin crew. This is not the first time Air India has grounded staff over weight issues. In 2009, it dismissed nine hostesses for being "overweight" on safety grounds saying their shape could "impair agility". In 2004, the airline landed itself in further controversy when it said that potential air hostesses and stewards should not have any scars, acne, or any major marks on the face.
MGT:
India's national carrier, Air India, has announced plans to ground approximately 125 cabin crew members who have been classified as "overweight." This decision comes as part of the airline's revamped health and fitness policy aimed at ensuring the safety and well-being of both passengers and crew members.

The move follows an internal audit conducted by the airline, which assessed the health parameters of its crew. The audit revealed that these 125 members did not meet the new fitness standards established by Air India. The airline emphasized that this decision was taken with a focus on passenger safety, as overweight staff could potentially face difficulties during emergency evacuations, thereby posing risks during critical situations.

Air India's management stated that the policy is not discriminatory but rather a necessary measure to align with international aviation safety standards. They highlighted that maintaining a healthy weight is crucial for the demanding physical requirements of cabin crew duties, which include assisting passengers during emergencies, ensuring compliance with health and safety protocols, and providing effective customer service.

The affected crew members were given a notice period during which they were expected to meet the new fitness criteria. The airline has also introduced wellness programs, including diet plans and fitness training, to assist their staff in meeting these standards. Additionally, Air India is offering counseling and support to those impacted, emphasizing that the policy is designed to be supportive rather than punitive.

This initiative is part of a broader strategy by Air India to enhance its operational efficiency and service quality. By prioritizing health and fitness, the airline aims to foster a more secure and comfortable flying environment for its passengers. The decision has sparked discussions within the aviation community about the balance between stringent health policies and the rights of employees, but Air India maintains that the move is essential for maintaining the highest standards of safety and service.

prompt: A meteor that may have caused phone calls to the Coastguard in Scotland and England was photographed from the shores of Loch Ness.
HWT: Tourist guide John Alasdair Macdonald captured his image on a compact camera near Dochfour at about 21:00 on Sunday. The Maritime and Coastguard Agency got calls from people in the Highlands, Dumfries and Galloway and Cumbria concerned it was a distress flare. Mr Macdonald described his images as a "fluke". Mr Macdonald said: "I was taking some new pictures to put on my Facebook page using a Sony RX100 compact camera. "It was a beautiful, clear night and I got some nice pictures but capturing the meteor was a fluke. I will never take a picture like that again." Mr Macdonald, who runs the business The Hebridean Explorer, said he had seen messages on social media of a meteor being seen elsewhere, including Sleat on Skye. Meteor sightings were also said to have been made from North Uist, Oban and Mull. A "meteorite" mistaken for a distress flare also sparked a lifeboat search operation off the English coast on Sunday. Maryport Coastguard Rescue Team said it received numerous reports of a moving red object over the sea between Workington, Cumbria, and the Isle of Whithorn in Dumfries and Galloway. Did you see the meteor?
MGT:
A spectacular meteor streaked across the Scottish and English skies, capturing the attention of onlookers and causing a flurry of phone calls to the Coastguard. The dazzling display was vividly photographed from the shores of Loch Ness, adding a touch of mystique to the renowned location.

The event took place late Monday evening, when witnesses observed the bright fireball illuminating the night sky. Many initially believed the meteor to be a distress signal, leading to an influx of calls to emergency services. The Coastguard in both Scotland and England reported an unusual spike in activity, with several callers expressing concern over the unusual light.

Astronomers have since confirmed that the meteor was likely part of a larger meteor shower, possibly related to the debris trails of Comet Swift-Tuttle, known for the Perseid meteor showers. The meteor was visible over a wide area, with reports coming from as far south as the English coast.

Local photographer, Emily McAllister, captured the moment from her vantage point at Loch Ness. "It was an incredible sight," she said. "The sky lit up with a brilliant flash, and I knew I had to capture it. It felt almost magical, especially here by the loch."

Authorities have reassured the public that there was no cause for alarm, and the meteor posed no danger. Meanwhile, the event has sparked renewed interest in astronomy within the region, with local observatories planning viewing events to take advantage of the heightened interest in celestial phenomena.
