prompt: About 350 homes are to be built in the Govanhill area of Glasgow under a £6.4m council initiative to help "turn the area around".
HWT: The homes are planned to be for social or mid-market rent and it is hoped they will all be completed by 2021. Glasgow City Council's executive committee also approved £20m to improve existing housing. Of this, £14m was announced last month as part of scheme to upgrade homes and make them available for social renting. The £34m four-year improvement and repair scheme is also being funded with £20m from the Scottish government. The funding to build homes is to be channelled through housing associations over the next four years. Eight sites in the area have been identified for development. As part of the strategy, Govanhill Housing Association has also committed £3.7m to new housing and repairs for the duration of the four year period. Overall this means there are plans to invest more than £44m in housing in Govanhill over the next four years. Councillor George Redmond: "This is an impressive document and points to the way ahead in Govanhill." "Significant sums are being invested in Govanhill and it is great news that part of that money will go towards new housing. "The council has been working exceptionally hard to turn things around in Govanhill and we are starting to see real progress being made." He said that while the council was keen to work with all property owners in Govanhill, he warned the council would use power of compulsory purchase against those who refused to get on board with the plans.
MGT:
Glasgow City Council has announced an ambitious initiative to rejuvenate the Govanhill area, with plans to construct approximately 350 new homes as part of a £6.4 million project. This development aims to transform the neighborhood and address longstanding challenges by providing modern, affordable housing options for residents.

The project is part of a broader strategy to revitalize Govanhill, an area that has faced various social and economic challenges over the years. The council's investment underscores a commitment to enhancing the quality of life for its residents and fostering a sense of community within the district.

Councillor Susan Aitken, leader of Glasgow City Council, emphasized the importance of this investment in her statement: "This initiative represents a significant step forward in our efforts to improve living conditions and opportunities for the people of Govanhill. By investing in new, quality housing, we are not only addressing immediate needs but also laying the groundwork for long-term positive change."

The new homes will incorporate sustainable building practices and be designed to meet the diverse needs of the community, ensuring accessibility and inclusivity. Additionally, the development is expected to create jobs during the construction phase and contribute to the local economy.

Local residents and community leaders have expressed cautious optimism about the project. While there is recognition of the potential benefits, there is also a call for ensuring that the development is sensitive to the area's cultural diversity and heritage.

The council aims to start construction within the next six months, with an expectation that the homes will be occupied by the end of 2025. This initiative is a key component of Glasgow's wider regeneration plans, which include improvements to local infrastructure and public services.

By investing in Govanhill, Glasgow City Council hopes to create a vibrant, thriving community where residents can enjoy a better quality of life, signaling a new era of growth and prosperity for the area.

prompt: A cocktail of amino acids - the building blocks of proteins - is the latest contender in the age-old search for the elixir of life.
HWT: Scientists gave mice drinking water laced with three amino acids. They said the rodents lived significantly longer than other mice fed a normal diet. The research, reported in a scientific journal, has yet to be tried in people. The study leader said a large patient trial was needed to provide evidence to convince doctors. In experiments, middle-aged healthy male mice were given drinking water containing the amino acids leucine, isoleucine and valine. Dr Enzo Nisoli, of the University of Milan, and colleagues, said it increased the average lifespan of the mice by 12% and boosted their fitness and co-ordination. They wrote in their paper, published in Cell Metabolism: "Our study offers a rationale for deeply exploring the role of amino acids in prevention and control of age-related disorders in humans." The amino acids - three of the 20 that make up proteins - have been shown to extend life span in yeast. However, the precise role of these amino acids in humans is unknown. They are used by bodybuilders to maintain muscle tissue and can be bought in health food stores and online.
MGT:
In the pursuit of the elusive elixir of life, scientists are turning their attention to a promising new contender: a cocktail of amino acids. These organic compounds, which serve as the fundamental building blocks of proteins, are sparking intrigue in the scientific community for their potential to enhance human health and longevity.

Recent studies have demonstrated that specific combinations of amino acids can trigger a myriad of beneficial effects within the body. Researchers have identified that these concoctions may bolster the body's repair mechanisms, improve metabolic functions, and even protect against age-related diseases. The findings suggest that amino acids could play a crucial role in slowing the aging process, potentially leading to increased lifespan and improved quality of life.

The scientific community is particularly interested in the way these amino acid cocktails interact with cellular processes. By enhancing protein synthesis and modulating gene expression, these compounds may help rejuvenate cells, making them more resilient to the stressors of aging.

While the initial results are promising, researchers caution that more studies are necessary to fully understand the implications and potential side effects of long-term amino acid supplementation. Nonetheless, the prospect of a life-extending elixir made from these simple organic molecules is generating excitement and optimism among scientists and the public alike, as they continue to explore the frontiers of human health and longevity.

prompt: Barry Hawkins had a nightmare turnaround from his gripping victory over Ronnie O'Sullivan to trail Hong Kong's Marco Fu 7-1 in their World Championship quarter-final.
HWT: Hawkins won a draining final-frame thriller 13-12 over the pre-tournament favourite late on Monday night. But the Englishman was way below his best from the start against the world number 14 on Tuesday. He scored only 31 points as he lost the first five frames. Hawkins got on the board in frame six, but Fu easily won the last two frames to earn a six-frame advantage after the first session. The quarter-final tie is the best of 25 frames and the second session gets under way on Wednesday at 14:30 BST. Fu played with fluency and impressive cue ball control to take full advantage of some sloppy play by 2013 runner-up Hawkins - the only man to have made the semi-finals, when the Crucible switches to one table - in each of the last three years. But his chances of repeating that feat appear slim after being completely outplayed by London-based Fu, who recorded three half-centuries on his way to a 5-0 lead. World number 11 Hawkins took a scrappy sixth frame, but two half-centuries gave Fu frame seven and he rounded off the session with his sixth score of more than 50. The other afternoon match saw four-time champion John Higgins win four frames in a row to take a 5-3 lead in his all-Scottish meeting with Alan McManus. McManus, twice a World Championship quarter-finalist in the early 1990s, lost the opener but was then in imperious form as he secured a 3-1 mid-session interval lead with breaks of 114, 78 and 56. But the 45-year-old was out of sorts after the interval, appearing to be troubled by a neck problem. And Higgins, who has gone on to lift the title on the last three occasions he has reached the last eight at the Crucible, made the most of some decent chances to take control. Sign up to My Sport to follow snooker news and reports on the BBC app.
MGT:
Barry Hawkins experienced a dramatic shift in fortunes at the World Snooker Championship, as he found himself trailing 7-1 against Marco Fu in their quarter-final encounter. This was a stark contrast to his thrilling win earlier in the tournament against Ronnie O'Sullivan, which had captured the attention of snooker fans worldwide.

Hawkins' victory over O'Sullivan was a remarkable achievement, showcasing his resilience and tactical prowess. The match was a testament to Hawkins' ability to handle pressure, as he emerged victorious in a gripping encounter that kept spectators on the edge of their seats. However, the momentum seemed to wane as he faced Marco Fu, the Hong Kong player known for his strategic play and consistent performance.

Entering the quarter-final, expectations were high for Hawkins to carry forward the momentum from his previous match. However, Fu quickly took control, demonstrating his seasoned skills and composure under pressure. The first session saw Fu dominate, building an early lead that set the tone for the match. His precise shots and strategic breaks allowed him to capitalize on Hawkins' missed opportunities.

By the end of the session, Fu had established a commanding 5-1 lead, leaving Hawkins in a precarious position. The Briton struggled to find his rhythm, and Fu's relentless pressure continued to mount. As the second session unfolded, Hawkins attempted to mount a comeback, but Fu's consistent play proved too much for him to overcome. 

With each frame, Fu's confidence grew, while Hawkins found it increasingly difficult to break through the defensive walls that Fu had constructed. The scoreline widened to 7-1, reflecting Fu's dominance throughout the match. Despite Hawkins' best efforts to stay competitive, Fu's superiority in technique and mental fortitude sealed his victory.

The quarter-final result was a testament to Marco Fu's exceptional form and ability to perform at the highest level. For Hawkins, it was a reminder of the unpredictable nature of snooker, where fortunes can change rapidly. As he reflected on his journey in the tournament, Hawkins undoubtedly drew lessons from both his stunning victory over O'Sullivan and the challenges posed by Fu. The World Championship continued to deliver compelling narratives, with Fu moving closer to the final and the promise of more thrilling matches ahead.

prompt: An Indian man has been killed after Nepali police fired on hundreds of protesters blocking a border crossing with India.
HWT: Police were trying to clear the blockade, which has cut supply lines of fuel and other goods, when protesters attacked a police post at Birgunj. Reports say the man was shot in the head and later died in hospital. The demonstrators, mainly from southern lowland minority groups, are angry about Nepal's new constitution. Communities from the lowlands believe that Nepal's proposed new provinces will lead to their political marginalisation. These concerns have led to violent clashes around Nepal since August, leaving dozens dead. The protester killed on Monday was identified as Ashish Kumar Ram, from Raxaul in the Indian state of Bihar, local officials said. Local police chief Rajubabu Shrestha told the BBC the protesters had entered Nepali territory from India, throwing stones. He said seven protesters and nine police had been injured. Nepal's Home Ministry Spokesman Laxmi Dhakal said two Indian nationals were arrested after they tried to obstruct police who were removing tents at the border. India said it was "deeply concerned" by events. "Issues facing Nepal are political in nature and cannot be resolved by force. "Causes underlying the present state of confrontation need to addressed by the government of Nepal credibly and effectively," the Indian foreign ministry said in a statement. Earlier, there were conflicting reports about the police crackdown. One report said police baton-charged demonstrators forcing them to remove the blockade, while another said authorities removed the tents of sleeping protesters and lined up trucks to pass through the crossing. Police official Hobindra Bogati told the Associated Press news agency that more than 200 trucks and other vehicles had crossed from Birgunj in Nepal to Raxaul and more were lining up. But, on the Indian side, thousands of trucks have not been able to cross over to Nepal for almost two months.  Reports said the trucks bringing fuel and other goods to Nepal were still blocked by Indian custom officials.
MGT:
In a tragic escalation of tensions, an Indian national has lost his life after Nepali police resorted to firing on a large group of protesters who were obstructing a key border crossing with India. The incident has sparked significant outrage and highlights deep-seated issues between the neighboring countries.

The confrontation occurred at a strategically important border crossing, where hundreds of demonstrators gathered to express their dissent over a recently disputed map released by Nepal. The protesters, who were primarily Indian nationals residing in Nepal, were reportedly demanding the Nepalese government retract the map that they claim encroaches upon Indian territory.

Amidst the rising tensions, the Nepali police attempted to disperse the crowd using tear gas and other non-lethal measures. However, as the situation intensified, and with reports of some protesters resorting to violence, the police ultimately discharged live rounds into the air, which tragically led to the death of one Indian man.

Eyewitnesses at the scene described chaotic scenes as the crowd surged towards the police lines, with many protesters reportedly throwing stones and other objects. The Nepali authorities have stated that the use of force was a last resort, taken to prevent further escalation and to protect the lives of both the protesters and law enforcement officers.

The death has provoked a strong reaction from India, with officials expressing their condolences and demanding a thorough investigation into the incident. The Indian government has also called for restraint and peaceful dialogue to resolve the ongoing territorial disputes that have strained relations between the two nations.

In Nepal, the government has promised to conduct an impartial inquiry into the use of force and has urged both countries to engage in diplomatic discussions to peacefully settle their differences. Meanwhile, local communities on both sides of the border have been affected by the closure of the crossing, disrupting trade and travel.

The incident underscores the fragile nature of Nepal-India relations, which have been marked by periodic border disputes over the years. Both governments have emphasized the need for continued dialogue and cooperation to address such issues, hoping to prevent further loss of life and maintain peace in the region. As the investigation proceeds, the international community watches closely, hoping for a resolution that fosters stability and goodwill between these two South Asian neighbors.

prompt: At least 23 Iraqi troops and pro-government fighters have been killed in clashes with militants in the western province of Anbar, officials say.
HWT: A suicide bombing at a mosque in al-Jubba killed 10 anti-jihadist fighters. Militants then attacked police and army positions, killing 13, officials said. A further 28 Iraqi troops were wounded, while militant casualties are unknown. The incidents took place near the Ain al-Asad airbase, where US forces are currently training Iraq's military. The attacks were carried out on Tuesday near the town of al-Baghdadi, which is 110 miles (180 km) north-west of Baghdad. No group has said it was behind the the attacks. However, they come as Iraqi forces battle fighters from the Islamic State (IS) militant group, which has seized large swathes of Iraq and neighbouring Syria. Iraqi forces are providing training to local fighters at the Ain al-Asad base, and on Monday Iraqi Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi called for a "tribal revolution" against IS. Meanwhile, IS said it had killed eight men in Iraq's Salahuddin province for allegedly co-operating with government security forces and international airstrikes, AP news agency reported. A series of photos posted on a Twitter account used by the group showed the men kneeling and blindfolded beside a riverbank. A provincial official speaking on condition of anonymity, however, contradicted the claim that the men were collaborators. He told AP the men were army officers who had deserted prior to IS taking over parts of the province last year, and that they had not co-operated with Iraqi government forces.
MGT:
In a recent surge of violence in Iraq's western province of Anbar, at least 23 Iraqi troops and pro-government fighters were killed in clashes with militant groups, according to officials. The clashes underscore ongoing instability in the region, despite previous efforts by the government and allied forces to regain control.

The confrontations took place in the volatile city of Ramadi, which has seen repeated cycles of conflict between government forces and various militant factions. The violence erupted when militants launched a coordinated attack on military positions, attempting to seize strategic locations within the city.

Government forces, alongside pro-government militia units, engaged the militants in fierce combat throughout the day. Despite the heavy casualties, officials reported that the troops managed to repel the attacks and maintain control over key areas. The clashes resulted in significant damage to infrastructure and civilian properties, exacerbating the humanitarian situation in the already war-torn area.

Iraqi officials have condemned the attacks, stating that they represent a deliberate attempt by militants to undermine the peace and stability the country has been striving to achieve. The government has vowed to intensify its military operations to root out insurgent elements and restore security across Anbar province.

This recent outbreak of violence in Anbar is a stark reminder of the challenges Iraq continues to face in its fight against insurgency. Despite substantial gains against extremist groups in recent years, sporadic attacks like these threaten to destabilize the region further and complicate ongoing reconstruction efforts. The international community has expressed concern over the developments, urging continued support for Iraq's security forces in their efforts to maintain peace and stability in the country.

prompt: A specialist ship has arrived at the site of one of three broken undersea internet cables to begin repairs, according to telecoms company JT.
HWT: A ship dragging its anchor on the seabed in the English Channel cut the three main internet cables to the Channel Islands on Monday. Repair work on the first cable is expected to take a week. Daragh McDermott from government owned JT said broadband speeds are expected to be slower during peak times. A second ship is on the way from France to repair the second cable and JT says the third cable will be repaired after that. Jersey's coastguard said there will be an investigation to see if the ship dropped anchor in a banned area. Owners of the King Arthur, Mediterranea di Navigazione, said they were investigating whether it was their ship that caused the problem. Three cables went one after the other on Monday with the first going at 16:00 GMT and the last by 21:00 GMT as the anchor was dragged across the seabed. Mr McDermott said: "Thanks to the actions taken since the cables were cut, we have capacity in place to manage demand, although we have obviously lost spare capacity should further issues arise."
MGT:
A specialist ship has reached the location of one of three damaged undersea internet cables to initiate urgent repair operations, according to telecoms company JT. The arrival marks a critical step in addressing connectivity issues that have impacted numerous regions since the cables were severed. The damage, caused by an unknown incident, has disrupted internet services across several countries, affecting both businesses and individuals reliant on stable connections.

JT has confirmed that their team of expert technicians aboard the vessel is equipped to handle the complex underwater repair process. The technicians are prepared to deploy remotely operated vehicles (ROVs) to assess the full extent of the damage and execute necessary repairs. This operation is expected to be challenging due to the depth and harsh conditions at the cable's location.

The company has emphasized the importance of these cables for maintaining the global internet infrastructure, as they carry a significant portion of international data traffic. Until the repairs are completed, users in affected areas may experience slower internet speeds or intermittent connectivity. JT is working diligently to minimize downtime and restore services as swiftly as possible.

As the repair team undertakes this critical mission, JT continues to coordinate with regional partners to manage the ongoing impact on local internet services. The successful restoration of these cables is essential for ensuring the stability and robustness of global communication networks.

prompt: Former Fiji and Leicester back Seru Rabeni has died at the age of 37.
HWT: Rabeni represented Fiji at the 2003 and 2007 World Cups and Premiership side Leicester between 2004-2009, before joining Leeds. Nicknamed 'Rambo' because of his marriage of pace and brutal tackling, he also played in New Zealand and France and was a noted sevens exponent. Fiji media reported Rabeni died at his home in Nausori, just outside the capital, Suva, on Tuesday. The Fiji Village website said the cause of death was unknown but quoted his father-in-law as saying he had been "sick for a while". Rabeni, who played as a centre or wing, is survived by his wife and two children. "We are shocked and saddened to hear of the passing of Seru Rabeni. Our thoughts go to all his friends and family," tweeted Leicester. "Incredibly sad news to hear Seru Rabeni has passed away. Rest in peace big man," Fiji Sevens coach Ben Ryan tweeted. Fiji-born former Wallaby Lote Tuqiri said Rabeni was "a great man taken away too young", while ex-Samoa centre Eliota Faumaono-Sapolu said Pacific rugby had lost one of its greats. "Stunned! RIP Seru Rabeni," tweeted Faumaono-Sapolu. "Absolutely hated every minute playing against you constantly smashing and stepping me." Scotland's James Hamilton, a former team-mate at Leicester, described Rabeni as "an incredible player and lovely man".
MGT:
The rugby community is mourning the loss of Seru Rabeni, a former Fiji international and player for Leicester Tigers, who passed away at the age of 37. Rabeni, known for his dedication and passion for the sport, left an indelible mark on rugby both at home and abroad.

Born in Fiji, Rabeni began his rugby career with local clubs before making the move to the UK, where he joined Leicester Tigers. His playing style was characterized by his physical strength and strategic acumen on the field, earning him a respected place among his peers and fans alike. During his tenure with Leicester, Rabeni contributed significantly to the team's successes, including their triumph in the 2001 Premiership Final.

Rabeni's international career with Fiji was equally noteworthy. He was a key player for the national team, participating in multiple Pacific Nations Cup tournaments and the 2003 Rugby World Cup. His performances on the international stage helped bring attention to Fiji's growing rugby talent.

Beyond his on-field achievements, Rabeni was celebrated for his leadership and commitment to the sport. He inspired many young players in Fiji with his work ethic and love for rugby. His untimely passing has left a void in the rugby community, and thoughts are with his family, friends, and teammates during this difficult time.

Tributes have poured in from across the rugby world, with former teammates and rivals alike sharing their respect and admiration for Rabeni. Leicester Tigers have expressed their condolences, highlighting his contributions to the club and the impact he had on those around him.

Seru Rabeni's legacy will live on through the memories of those who knew him and the countless young rugby players he inspired. His passing is a significant loss to the sport, and he will be remembered as a talented player and a true ambassador for rugby in Fiji and beyond.

prompt: Mobile phone company EE has introduced a charge for jumping the queue on customer service calls.
HWT: Callers are invited by an automated message to use the priority service for a flat fee of 50 pence. Some customers, especially those who have been with the company for years, are unhappy that calls are not treated equally. But EE said that they had set high standards for their customer service operations. One customer - Andrew Griffiths - told BBC Radio 4's You and Yours that he would consider switching if EE was the only firm to do this. It added that the "small charges" for certain services contributed to the investment in this side of the business. The priority answering system is similar in some ways to queue jumping charges at airports and theme parks. The service has been available for a week to customers on pay monthly on Sim-only plans. "I thought it was a bad idea for a company to offer to provide what really ought to be a standard level of customer service for a fee," he said. "It makes you think that perhaps they might not be trying too hard to answer the non-prioritised calls."
MGT:
EE, a leading mobile phone company, has recently announced the introduction of a charge for customers who wish to bypass the waiting list on customer service calls. This new policy aims to manage the high volume of inquiries more effectively and ensure a fairer system for all customers. Under the new rules, customers who opt to skip the queue will be subject to a fee, while those who choose to wait their turn will continue to receive free assistance.

This move comes in response to growing demand for EE's customer service, particularly as more users seek support for technical issues and billing queries. Many customers have expressed frustration over long wait times, prompting EE to explore solutions that could enhance service efficiency.

EE's spokesperson highlighted that the fee will vary depending on the time of day and the complexity of the query. The company assures that this change will not affect the quality of service provided but will instead allow customer service representatives more time to address each case thoroughly.

Customers have mixed reactions to this development. Some appreciate the effort to improve service, while others are concerned about the additional cost. EE has committed to monitoring the impact of this policy and adjusting as necessary to maintain customer satisfaction. The company encourages users to utilize online resources and self-help tools to resolve common issues without needing to call.

prompt: Tottenham midfielder Erik Lamela has been ruled out for the rest of the season because of a hip injury.
HWT: The 25-year-old Argentina international has not played for Spurs since October because of the problem and will undergo surgery on Saturday. Tottenham said Lamela had "achieved a good level of function" but was not at a stage to make a return to training, leading to the decision to operate. "I tried everything to recover but my hip is still not 100%," Lamela tweeted. "I can't compete at the level I want to. I'll face this challenge with a positive attitude and can't wait to get back with the team and be stronger." Lamela had made 14 appearances this season for Spurs before the injury. He joined Tottenham from Roma in 2013 and enjoyed a superb season last term, scoring 13 goals. Spurs are second in the Premier League, 10 points behind leaders Chelsea, who they also play in the semi-finals of the FA Cup.
MGT:
Tottenham Hotspur have confirmed that midfielder Erik Lamela will miss the remainder of the season due to a hip injury. The Argentine international has been an influential presence in the team, contributing significantly with his creative play and goal-scoring abilities. However, the latest medical assessments have indicated that surgery is necessary, sidelining Lamela for the foreseeable future. 

Lamela's absence will be felt deeply as Spurs navigate the crucial final stages of the Premier League campaign and their European commitments. His dynamic style and vision have been key elements in Tottenham's attacking setup throughout the season. The club has expressed their support for Lamela during his recovery, emphasizing their commitment to ensuring he receives the best possible care to return to full fitness.

In the meantime, manager Antonio Conte will need to adjust his lineup and tactics to fill the creative void left by Lamela's injury. Spurs will rely on their remaining squad depth and possibly look for short-term reinforcements to maintain their competitive edge. The team will also focus on securing a top-four finish in the Premier League, as they aim to qualify for the Champions League next season.

prompt: The candidates to become Labour's nomination for London mayor have clashed over airport expansion in their first hustings debate.
HWT: Tooting MP Sadiq Khan defended his opposition to a third runway at Heathrow, saying London's air quality was already breaching EU regulations. He said Gatwick Airport should be expanded, with "high speed links" between the two and a single check-in. But rival David Lammy accused him of "the same Ed Miliband politics". "My view is the way to proceed is no third runway at Heathrow," Mr Khan said, calling for "a better Heathrow, not a bigger one". But Tottenham MP Mr Lammy questioned the timing of Mr Khan's decision, which came after the emergence of Conservative MP and environmental campaigner Zac Goldsmith as a potential Tory candidate for the 2016 election. "Zac Goldsmith has announced he's running and suddenly Sadiq is against it," he said, accusing Mr Khan of "playing the same Ed Miliband politics that got us nowhere". Former culture secretary Tessa Jowell said she was prepared to wait until the final report of the Airports Commission which is looking at the options for expanding London's air capacity before making up her mind. But she warned against the issue becoming "gridlocked" in government. "We can't go on forever putting this decision off because it's just too difficult," she said. Journalist Christian Wolmar said climate change should inform the decision, while Harrow West MP Gareth Thomas said new runways should be built at both Heathrow and Gatwick. Hackney North and Stoke Newington MP Diane Abbott also opposed Heathrow expansion. The candidates were also asked about the "mansion" tax on homes worth over Â£2m that was proposed by Labour ahead of the general election. Mr Lammy, Ms Jowell, Ms Abbott and Mr Wolmar all criticised the policy, with Ms Jowell saying that while it had been "well intentioned" it had been "emblematically disastrous" for Labour because it had caused people "anxiety" even if they weren't affected.
MGT:
In a heated first hustings debate, candidates vying for Labour’s nomination for London Mayor engaged in a fiery discussion over the contentious issue of airport expansion. The debate, held in central London, brought the city's aviation future to the forefront, with each candidate presenting their vision for managing growth and environmental concerns.

The debate opened with the frontrunner, Sarah Jones, emphasizing her commitment to sustainable development. Jones argued that while London needs to maintain its status as a global aviation hub, this should not come at the expense of the environment. She proposed investing in green technology and improving existing airport infrastructure rather than expanding capacity. Jones highlighted the necessity of working with environmental groups to ensure that any future developments align with climate goals.

Opposing this stance, candidate David Greenfield argued that airport expansion is critical to boosting the city's economy and maintaining its competitive edge in the global market. Greenfield pointed to the potential for job creation and increased tourism revenue, suggesting that expansion could be achieved through modern, eco-friendly methods. He acknowledged the environmental concerns but stressed the importance of strategic planning to mitigate potential impacts.

Meanwhile, Zoe Edwards took a middle-ground approach, advocating for a comprehensive review of the current airport capacities and their usage. Edwards proposed conducting a detailed feasibility study to assess the real need for expansion, considering factors such as technological advancements in aircraft efficiency and changes in passenger behavior. She emphasized the need for transparent public consultations to gauge residents' opinions and ensure community interests are prioritized.

The candidates also discussed the importance of cross-party collaboration in addressing the airport expansion issue. Jones stressed the value of working with other political parties and stakeholders to find a balanced solution that considers both economic and environmental priorities. Greenfield echoed the sentiment, highlighting the need for a united approach to navigate the complex challenges associated with aviation growth in a densely populated city.

As the debate concluded, it was clear that airport expansion remains a divisive issue within the Labour Party, reflecting broader societal debates over growth and sustainability. With the nomination race heating up, voters are keen to see how each candidate will balance the competing demands of economic development and environmental responsibility in their potential mayoral campaign.

The hustings debate set the stage for further discussions, with each candidate vowing to engage with the public and experts to refine their policies. As Londoners look to the future of their city's skies, the outcome of this nomination race could significantly influence the direction of the city's aviation strategy.

prompt: Profits at Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba have nearly tripled ahead of the firm's planned US stock market debut this autumn.
HWT: In a filing with US regulators, Alibaba said second-quarter profit was 12.3bn renminbi ($2bn; £1.2bn), compared to 4.3bn renminbi last year. The firm will list on the New York Stock Exchange later this year. It is expected to be the biggest internet stock offering since Facebook's in 2012. Many analysts believe that the company could raise over $20bn in its stock market debut, which is expected to happen in September. That would value the company at somewhere between $130bn and $150bn. Those hoping to invest in the firm - which controls the lion's share of China's rapidly expanding e-commerce market - were cheered by the increasing number of users accessing Alibaba's various sites via their smartphones. Monthly active mobile users increased to 188 million for the quarter, which ended on 30 June, an increase of 25 million from the prior quarter. And those users were increasingly eager to spend: Alibaba said mobile merchandise sales nearly quadrupled, and now make up nearly a third of all merchandise volume sold on the site. Founded in 1999 by Jack Ma, Alibaba controls several popular internet sites in China, including Tmall - where brands can sell their wares - and Taobao, the world's largest online shopping website.
MGT:
Alibaba, the Chinese e-commerce behemoth, has announced a staggering near-tripling of its profits in the latest financial quarter, signaling robust growth as it gears up for its much-anticipated US stock market debut this autumn. The company's financial performance underscores its dominant position in the Chinese market and its expanding global footprint.

Alibaba's impressive earnings report reflects the company's strategic initiatives and adaptability in a competitive digital landscape. The surge in profits has been attributed to a significant increase in online retail sales, bolstered by the ongoing impact of the pandemic, which has accelerated digital transformation and e-commerce adoption worldwide. Alibaba's diverse portfolio, including cloud computing services, digital media, and logistics, has also contributed to its robust financial health.

As Alibaba prepares for its public offering in the United States, the company is poised to become one of the world's most valuable firms. The move to list on the US stock exchange is seen as a strategic effort to enhance its global presence and attract international investors. This listing follows the recent success of other major Chinese tech companies in Western markets, further highlighting the growing influence of Chinese enterprises on the global stage.

Alibaba's leadership remains optimistic about the company's future, emphasizing its commitment to innovation and customer-centric solutions. As it approaches its stock market debut, Alibaba's financial performance not only reflects its past successes but also sets the stage for its ambitious plans to expand and innovate in the years to come.

prompt: A Welsh rugby player has been banned after testing positive for a steroid.
HWT: Joseph Phelps of Newbridge RFC cannot play for four years, making him the 13th Welsh rugby union player to currently be serving a ban. United Kingdom Anti-Doping says Phelps' use of nandrolone was detected in June 2015 and he is banned until July 2019. A summary of the tribunal published by Ukad said Phelps claimed he had taken Viagra and a "test booster" product to treat erectile dysfunction. He also claimed not to have taken anything "for performance enhancement in sport" but to treat symptoms he had suffered after sustaining a testicular injury. A report by Professor David Cowan, Director of the Drug Control Centre at King's College London, confirmed to the tribunal that "the human body does not naturally produce nandrolone in measurable quantities and that nandrolone is a drug administered via deep intra-muscular injection". Ukad legal chief Graham Arthur said athletes are "solely responsible" for banned substance found in their system. Arthur added: "This case highlights that all athletes, regardless of level, must be aware, and understand, the risks to their sporting careers if they test positive. "They must ensure they manage that risk at all times." Phelps' ban comes less than a month after Ukad chief executive Nicole Sapstead said a "societal problem" could be the cause of steroid drug use in Welsh rugby. Newbridge play in Swalec Championship.
MGT:
A prominent Welsh rugby player has been handed a ban after testing positive for a steroid, in a significant blow to both the player and the sport. The athlete, whose identity has been withheld pending further investigation, tested positive during a routine out-of-competition drug test administered by the World Rugby authorities.

The player, a key member of the Welsh national team and a star in the domestic Premiership, tested positive for a banned substance that falls into the category of anabolic agents, specifically a prohibited steroid. World Rugby has confirmed the player's suspension, which will see them sidelined for a minimum of 18 months, in accordance with the organization's anti-doping policy. This period may be extended depending on the outcome of the ongoing investigation and any mitigating factors.

The player issued a statement expressing deep regret over the situation, emphasizing that they never intended to gain an unfair advantage or compromise the integrity of the sport. The athlete further stated that they are cooperating fully with the authorities and have voluntarily sought guidance from anti-doping experts to better understand the implications of the substance found in their system.

Welsh Rugby Union and the player's club have both expressed disappointment at the news, highlighting the stringent anti-doping measures they adhere to and their commitment to clean sport. The club has confirmed that it will continue to support the player during this challenging time but reiterated its zero-tolerance policy towards any form of doping.

This incident has sparked a broader conversation within the rugby community about the pressures athletes face and the importance of robust anti-doping education and support systems. As the investigation continues, the rugby community awaits further details and hopes for a swift resolution to this unfortunate episode.

prompt: Ceredigion council has failed to co-operate with an investigation into the closure of a Llandysul residential home, a union has claimed.
HWT: Unison said the council had failed to provide answers for social care expert Tony Garthwaite, heading the investigation, and that he was not able to complete his report. Awel Deg care home was shut in February 2014, making 40 employees redundant. The council said it was working with Mr Garthwaite. Awel Deg was closed following the suspension of 11 members of staff and concerns about standards of care. The council said in May 2014 the facility would re-open as a dementia home in spring 2015, but a spokesman said on Wednesday that this could not happen until Mr Garthwaite's investigation was complete. Jeff Baker, regional organiser for Unison, said the union had written to the council complaining about the wait. "It is very disappointing," he said. "Unison understands that Mr Garthwaite cannot complete his report because the council has not taken steps to provide answers to key matters that Mr Garthwaite has put forward." A council spokesman said it was aware of Unison's comments. "The council is working with Tony Garthwaite... to ensure that he has access to all the relevant information that he requires in order that he can complete his investigation," the spokesman said.
MGT:
Ceredigion Council has been accused of failing to cooperate with an investigation into the controversial closure of a residential home in Llandysul, according to a union. The home, which provided care for several elderly residents, was abruptly shut down, leaving families and staff scrambling for answers and alternative arrangements.

The union representing the home's staff has voiced its concerns over the council's lack of transparency and engagement throughout the investigative process. It claims that crucial information has been withheld and that there has been a lack of meaningful communication with both the staff and the residents' families. This has exacerbated the anxiety and uncertainty surrounding the closure.

The council has defended its actions, stating that the closure was necessary due to financial constraints and the need to ensure the sustainability of care services in the area. However, the union argues that the lack of consultation with staff and the community before the decision was made is unacceptable. They assert that more could have been done to explore alternative solutions or to provide adequate notice and support to those affected.

The closure has raised significant concerns about the future of care provision in the region, with many fearing that similar actions could be taken elsewhere. The union is calling for a comprehensive review of the council's decision-making process and for greater accountability in how such critical services are managed. As the investigation continues, families and staff are seeking assurances that their needs and concerns will be addressed.

prompt: Ross County manager Jim McIntyre is urging the Staggies to deliver another of their big-game performances against Aberdeen in Saturday's cup tie.
HWT: County host the Dons in one of three all-Premiership Scottish Cup fifth-round fixtures. "Our best performances this season have been against the bigger sides," McIntyre told BBC Scotland. "We know we're going to have to have a good performance again in order to get into the next round." McIntyre's men beat Aberdeen when they visited Victoria Park in the league in December and also defeated them in Dingwall last season. "Aberdeen are playing well at the moment," said McIntyre of the side sitting second in the Premiership. "They've got real pace in their team. They're a real threat at set-plays also. "We know we need to bring the type of performance that we've had against them here in Dingwall over the last year or so. It's going to take something similar again. "Their front four are very potent and they've got lots of goals in them and generally most of their goals come from that. "You need to try and nullify that major threat that they have in that front four positions." County drew 1-1 with Rangers at Ibrox in last weekend's Premiership match, having led 1-0 at the break. And McIntyre's assistant Billy Dodds told Radio Scotland's Sportsound: "The Rangers game on Saturday, it's the best first 45 minutes we've played at any big ground, whether it's Aberdeen, Celtic, Rangers. "We really deserved to probably be a couple in front but it wasn't to be. "We've been a bit inconsistent in the league this year. We look a right good team sometimes. "It's not the ideal draw [against Aberdeen] but it's a great game to take part in. It's such a tricky tie, it'd be hard to call. "I would like to get through the tie at first time of asking. A trip to Pittodrie [in a replay], you would make Aberdeen probably heavy favourites. "Our best chance is to go and do it first time. We'll be going all out to do that. Scottish Cup has a special feeling about it."
MGT:
Ross County manager Jim McIntyre is calling on his team, the Staggies, to channel the same spirit and performance level they've shown in previous big games as they prepare to face Aberdeen in Saturday's Scottish Cup tie. McIntyre knows the importance of this match for his squad, emphasizing the need for a strong, cohesive performance to overcome a formidable opponent.

Ross County’s journey to this cup game has been marked by resilience and determination, traits that McIntyre hopes will be evident once again. The team has shown they can rise to the occasion, delivering impressive performances against top-tier teams in the league. Now, with Aberdeen on the horizon, McIntyre is urging his players to harness that same energy and focus.

McIntyre pointed out that the Scottish Cup offers an opportunity for Ross County to achieve something special, especially in a competition that has historically brought unexpected thrills and upsets. "We've prepared well for this game," McIntyre said. "We know Aberdeen is a strong side with quality players, but we have our own strengths that we need to exploit."

The manager highlighted the importance of maintaining a solid defensive structure while also pressing high to disrupt Aberdeen’s rhythm. McIntyre believes that if Ross County can control the midfield and apply pressure, they will limit the opportunities for Aberdeen's attacking threats.

In terms of tactics, McIntyre has been focusing on flexibility and adaptability, preparing his team to adjust their game plan as the match unfolds. "We must be ready to change things if needed," he stated. "Our players need to be sharp and ready to make the right decisions at the right times."

For Ross County, the Scottish Cup not only presents a chance to progress further in the competition but also an opportunity to bolster their confidence and momentum. McIntyre is aware of the psychological boost that a good cup run can provide, especially as the team aims to maintain their league position and finish the season strongly.

The squad has been working hard in training, with McIntyre emphasizing the importance of physical fitness and mental toughness. He praised his players' commitment and work ethic, noting that their dedication in training sessions is a positive sign for the upcoming match.

As the Staggies gear up for this crucial cup tie, the support from their fans will be vital. The team will be looking to the stands for that extra push, hoping the energy from the crowd will spur them on to another memorable performance.

In conclusion, Jim McIntyre is confident that if Ross County can replicate the tenacity and determination they've shown in other big games, they have a real chance to defeat Aberdeen. With preparation focused on both tactical discipline and mental resilience, the Staggies are ready to face the challenge head-on, aiming to create another chapter in their Scottish Cup history.

prompt: The safety of a light aircraft was compromised in a near-miss with a commercial drone, investigators found.
HWT: The incident happened near Byfield 2,000ft (610m) over the skies of Northamptonshire, in May. The pilot of the Van's RV-6 two-seater, single engine craft had to take evasive action, and the drone passed down the left-hand side of the aircraft. He reported the near-miss, but the drone could not be seen on radar and the operator could not be traced. The UK Airprox Board, set up to enhance air safety in the UK, branded the risk rating a "category B", meaning the aircraft's security was compromised. The pilot described the drone as a "red and yellow, three-rotor drone", which was the "type that can be easily bought in shops and not a commercial surveillance type vehicle". The report states the drone operator should not have been operating the drone at such a high altitude. It says: "Because the drone was being operated at an altitude it should not have been, the reported drone was flown into conflict with the RV6. "Although there was no radar data to measure the exact separation, the Board thought it was clear from the pilot's report that this was a fairly close encounter, and they assessed the risk as Category B."
MGT:
In a startling incident reported by aviation safety investigators, the safety of a light aircraft was compromised following a near-miss with a commercial drone. The event, which occurred over a densely populated urban area, has sparked renewed debates about the regulation of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) and their coexistence with manned aircraft.

The incident took place when a small, privately-owned light aircraft was conducting a routine flight path. According to preliminary reports, the aircraft narrowly avoided a collision with a commercial drone that was reportedly operating within restricted airspace. The light aircraft pilot managed to execute an emergency maneuver just in time, averting what could have been a catastrophic event.

Investigations into the incident have highlighted significant gaps in current drone regulation and airspace management. The drone, operated by a commercial entity, was found to be flying without the necessary permissions and clearances, raising concerns over the enforcement of existing laws designed to prevent such occurrences.

Aviation authorities have responded by urging stricter compliance with airspace regulations and the implementation of more robust monitoring systems to track drone activities. They emphasized the critical need for both commercial and recreational drone operators to adhere to safety protocols to prevent interference with manned aircraft operations.

The incident has prompted calls for immediate action to address these regulatory shortfalls. Experts are advocating for enhanced communication channels between manned and unmanned aircraft traffic management systems and increased public awareness about drone operation guidelines.

As investigations continue, this incident serves as a stark reminder of the potential risks posed by drones in shared airspace and underscores the urgency for comprehensive regulatory measures to ensure the safety of all airspace users.

prompt: A petition calling for a hospital's minor injuries unit to remain open 24 hours is being presented to Gloucestershire county councillors.
HWT: More than 5,000 people have signed the petition to keep Stroud Hospital's unit open through the night. Tim Lezard, from Stroud Labour Party, which organised the campaign, said it was "a local service that people need". But Paul Jennings, from Gloucestershire Care Services NHS Trust, said keeping it open was "not practical". Mr Jennings said: "We're not in a position to provide an overnight service at Stroud and Cirencester minor injury units, that's why we've had to have so many closures over the last few months. "We simply cannot recruit the staff to work those shifts. They don't want to do it, there are very few patients. It's potentially quite de-skilling and demoralising for the nurses who would be working there.  It's just not a practical proposition." Mr Lezard said: "The danger is now that people will have to go to Gloucester and it is already overstretched in A & E there." There are eight minor injury units in Gloucestershire. Cirencester and Stroud hospitals currently offer a 24 hour service. Other units, which are not open overnight, are based in Dilke Memorial Hospital, Lydney and District Hospital, North Cotswolds Hospital, Tewkesbury Hospital, Vale Community Hospital and Tetbury Hospital. The units treat both adults and children for a variety of injuries and illnesses including sprains, minor fractures, cuts and wounds and rashes, bites or stings.
MGT:
Residents of Gloucestershire are rallying behind a petition to ensure their local hospital's minor injuries unit remains operational 24 hours a day. The campaign, gaining significant traction, is set to be presented to county councillors, who will weigh the community's concerns and demands.

The petition highlights the crucial role the minor injuries unit plays in providing accessible and timely healthcare services for non-life-threatening conditions. Residents argue that having the unit open round-the-clock is essential for the well-being of the community, offering critical first aid and care for accidents and minor injuries that occur outside regular hours.

The petition, backed by hundreds of local supporters, underscores the increasing reliance on the facility due to rising population and the limited availability of other healthcare services in the area. Many signatories have shared personal stories, emphasizing how the unit has been instrumental in managing emergencies during late hours when other healthcare options are unavailable.

The county council will review the petition during their next meeting, where they will consider the perspectives of healthcare professionals and financial implications. Supporters of the campaign are hopeful that the council will acknowledge the importance of maintaining 24/7 operations, ensuring the unit's continued support for the community's healthcare needs.

As the debate unfolds, community groups are organizing events to raise awareness and gather further support. They aim to demonstrate to the council the widespread public support and the potential negative impact on health outcomes if the unit's hours were to be reduced. The outcome of the council's decision will be eagerly awaited by the community, with many hopeful for a positive resolution that maintains the unit's essential services.

prompt: The pilot of a small plane was forced to make an emergency landing near a reservoir in the Highlands.
HWT: Friday afternoon's incident near Kinlochleven is being investigated by the Air Accidents Investigation Branch. Two men in the Piper Cub - the pilot and his passenger - were uninjured. The aircraft is understood to be stuck in a bog near Blackwater Reservoir. Inverness Coastguard helicopter picked up the pair and flew them to Oban Airport. The pilot's "pan-pan", an emergency call, was received by the Distress and Diversion Emergency Centre based at RAF Swanwick near Southampton. It was picked up by air traffic controllers at Prestwick Airport in Ayrshire. The crew of an easyJet passenger plane was understood to have relayed the distress call to the Distress and Diversion Emergency Centre. The Air Accidents Investigation Branch confirmed the incident had been reported to it and it was investigating. Meanwhile, the Mountain Bothies Association said it had received an inquiry about use of the bothy near to the scene by the plane's owner when attempts are made to remove the aircraft.

prompt: Thousands of leaflets containing life-saving information are being given out to inexperienced fell walkers.
HWT: Last year teams carried out 480 rescues - a fall of 10% compared to 2015,  but the Lake District Search and Mountain Rescue Association (LDSMRA) said the figure is too high. This week its volunteers have been giving out 9,000 copies of Stay Safe on the Cumbrian Fells. Volunteers are giving out 2,000 more copies over Easter. They are also leaving copies in tourist offices and shops. Richard Warren, chairman of LDSMRA, said: "These safety leaflets are primarily targeting those people who perhaps need a little bit of help in preparing themselves for their outings onto the fells, many of whom won't have been high up on a mountain before." He said the leaflet is a simple, step-by-step guide to remind people what they should do before they set out on the fells - and what to do if they have an accident. It costs around Â£500,000 a year to run the county's 12 rescue teams which are funded through voluntary donations.
MGT:
Thousands of leaflets containing vital life-saving information are being distributed to inexperienced fell walkers, aiming to enhance safety on rugged terrains. This initiative comes as a response to the rising number of incidents involving unprepared hikers facing adverse conditions in the fells.

The leaflets, created by local safety organizations in collaboration with park authorities, cover essential tips on navigation, weather awareness, and emergency procedures. They emphasize the importance of wearing appropriate gear, staying on marked paths, and being aware of one's physical limits. The guide also includes advice on what to do in case of injury or sudden weather changes, ensuring hikers are better prepared to handle unexpected situations.

“We’re witnessing more people exploring the beauty of the fells, often without fully understanding the risks involved,” said a spokesperson from the safety committee. “Our goal is to equip them with the knowledge they need to enjoy their experience safely.”

Distribution points include popular trailheads and visitor centers, where rangers offer additional guidance and support. The campaign also encourages experienced walkers to mentor newcomers, fostering a community of responsible and informed outdoor enthusiasts.

This proactive approach aims to reduce accidents and ensure that the natural splendor of the fells remains accessible and enjoyable for all.

prompt: The city of Baltimore says it has reached a proposed $6.4 million (Â£4.2M) wrongful death settlement with the family of Freddie Gray.
HWT: Six Baltimore police officers face criminal charges for the death of Gray, who died of a critical spine injury while in police custody in April. Riots, looting and violence shook the city in the days following the black 25-year-old's death. The city will propose the settlement to its Board of Estimates on Wednesday. Gray was in the back of a prisoner transport van when he was injured. His death is of one of several involving black Americans and police which has spurred national debate, unrest and various social justice movements. Baltimore police have admitted he was not secured by a seatbelt, as required by law, and he was denied medical attention while in the van. The settlement would "resolve all civil claims related to the City of Baltimore, the Baltimore Police Department, individual Baltimore Police offers and any other persons or institutions who might be deemed responsible for the death of Mr Gray," according to a statement from Baltimore Mayor Stephanie-Rawlings Blake. The payment does not resolve any "factual disputes" surrounding his death and does not admit liability or fault on the part of the city or the police department, the statement added. It is not a judgement on the guilt or innocence of the officers facing trial, said Ms Rawlings-Blake. The total payment being proposed for Gray's case is more than the total paid out by the city for more than 120 other lawsuits against the Baltimore Police Department since 2011, the Baltimore Sun newspaper reports. The officers facing criminal charges ranging from false imprisonment to involuntary manslaughter have pleaded not guilty. Dates for their trials have not been set yet.
MGT:
The city of Baltimore has announced a proposed settlement of $6.4 million with the family of Freddie Gray, whose death in police custody sparked widespread protests and calls for justice. The settlement aims to resolve the wrongful death lawsuit filed by Gray's family, stemming from the tragic events of April 2015.

Freddie Gray, a 25-year-old African American man, suffered a fatal spinal cord injury while being transported in a police van. The injuries occurred after he was arrested and placed in the van without being secured by a seatbelt. Gray’s death ignited a series of protests across Baltimore and brought national attention to issues of police conduct and systemic racism.

The proposed settlement comes after a protracted legal battle and intense public scrutiny. Baltimore City officials announced their intention to settle, emphasizing their commitment to healing and reconciliation within the community. The city's decision to settle reflects an acknowledgment of the profound impact Gray's death has had on his family and the city at large.

Gray's family has expressed a mix of relief and sorrow, welcoming the settlement as a step towards justice, while also emphasizing that it cannot bring back Freddie. They hope the settlement will bring about meaningful changes in police practices and accountability.

The settlement includes a provision for the city to implement significant reforms aimed at improving police procedures and community relations. These reforms are designed to prevent similar incidents from occurring in the future and to ensure that law enforcement officers are held accountable for their actions.

The announcement of the settlement has been met with a range of reactions. Community leaders and activists view it as a positive development toward justice and reform, while some critics argue that it is insufficient in addressing the broader issues of systemic racism and police brutality.

As the city moves forward, both officials and community members are focused on fostering dialogue and implementing changes that will promote trust and safety for all residents. The settlement marks a pivotal moment in Baltimore's ongoing efforts to heal and rebuild in the aftermath of Freddie Gray's death.

prompt: A Saturday Night Live writer has been suspended after posting a tweet mocking US President Donald Trump's son Barron, US media reports say.
HWT: They quote a person familiar with SNL's plans as saying Katie Rich was suspended indefinitely. The programme's network, NBC, is yet to comment. One Facebook post in reaction to her previous tweet has been shared nearly three million times. The post read: "NO child deserves to be talked to in such a manner... prompt: Colombia's Mining Minister German Arce has questioned whether the result of a referendum held in the town of Cajamarca, where 98% of residents voted against a major gold mining project, will prevail.
HWT: Locals fear it will damage the environment and pollute their water sources. La Colosa, in Central Colombia, has the potential to become South America's largest gold mine. Mr Arce said the town's decision could not be applied retroactively. The minister added that the South African mining giant AngloGold Ashanti had already been issued an exploration licence, which would retain its validity. Mr Arce also said that while the land was under the control of local authorities, any subterranean riches were under the control of the national government. The minister said that if AngloGold Ashanti was awarded the environmental licence it needs to proceed with the project, the courts or Colombia's congress would have to decide whether the local or national authorities prevailed. Mr Arce insisted that the referendum vote would not affect foreign investment in Colombia's mining sector. "For the first time in 20 years we will have three major projects in execution phase," he told RCN. He said campaigners had misinformed voters. "We're not talking about an open-air mine here," he said. "Nor are there a hundred rivers at risk." Campaigners were angered by Mr Arce's comments. The opposition to President Juan Manuel Santos also criticised the government's stance on the issue. "Santos and the Mining Minister agreed to disregard Cajamarca's decision on La Colosa. Democratic mobilisation will also defeat them," tweeted opposition Senator and presidential hopeful Jorge Robledo. Only 76 residents of Cajamarca, in the central province of Tolima, voted in favour of the mining project in Sunday's referendum, while more than 6,100 of the town's 19,000 inhabitants voted against. Several other Colombian cities and towns are planning to hold similar votes to try to block mining projects in their area. Correction 29 March 2017: This story has been amended to clarify the government's position on the mining ban.
MGT:
In a significant development concerning a major gold mining project in Colombia, Mining Minister German Arce has raised questions about the outcome of a recent referendum held in the town of Cajamarca. In this referendum, an overwhelming 98% of the residents voted against the proposed mining initiative, casting doubt on the future of the project.

The referendum took place in Cajamarca, a small town that stands to be directly affected by the mining operations. The proposed project, spearheaded by a Canadian mining company, aims to extract gold from the region, promising economic benefits such as job creation and infrastructure development. However, the project has been met with strong opposition from local communities who fear the environmental and social impacts that could arise from such large-scale mining activities.

Despite the resounding vote against the project, Minister Arce expressed skepticism about whether the referendum result will ultimately determine the project's fate. His comments have sparked a debate about the power and influence of local referendums in decision-making processes related to mining and development projects in Colombia.

The controversy highlights a broader tension between economic development goals and community rights in the country. Proponents of the project argue that it would bring much-needed economic growth and development to the region, which has historically been marginalized. They point to potential employment opportunities and improvements in local infrastructure as key benefits.

On the other hand, opponents, including environmental activists and local residents, emphasize the potential risks to the region's water supply, biodiversity, and overall environmental health. They argue that the long-term costs of environmental degradation could outweigh the short-term economic gains. Additionally, there are concerns about the social implications, including the displacement of communities and the potential for increased social inequality.

The referendum in Cajamarca is not an isolated incident. Across Colombia, there has been growing resistance to mining projects, with communities increasingly demanding a say in decisions that directly impact their lives and environment. This has led to calls for more inclusive and transparent decision-making processes that take into account the voices and concerns of local populations.

As the debate continues, the Colombian government faces the challenge of balancing economic interests with environmental protection and community rights. The outcome of this situation in Cajamarca could set a precedent for how similar conflicts are addressed in the future, potentially reshaping the country's approach to mining and development. For now, the residents of Cajamarca remain hopeful that their overwhelming vote will be respected and that their concerns will be addressed in the decision-making process.

prompt: New Southampton manager Claude Puel says captain and Portugal international Jose Fonte is staying at the club.
HWT: Centre-back Fonte, 32, helped his country to Euro 2016 victory in July and has been linked with a move to Manchester United. "It is important to keep Jose Fonte at Southampton," Puel said. "He is a very important player for the team, a good player and I don't see that it is a possibility for him to leave us." Puel, who joined the club as successor to Ronald Koeman in June, believes many players in his squad will attract interest during the transfer window. "It's no different for Jose Fonte than it is for other players," he said. "I'm enjoying sitting down and working with this squad. "The qualities are there, but there is also the spirit and attitude, which is encouraging for the future of Southampton." Puel will take charge of his first Premier League game at home to Watford on Saturday. The former Nice, Monaco and Lyon manager will be without England left-back Ryan Bertrand through injury, but is set to use summer signing Nathan Redmond in an attacking role. Puel said: "Last season at Norwich, he often played out wide, but I think he is a very good striker. He can make different things happen. It's a good surprise for me, because he has real potential."
MGT:
Southampton have confirmed the retention of their captain, Jose Fonte, amid the managerial change at St Mary's Stadium. Claude Puel, the newly appointed manager, has made it clear that the Portugal international will remain an integral part of the team as they look to rebuild and compete in the Premier League.

Following the departure of Mark Hughes, Puel was brought in to steer the Saints through a challenging season. In his first press conference, Puel emphasized the importance of stability and continuity, highlighting Fonte's leadership qualities and experience as critical to his plans. "Jose Fonte is a vital player for us," Puel stated. "His leadership on and off the pitch is something we value immensely. He is not just a central defender but a leader who embodies the spirit and resilience we want in our team."

Fonte, who joined Southampton in 2015, has been a key figure in the club's defensive setup. His performances have earned him a place in the Portugal national team, where he continues to showcase his defensive prowess. His commitment to Southampton has been unwavering, and this has been reciprocated by the club's management, who are keen on building a cohesive squad around their captain.

As Puel looks to implement his tactical vision, maintaining a core group of players like Fonte will be crucial. The manager, known for his tactical acumen, believes that building on existing foundations will help the team adapt swiftly to his methods. "We have a good basis to work with," Puel remarked. "It's about enhancing what we have and ensuring we grow together."

Fonte's continued presence at the club is a reassuring sign for Southampton fans, who have been anxious about the club's direction following the managerial upheaval. With Puel at the helm and Fonte as a central figure, the Saints are poised to tackle the upcoming fixtures with renewed vigor and determination.

prompt: A woman believed to be in her 80s has died after apparently being shot by a fellow resident at a care home in Essex, police have said.
HWT: Police have begun a murder inquiry and a man has been arrested on suspicion of murder. Police said the victim and the alleged assailant were residents in the home. Officers were called to De La Mer House care home in Naze Park Road, Walton-on-the-Naze, at about 09:00 GMT after reports a woman was seriously injured. DCI Simon Werrett said: "At this stage we are not looking for anyone else in connection with the investigation and our inquiries are ongoing." The premises are being guarded while forensic searches are conducted. Nearby resident and retired financial adviser John Knights said security was tight at the care home. He said: "My mother had to go into  De La Mer about two years ago, and I can tell you that it was quite tricky to get in and out of there. "You couldn't just go up to the building and get in. You needed a security code to get in. It had electronic key pads on the door, so to get inside you needed to know those." A spokeswoman for the care home said there would be no comment until staff had spoken to police. Douglas Carswell, the UKIP MP for the area, said he was "very shocked". He said: "If you have got a loved one in a care home, you expect them to be safe. Walton-on-the-Naze is supposed to be one of the most peaceful and tranquil places there is. Of all the places you expect this to happen, this is the last."

prompt: Anyone lucky enough to have a £50 note in their wallet or purse will find it is the only banknote made of paper in a few years.
HWT: The Bank of England has announced that the next design of the £20 note will be plastic. The new £20 note, entering circulation in 2020, will follow the polymer £5 and £10 notes. Consumers will be able to get their hands on the new plastic £5 note, the first in the polymer series, from 2016. This will feature the image of Sir Winston Churchill. The Bank argues that the polymer notes stay cleaner and are more secure than cotton paper notes, which have been used for more than 100 years. The £5 polymer note will enter circulation in the autumn of 2016, followed by the Jane Austen plastic £10 note a year later. The Bank said that the decision for the £20 note to also be made from polymer came after "extensive research into the developments in security features". On a more practical level for many consumers, it will also survive a spin in the washing machine. A bank committee is considering which character will appear on the new £20 note. It received 29,701 nominations from the public after it announced it wanted to celebrate an artist on the note. Some 592 eligible visual artists are being considered for the honour. The final decision will be made by the Bank's governor, Mark Carney. Favourites include the sculptor and artist Barbara Hepworth, the author Beatrix Potter and fashion designer Alexander McQueen. Whoever wins will replace the economist Adam Smith on the current £20 note. The next £50 could also be made of plastic, but it will be some time before that decision is made. The latest version of the note, featuring Matthew Boulton and James Watt, only entered circulation in November 2011. Clydesdale Bank in Scotland has issued a limited number of polymer notes. In 1999, Northern Bank of Northern Ireland issued a polymer £5 commemorative note celebrating the year 2000. A plastic note was introduced in the Isle of Man in 1983 but was withdrawn in 1988 owing to problems with the ink.
MGT:
In a significant move set to transform the landscape of UK currency, the Bank of England has announced plans to phase out all paper banknotes, leaving the £50 note as the sole paper denomination in circulation. This decision marks a pivotal shift towards greater durability and security in the nation's currency, prompted by technological advances and environmental considerations.

Currently, the UK's banknotes, including the £5, £10, and £20, are crafted from a unique polymer blend—a material that has proven to be far more resilient than traditional paper. This enhanced durability means the notes last longer in circulation, reducing the environmental impact associated with frequent replacements. The transition to polymer began in 2016 with the introduction of the new £5 note, featuring Winston Churchill, and has since expanded to the £10 and £20, depicting Jane Austen and J.M.W. Turner respectively. The success and acceptance of these polymer notes have encouraged the Bank of England to continue on this path.

While polymer notes offer numerous advantages, such as increased resistance to wear and tear and enhanced security features that combat counterfeiting, the £50 note remains the last bastion of the traditional paper format. The Bank of England has cited cost-effectiveness and the current satisfactory level of security and durability of the £50 note as reasons for maintaining its paper form, at least in the near term.

As the transition continues, the public will need to be mindful of the shift. The Bank of England is committed to ensuring an orderly transition, with clear communication and support for those who may be unfamiliar with the new polymer technology. Banks and retailers are also being urged to update their infrastructure to accommodate the new notes, ensuring seamless transactions across the economy.

Environmental concerns also play a role in this currency evolution. The polymer notes are recyclable, and their longevity means fewer resources are expended over time, aligning with broader sustainability goals. The Bank of England has indicated that once the decision is made to convert the £50 note to polymer, it will be done with careful planning to minimize disruption and maximize environmental benefits.

In conclusion, the move away from paper banknotes underscores the Bank of England's commitment to modernizing the UK's currency system while addressing practical and ecological considerations. As the public adjusts to this change, the long-term benefits are anticipated to outweigh the initial adaptations required, securing a more sustainable and secure future for UK currency.
