prompt: Former Eggheads star CJ de Mooi will "continue to co-operate with the Dutch authorities" after a failed attempt to extradite him to the Netherlands over an alleged killing.
HWT: The ex-quiz show panellist, 46, from Caldicot, Monmouthshire, is accused of manslaughter, murder, assault and battery in Amsterdam in 1988. He was detained under a European arrest warrant at Heathrow Airport last month. Dutch authorities reportedly abandoned a bid to bring him to the Netherlands. Mr de Mooi, whose real name is Joseph Connagh, was said to be "very pleased". His manager said in a statement: "CJ is obviously very pleased with the result of today's hearing and will continue to co-operate with the Dutch authorities until this matter is finally concluded. "He would like to thank the tens of thousands of people who have contacted him via social media and in person, for their lovely words and support during this traumatic time for him." Mr de Mooi's autobiography, published last year, described an incident in which he said he may have killed a man while he lived on the streets. He said he punched a man who approached him with a knife before throwing him into a canal in 1988. In his book, he wrote: "He caught me on the wrong day and I just snapped. I fully suspect I killed him. I've no idea what happened to him." Mr de Mooi, originally from Barnsley, South Yorkshire, adopted the name de Mooi when modelling. He became a panellist on Eggheads in 2003 after winning a series of game shows.
MGT:
Former "Eggheads" star CJ de Mooi has pledged to continue cooperating with Dutch authorities following a failed attempt to extradite him to the Netherlands on allegations of involvement in a murder case. De Mooi, known for his appearance on the popular British quiz show, is accused of being involved in the 1979 killing of American sailor Carl Kiekhaefer.

The extradition bid, which was pursued by Dutch prosecutors, was recently halted by a UK court. The decision was based on procedural grounds rather than any determination of de Mooi's guilt or innocence. The court cited concerns about the length of time since the alleged crime and the potential impact on de Mooi's ability to receive a fair trial.

Despite the setback in extradition efforts, de Mooi has expressed his willingness to assist the investigation. In a statement, he stated, "I have always intended to cooperate fully with the authorities, and I will continue to do so." His legal team has emphasized his commitment to transparency and urged patience as proceedings continue.

The case against de Mooi has garnered significant media attention, partly due to his high-profile status in the UK. The alleged crime occurred in the Netherlands when de Mooi was only 18 years old. The victim, Carl Kiekhaefer, was found dead under suspicious circumstances, leading to a long-standing investigation that has spanned decades.

Dutch authorities remain determined to pursue the case and have indicated that they will explore alternative legal avenues to bring de Mooi to trial. Meanwhile, de Mooi continues to live in the UK, where he has maintained a relatively low profile since the attempted extradition.

As the situation develops, both legal experts and the public are closely watching to see how the case will proceed. The complexities of international law and the passage of time add layers of challenge to the pursuit of justice in this high-profile case.

However, they were left to bemoan a series of handling errors after Hinchcliffe's try put Huddersfield ahead. Huddersfield then saw their restart go out on the full, allowing Roberts the chance to quickly play provider for Webster as Tigers piled the points on. Gale gave Daryl Powell's side the ideal start to the second half, crossing for the first of his tries after just 30 seconds, as Castleford went on to win big to remain top. prompt: Plans for a new rail link to Heathrow Airport as part of the HS2 high-speed network have been ruled out by the transport minister Patrick McLoughlin.
HWT: He was responding to a question by MP Dominic Grieve about the Heathrow spur. Mr McLoughlin said: "I would now like to make clear that we do not intend to build the spur as part of Phase 1 or 2 of the HS2 scheme". HS2 is a planned high-speed rail network from London to Birmingham, Manchester and Leeds. Previously the government had said any decision about the Heathrow spur would be delayed until the Davies Commission's report on future UK airport capacity had been completed. Responding to Mr Grieve's written Parliamentary question, the minister cited the Airports Commission review findings - published in November - which "indicated that an HS2 spur is highly unlikely to be necessary to support any expansion of Heathrow airport". Nick Hurd, Conservative MP for Ruislip, Northwood and Pinner tweeted he was "delighted" the government had dropped the idea and gave "credit to ministers for listening to our argument". He said the best way of connecting passengers to Heathrow was via Old Oak Common. He said it also simplified the case for extending the HS2 tunnel to protect Ickenham and Colne Valley. Paul Prentice, assistant news editor at Rail magazine said it was a "very sensible decision. Bearing in mind there is already a spur tunnel to Heathrow and another western link being built". Campaigner Lottie Jones from Hillingdon Against HS2 said the group was "delighted" with the decision but cautious that it was not "just a pre-election sweetener" that might be revoked.
MGT:
In a significant development for the UK's transportation infrastructure plans, Transport Minister Patrick McLoughlin has announced the cancellation of a proposed rail link to Heathrow Airport as part of the HS2 high-speed network. This decision marks a notable shift in the government's strategic approach to enhancing connectivity around one of the world's busiest airports.

The original plan aimed to integrate Heathrow into the HS2 network, promising to reduce travel times significantly and improve accessibility for passengers and freight. Proponents argued that such a link would bolster the UK's position as a global aviation hub, facilitating smoother transit for both international travelers and cargo.

However, McLoughlin cited financial constraints and the need to prioritize other elements of the HS2 project as the primary reasons for the decision. The HS2 rail line, designed to connect London with the Midlands and the North of England, has faced scrutiny over its escalating costs and ambitious timelines. By ruling out the Heathrow link, the government intends to streamline the project and focus resources on its core objectives.

The decision has sparked a mix of reactions. Critics argue that the omission could hinder economic growth and undermine the UK's competitive edge in global aviation. They believe that the rail link would have been instrumental in alleviating some of the congestion and logistical challenges faced by Heathrow, particularly given the expanding demand for air travel.

On the other hand, supporters of the decision emphasize fiscal responsibility and the importance of delivering the HS2 network as planned without further delays or budget overruns. They contend that the benefits of connecting major cities in the North and Midlands will provide a substantial economic boost and should not be compromised by additional expenditures.

As the HS2 project continues to advance, stakeholders in the aviation and transportation sectors are keenly watching for further developments, anticipating the broader implications of this decision on the UK's infrastructure strategy.

By ruling out the Heathrow link, the government intends to streamline the project and focus resources on its core objectives.

The decision has sparked a mix of reactions. Critics argue that the omission could hinder economic growth and undermine the UK's competitive edge in global aviation. They believe that the rail link would have been instrumental in alleviating some of the congestion and logistical challenges faced by Heathrow, particularly given the expanding demand for air travel.

On the other hand, supporters of the decision emphasize fiscal responsibility and the importance of delivering the HS2 network as planned without further delays or budget overruns. They contend that the benefits of connecting major cities in the North and Midlands will provide a substantial economic boost and should not be compromised by additional expenditures.

As the HS2 project continues to advance, stakeholders in the aviation and transportation sectors are keenly watching for further developments, anticipating the broader implications of this decision on the UK's infrastructure strategy.

prompt: Tunisian side Club Africain will host French giants Paris Saint-Germain (PSG) in a friendly match next month.
HWT: The game will take place at the Olympic Stadium in Rades on 4 January, according to the French side. The 1991 African champions and the six-time French Ligue 1 winners will contest the Trophée Ooredoo des Champions at the ground which hosted the 2004 African Cup of Nations final. PSG are expected to field a strong squad, including star names such as Edinson Cavani, Thiago Silva, Serge Aurier and Angel Di Maria. The match is to be bankrolled by Ooredoo, the premier private telephone operator in Tunisia. "I'm very happy that the players and the staff will have the chance to come and experience the Tunisians' fervour for football," PSG managing director Frédéric Longuépée said. "Paris Saint-German is very popular in Tunisia, with more social media fans numbering over 575,000 and growing everyday. "This tour will be a great chance for us to come and meet them. Thanks to their support, we'll be playing in a fantastic atmosphere," Longuépée added. Paris Saint-Germain have played five matches in Tunisia. The last two of those matches were held at the Olympic Stadium in Rades. Over the last two years, Paris Saint-Germain have also had a presence in Tunisia thanks to the Paris Saint-Germain Academy programme, in partnership with Ooredoo. Sessions were held in Tunis in 2015 and Sousse in March 2016.

prompt: Alan Campbell will become the first NI competitor at four Olympic Games after his selection for Team GB along with brothers Peter and Richard Chambers.
HWT: The Coleraine rowers were medallists in London four years ago. Peter Chambers is selected men's lightweight four for Rio while Richard partners Will Fletchers in the Lightweight Double Scull. Meanwhile, Hillsborough's Clare Abbott has been named in the Ireland Eventing Team for the Olympics. The 29-year-old will ride chestnut gelding Europrince at the Rio Games. Campbell, who won bronze in 2012, is delighted to make history as Northern Ireland's first four-time Olympian. "I feel very honoured, it's very special and I'm just so happy," said Campbell. "Sport is something very special in Northern Ireland and to carry the flag for a fourth time is unbelievable. "The Olympics is the pinnacle, what makes all those horrible mornings, driving snow and sleet worthwhile. "It brings together the best of the best and I'm glad I will be there once again."
MGT:
Alan Campbell has secured his place at the Tokyo Olympics, becoming the first Northern Irish athlete to compete at four different Olympic Games. Selected as part of Team GB, Campbell joins his brothers, Peter and Richard Chambers, in representing Great Britain. This remarkable achievement highlights Campbell's enduring dedication and exceptional performance in the pool.

Campbell's journey to his fourth Olympics is a testament to his resilience and commitment to the sport. Having previously competed in London 2012, Rio 2016, and Tokyo 2020, he has consistently demonstrated his prowess in the 200m breaststroke. The trio of brothers, all swimming champions, have been a formidable presence in British swimming, inspiring aspiring athletes across the nation.

Peter and Richard Chambers, both seasoned Olympians, will also be representing Team GB in Tokyo. Their participation adds further depth to Britain's strong swimming contingent. As Alan prepares for his fourth Olympic appearance, he carries the hopes of Northern Ireland, aiming to add to his impressive collection of medals and personal bests. This unique family achievement will surely capture the attention of fans worldwide, as they rally behind the Chambers brothers in their pursuit of Olympic glory.

prompt: Japanese tech giant Sony swung to a net profit in the second quarter of its financial year, driven by strong sales of its PlayStation 4 video games.
HWT: Profit was 33.6bn yen ($278m; Â£182m) in the three months to September, compared with a 136bn yen loss a year earlier. The results are big turnaround for the firm that has seen years of losses and undergone a restructuring, which has resulted in job cuts and asset sales. Its first half restructuring charges were down 35% at 15.7bn yen. But sales of its smartphones continued to decline. "In the Mobile Communications segment, sales decreased primarily due to a significant decrease in smartphone unit sales resulting from a strategic decision not to pursue scale in order to improve profitability," the company said. Overall, its sales fell 0.5% to 1.8tn yen despite the uptick in demand for PS4 games and image sensors. Expecting to sell more PS4 consoles, Sony left its forecast for earnings for the year ending in March 2016 unchanged. "Sales are expected to be higher than the July forecast primarily due to an expected increase in PS4 hardware unit sales and PS4 software sales," the company said. The earnings report comes a day after Sony announced that it would take over Toshiba's image sensor business.
MGT:
Japanese tech giant Sony has reported a significant turnaround in its financial performance for the second quarter, swinging to a net profit primarily fueled by robust sales of its PlayStation 4 video game console. The gaming division played a crucial role in offsetting challenges faced by other segments of the company, marking a promising shift in its financial trajectory.

Sony's latest financial results demonstrate the enduring popularity of the PlayStation 4, which continues to attract a large user base despite the growing anticipation of its successor. The console's strong sales have been instrumental in driving revenue, bolstered by a compelling lineup of exclusive titles and services that have kept consumers engaged.

In addition to the success of the PlayStation 4, Sony's digital content and services, including its music and film divisions, have shown steady performance, contributing to the overall profitability. However, the company remains cautious, acknowledging ongoing challenges in other areas, such as its struggling mobile and imaging businesses, which have been underperforming.

Despite these challenges, Sony's financial recovery in the second quarter reflects its ability to leverage its core strengths in the gaming and entertainment sectors. The company remains focused on capitalizing on these areas while exploring strategic initiatives to revitalize its weaker segments. With a clear emphasis on innovation and customer engagement, Sony is poised to maintain its momentum in the competitive tech landscape.

prompt: A missing woman was struck and fatally injured by a police van that had been sent out to search for her, investigators said.
HWT: The woman, who was walking in Hethel, Norfolk, died in hospital a day after being hit by the vehicle on 27 July. The Duke of Cambridge was on his final shift as an air ambulance pilot when he was sent out to attend the incident. The Independent Police Complaints Commission (IPCC) said her family had reported her missing hours earlier. The IPCC said: "Early indications are that the police van had its blue lights on at the time of the collision." Investigators confirmed police had been "attending her missing persons report". "The woman had been reported missing and concerns for her welfare raised by her family earlier that evening," the IPCC said. "She was taken to hospital by air ambulance where she died in the morning of Saturday." IPCC Operations manager Adam Stacey said: "The IPCC has now begun an investigation to determine the circumstances that led to her death and the actions of Norfolk police officers that night."
MGT:
A tragic incident occurred last night when a woman who had been reported missing was fatally struck by a police van that was dispatched in the search for her. The incident took place in a suburban neighborhood late in the evening as law enforcement officers were actively combing the area.

The woman, whose identity has not been released pending notification of next of kin, was crossing a busy street when she was hit by the police vehicle. Despite immediate medical attention and efforts by first responders, she was pronounced dead at the scene.

Authorities have initiated a thorough investigation into the circumstances surrounding the accident. The police department has expressed deep regret over the incident and extended condolences to the woman's family. The officers involved are currently on administrative leave as the investigation progresses.

The local community, shaken by the news, has called for enhanced safety measures during search operations. The police have promised to review their procedures and ensure such a tragedy does not happen again. Meanwhile, the family has been notified and is receiving support from local grief counselors. The department urges anyone with additional information or who may have witnessed the incident to come forward to assist in the ongoing investigation.

prompt: World number two Serena Williams suffered a shock defeat in her second match back after injury at the ASB Classic in New Zealand.
HWT: The 35-year-old lost 4-6 7-6 (7-3) 4-6 to compatriot and world number 72 Madison Brengle in Auckland. Williams had returned to action after four months out on Tuesday, claiming she was 'rusty' despite winning. It was a disappointing day for the Williams sisters after older sister Venus withdrew with an arm injury. The 36-year-old beat New Zealand wildcard Jade Lewis 7-6 (7-2) 6-2 and was due to play Japan's Naomi Osaka in the second round later on Wednesday but pulled out before the match. Tournament director Karl Budge said that the seven-time Grand Slam winner "wasn't able to serve as she would like to and at the level that we have come to expect from Venus and unfortunately that has taken her away from the tournament this year". Venus later posted a message on Twitter thanking her supporters. Britain's Naomi Broady won her opening match at the tournament before suffering a second-round exit. Broady, ranked 90 in the world, beat Danka Kovinic of Montenegro 7-6 (7-5) 6-3 to ensure she remains in the top 100. The British number three, who reached the quarter-finals last year, was back on court later on Wednesday but lost 7-5 6-4 to Germany's Julia Goerges, who is 37 places above her in the rankings.
MGT:
Serena Williams, the world number two and tennis legend, experienced an unexpected setback in her latest match at the ASB Classic in New Zealand. Returning to the court after a period of injury, Williams faced an early exit in her second match at the tournament. The match, which took place on a cool Saturday evening, saw Williams go head-to-head with American player Ann Li.

The match was highly anticipated, as fans and spectators were eager to see how Williams would perform following her absence from the sport. However, Li delivered a stunning performance, showcasing a formidable serve and strategic gameplay. Despite Williams' persistent efforts and her best attempts at a comeback, Li maintained her composure and secured a decisive victory.

Williams, known for her resilience and fighting spirit, expressed her disappointment with the outcome but remained optimistic about her recovery and future matches. "I’m just trying to get back into the rhythm and flow of the game," Williams commented after the match. "I’m proud of how far I’ve come, and I know I’ll bounce back stronger."

The defeat was a reminder of the challenges athletes face when returning from injury. Nonetheless, Williams' presence at the tournament was a testament to her dedication and determination to reclaim her position at the top of the sport. The tennis community continues to support her journey back to form, eagerly awaiting her next steps on the court.

prompt: A new 1,000-space lorry park to help reduce congestion from queuing lorries on the M20 and in Dover has local support, an MP says.
HWT: Charlie Elphicke, Conservative MP for Dover and Deal, said Shepway District Council supported the plans for a smaller lorry park at Westenhanger. The council's leader had previously branded a proposed 3,300-space lorry park as "bonkers". Lorries are allowed to park on the M20 when there are delays at Channel ports. The proposed lorry park is aimed at relieving pressure caused by Operation Stack, when trucks are allowed to queue due to delays at Channel Tunnel and ferry ports. Mr Elphicke said: "We've had major problems in Dover in recent months because of the level of gridlock, which is a weekly occurrence. "We need a long term solution. There is a site near Folkestone which could be the site with up to 1,000 lorry parking spaces. "[Shepway] District Council is supportive and I'm making the case it should be advance check-in, before lorries go down to the Eastern Docks. "There would be 1,000 spaces in the Eastern Docks and 1,000 spaces near Folkestone which would be enough capacity not to cause gridlock in Dover." A spokeswoman said Shepway council was "driving plans" for a lorry park with about 1,000 spaces. She said the authority was looking at land near Westenhanger and was talking to local land owners. Councillor Paul Carter, Conservative leader of Kent County Council, said problems arising from Operation Stack were "intolerable" to the people of Kent. He said: "We need national government to fund what is needed to get the private sector to operate those lorry parks. "Recently, the government introduced charging for foreign lorries using our roads, and I believe a substantial amount of the money should be used to fund these lorry parks."
MGT:
A new 1,000-space lorry park designed to alleviate congestion from queuing lorries on the M20 and in Dover has received local support, according to an MP. The facility, strategically positioned to address the frequent traffic snarls and delays that have plagued the area, is expected to significantly ease the burden on both roads and local communities.

The congestion issue has been a persistent problem, especially during peak hours and periods of heightened activity at the port. Long lines of lorries often spill over onto local roads, causing delays for commuters and businesses alike. The introduction of the lorry park is seen as a proactive measure to manage these disruptions more effectively.

Local MP, Jane Smith, expressed her enthusiasm for the project, emphasizing that it aligns with the community's desire for improved infrastructure and traffic management. "This new lorry park is a vital development for our area," Smith stated. "It not only supports our local economy by ensuring smoother transit for goods but also enhances the quality of life for our residents by reducing the congestion that frequently affects our roads."

The park is expected to serve as a holding area where lorries can wait without contributing to road congestion. This approach is anticipated to facilitate better traffic flow on the M20, one of the main arteries for freight and passenger traffic between London and the Channel ports.

The project has also garnered support from local businesses that rely on the efficient movement of goods. Many have faced challenges due to the unpredictable delays caused by lorry queues, impacting delivery schedules and operational efficiency. The lorry park is expected to provide a more predictable and reliable environment for logistics operations.

Environmental benefits are also anticipated, as reduced idling of lorries will likely lead to lower emissions. This aspect of the project has been particularly welcomed by environmental groups and local residents concerned about air quality.

Funding and construction timelines for the lorry park have been outlined, with the goal of having the facility operational within the next two years. Local authorities and stakeholders are working closely to ensure the project meets the community's needs while minimizing any potential disruptions during its development.

Overall, the new lorry park is seen as a positive step forward, promising to enhance logistical efficiency and improve the daily lives of those affected by the current congestion issues.

prompt: Gareth Southgate says trying to keep Manchester United boss Jose Mourinho happy would be "fairly difficult" - and that he will not stop making decisions "that are right for England".
HWT: The England coach has picked United's Marcus Rashford, 19, in his squad. The teenage striker will now miss the Under-21 European Championship this summer - something Mourinho wanted. "I'm not in a position where I can make decisions to keep people happy. I'm not going to achieve that," said Southgate. "The key is not the relationship with Jose, it's the relationship with Marcus. I didn't speak to him [Mourinho] about it. I let him know where I was heading at the end." Mourinho said last month Rashford should not go to the Euros as "it does not make a lot of sense to drop levels". The FA previously indicated young players needed tournament experience. Rashford has instead been called up for the World Cup qualifier against Scotland on 10 June and the friendly against France three days later. He played 58 games for United and England this season, scoring 11 goals, having broken into his club's first-team last term. Just four months into his first professional season in February 2016, he was selected for Euro 2016 by England manager Roy Hodgson and has gone on to win eight caps. Rashford led the line in United's Europa League final win over Ajax and came on in the EFL Cup final triumph over Southampton. Southgate said he "wants a good working relationship with the clubs" but has to make decisions "that are right for England". The former international defender added: "I have got to make decisions that are right for England seniors long term, I'm always mindful of what is right for the players. "Respectfully, none of the managers are going to be around in 10 years, or it's very, very unlikely, and I think people like Marcus Rashford will be. "So there's always going to be some collision at some point on that and some disagreement on that."
MGT:
Gareth Southgate, the England national team manager, has openly acknowledged the complexities of managing international football amidst the dynamics of club interests. In a candid interview, Southgate addressed the intricate relationship between his role and the influential figures in the Premier League, particularly highlighting Manchester United manager Jose Mourinho. The manager remarked that attempting to keep Mourinho content with his international team selections would be "fairly difficult." Southgate emphasized his primary responsibility is to England's national team, insisting that decisions will always be made in the best interest of the country's football ambitions.

Southgate's comments come amid increasing scrutiny of how national team managers navigate the often conflicting interests between club and country. This is especially pertinent given the high-profile nature of players like Marcus Rashford and Paul Pogba, both of whom have played significant roles at both club and international levels. The manager's stance reflects a commitment to prioritizing England’s goals over any potential discord with club managers.

The England manager further elaborated on his approach, stating that while he values the input and perspectives of club managers, the overarching aim is to field the strongest team possible for national duty. Southgate understands the pressures that players face when balancing commitments to their clubs and the national team, but he remains steadfast in his belief that the pursuit of excellence for England must come first.

Southgate's leadership style has been characterized by a focus on team cohesion and development. Since taking the helm, he has been instrumental in fostering a positive team environment, which has translated into successful performances on the international stage. His tenure has seen England reach the semi-finals of the 2018 World Cup and become UEFA Nations League champions, milestones that have reaffirmed his philosophy and approach.

In his remarks, Southgate also addressed the broader implications of his decisions on international football. He believes that maintaining a clear and independent stance is vital for the integrity of the sport. By prioritizing national team success, he hopes to inspire a new generation of players who see representing their country as a prestigious and rewarding endeavor.

Overall, Southgate's comments underscore his dedication to England's footballing progress. While acknowledging the challenges that arise from the dual pressures of club and country, he remains committed to making choices that serve the best interests of the national team, regardless of external opinions.

This is especially pertinent given the high-profile nature of players like Marcus Rashford and Paul Pogba, both of whom have played significant roles at both club and international levels. The manager's stance reflects a commitment to prioritizing England’s goals over any potential discord with club managers.

The England manager further elaborated on his approach, stating that while he values the input and perspectives of club managers, the overarching aim is to field the strongest team possible for national duty. Southgate understands the pressures that players face when balancing commitments to their clubs and the national team, but he remains steadfast in his belief that the pursuit of excellence for England must come first.

Southgate's leadership style has been characterized by a focus on team cohesion and development. Since taking the helm, he has been instrumental in fostering a positive team environment, which has translated into successful performances on the international stage. His tenure has seen England reach the semi-finals of the 2018 World Cup and become UEFA Nations League champions, milestones that have reaffirmed his philosophy and approach.

In his remarks, Southgate also addressed the broader implications of his decisions on international football. He believes that maintaining a clear and independent stance is vital for the integrity of the sport. By prioritizing national team success, he hopes to inspire a new generation of players who see representing their country as a prestigious and rewarding endeavor.

Overall, Southgate's comments underscore his dedication to England's footballing progress. While acknowledging the challenges that arise from the dual pressures of club and country, he remains committed to making choices that serve the best interests of the national team, regardless of external opinions.

prompt: Ukraine's energy minister has said that a "technical fault" in Europe's largest nuclear power plant has cut production but poses no danger.
HWT: Volodymyr Demchyshyn said on Wednesday that one of the reactors at the Zaporizhzhya plant in the south of Ukraine had automatically shut down. There was no problem with the reactor itself and the problem would be fixed by the weekend, he added. Zaporizhzhya produces more than one-fifth of Ukraine's electricity. The operator of the nuclear plant, Energoatom, had reported a problem with the power plant on Friday. But the details were not fully disclosed until a cabinet meeting on Wednesday when Prime Minister Arseniy Yatsenyuk asked the energy minister to report on what had happened. Mr Demchyshyn said that damage to a transformer in a power-generating unit had triggered an automatic shutdown of one of the six 1,000 MW reactors. He added that there was "no threat" to the safety of the reactor. The French Institute for Radiological Protection and Nuclear Safety (IRSN) told Reuters that their sensors had not detected anything unusual in Ukraine. Michel Chouha, IRSN's special representative for Central and Eastern Europe, said: "If there was an accident, we would know." The drop in electricity production has left several dozen towns and villages without electricity, Russian media reported. Ukraine's energy industry is already under pressure because of a fuel shortage. Mr Demchyshyn said that Ukraine will probably have to import power from Russia this winter. He called it a "necessary step" despite how "politically problematic it might be". Last year Ukraine was self-sufficient in electricity but the conflict with pro-Russian rebels in the east of the country has severely hit coal production. Ukraine has already agreed a $4.6bn package of gas supplies from Russia, ending months of wrangling with Moscow over prices.
MGT:
In a recent development concerning Europe's largest nuclear power plant, Ukraine's Energy Minister has reported a "technical fault" at the facility, resulting in a temporary halt in production. The minister reassured the public and international community, emphasizing that the situation poses no danger to safety or security.

The fault occurred at the Rivne Nuclear Power Plant, a crucial energy source for the region. Despite the interruption in operations, the minister highlighted that the plant's safety systems functioned as designed, preventing any risk of radiation exposure or environmental harm. This swift response by plant operators underscores the robust safety measures in place at Ukraine's nuclear facilities.

The Rivne plant, located in the western part of Ukraine, plays a significant role in the country's energy infrastructure, providing a substantial portion of its electricity needs. The technical issue has necessitated a temporary suspension of operations, as technicians work diligently to diagnose and rectify the fault. The Ukrainian Energy Ministry is closely monitoring the situation, coordinating with international nuclear safety agencies to ensure all protocols are followed.

While the exact nature of the technical fault has not been disclosed, the minister assured that the plant's staff are well-trained and experienced in handling such incidents. The plant's design includes multiple redundancies and safety systems to manage and mitigate any potential risks, ensuring the protection of both personnel and the surrounding environment.

In the meantime, Ukraine is taking measures to compensate for the temporary loss of power from the Rivne plant. This includes leveraging alternative energy sources and optimizing the energy supply across the national grid to maintain stability. The government remains committed to transparency and has pledged to keep the public informed as the situation evolves.

This incident serves as a reminder of the complexities and challenges associated with nuclear energy production. However, the swift action and effective management of the situation by Ukrainian authorities and plant operators demonstrate a strong commitment to maintaining safety and security standards. The Energy Ministry continues to work closely with all relevant parties to ensure a swift resolution and the resumption of normal operations at the Rivne Nuclear Power Plant.

prompt: The centre-left coalition of Prime Minister Victor Ponta has swept to victory in Romania's general election.
HWT: The Social Liberal Union (USL) won nearly 60% of the vote, with four-fifths of ballots counted. The Right Romania Alliance (ARD) of centre-right President Traian Basescu came a distant second with about 17%. The result could open the door to a constitutional crisis, as the president has previously hinted he may refuse to reappoint his arch-rival Mr Ponta. Mr Ponta said: "This is a clear victory with an absolute majority." But, if he resumes as prime minister, he will have to share power with Mr Basescu, whose term runs until 2014. The pair have been locked in a power struggle since Mr Ponta came to power in April following the collapse of the previous centre-right government. The two men have argued over control of state television and the Romanian Cultural Institute and attempts to draw up a new electoral law. But, says the BBC's correspondent in the region Nick Thorpe, the political feud often seems to have more to do with the vanity of the main players than with genuine differences in policy. Their antagonism has meant political decision-making has at times been paralysed. In July, Mr Ponta suspended Mr Basescu and tried to impeach him. But a referendum failed to meet the required turnout. Mr Basescu hinted before the election that he might refuse to re-appoint Mr Ponta as prime minister. He has described him as a "mythomaniac". Mr Basescu's popularity has plummeted since he introduced stringent austerity measures and a 25% cut in public sector pay. Romania is the second poorest member of the European Union, which it joined in 2007 with Bulgaria. The country, together with neighbour Bulgaria, are under special EU monitoring because of concerns about judicial independence, corruption and political influence in state institutions. Romania is trying to negotiate a new loan from the IMF to replace the existing one which expires early next year.
MGT:
Romania's political landscape has undergone a significant transformation following the recent general elections, where the centre-left coalition led by Prime Minister Victor Ponta claimed a decisive victory. This outcome marks a pivotal moment for the country as it embraces a new direction under Ponta’s leadership, reflecting the electorate's desire for change and reform.

The elections, characterized by high voter turnout, showcased the Romanian public's support for the centre-left coalition's agenda, which emphasizes social welfare, economic growth, and anti-corruption measures. Victor Ponta, who has been at the forefront of Romanian politics, articulated a vision that resonated with many citizens, promising to address pressing issues such as unemployment, healthcare, and education.

Ponta's coalition managed to secure a substantial majority in both the Chamber of Deputies and the Senate, enabling them to govern without the need for coalition partners, thus providing a stable foundation for implementing their policy initiatives. This political stability is seen as a crucial factor in bolstering investor confidence and fostering economic development in Romania.

The victory is also attributed to the coalition's effective campaign strategy, which focused on connecting with voters through grassroots engagement and addressing their immediate concerns. By promising reforms aimed at improving public services and increasing transparency in government, Ponta’s coalition was able to galvanize support across various demographics, including the youth and working-class citizens.

International observers noted that the elections were conducted smoothly, with a high degree of transparency and fairness, reinforcing Romania's democratic credentials on the global stage. This success is expected to enhance Romania's standing within the European Union, as it aligns with broader EU goals of promoting democracy, rule of law, and economic integration.

In his victory speech, Prime Minister Ponta expressed gratitude to the Romanian people for their trust and outlined his administration's priorities. He emphasized the importance of collaboration with EU partners to drive forward economic reforms and ensure sustainable growth. Additionally, Ponta reaffirmed his commitment to tackling corruption, a persistent issue that has plagued Romanian politics for years.

As Romania embarks on this new chapter, the centre-left coalition faces the challenge of translating electoral promises into tangible outcomes. The public's expectations are high, and the government's ability to deliver on its commitments will be closely scrutinized. Nonetheless, the election results have injected a sense of optimism into the nation, as many hope for a brighter future under the leadership of Victor Ponta and his coalition.

prompt: The government could be forced to think again over plans to restrict trade union funding of political parties after a defeat in the Lords.
HWT: Peers voted by 327 to 234, to give a majority of 93 to a Labour motion forcing the plans to be debated by a cross party select committee. Labour fears it could lose Â£6m a year under the Trade Union Bill proposals. Labour's Baroness Smith of Basildon rejected government claims the bill would not hurt her party financially. She told peers democracy would be damaged if the government pushed through the changes on funding without them being scrutinised by a select committee first. As it stands, the legislation would require Labour-affiliated union members to "opt in" to paying a levy to the party instead of having it automatically deducted. Lady Smith said: "Our genuinely held concern is that this aspect of the bill will have a significant impact on the resources of one major political party - my party, the Labour Party. "And in doing so, it will both disrupt the political balance in the UK and have a damaging effect on the electoral process and our democracy." Conservative and Lib Dem peers suggested the government should rethink its proposals. Tory peer Lord Forsyth said: "It will take away funding from the Labour Party at a time when the Labour Party is perhaps not at its strongest... our Parliamentary system does depend upon having a strong and effective opposition." Labour is also reported to be set to lose out by about Â£1.3m a year when state funding for opposition parties - known as Short money - is cut. Junior business minister Baroness Neville-Rolfe, responding for the government, said Labour's motion would shift the focus of scrutiny on the Bill to party funding and away from its central purpose of trade union reform. She added: "This Bill is a package of measures and it's disappointing that the party opposite has chosen to misinterpret our intentions."
MGT:
In a significant parliamentary setback, the government faces pressure to reconsider its plans to restrict trade union funding of political parties following a defeat in the House of Lords. The proposed legislation aimed to limit the political levy by ensuring that union members actively opt-in to fund political activities. However, the Lords voted against the bill, highlighting concerns over the implications for workers' rights and political representation.

The defeat underscores the contentious nature of the legislation, which has sparked a heated debate about the balance between individual choice and collective political influence. Critics argue that the requirement for unions to obtain explicit consent from each member to use their dues for political purposes could undermine the financial stability of political parties that traditionally rely on union support, particularly the Labour Party.

Supporters of the bill, primarily from the government, contend that the changes are necessary to ensure transparency and reflect the true wishes of union members. They argue that the current system allows for the use of funds without explicit consent, which could disenfranchise members who do not wish to contribute to political causes.

The loss in the Lords has prompted calls for a re-evaluation of the government's approach, with some suggesting that a compromise might be necessary to address the concerns raised. The government now faces the challenge of navigating these legislative hurdles while maintaining its commitment to reforming political funding.

Labour leaders have welcomed the defeat, emphasizing the importance of union support in shaping political discourse and advocating for workers' rights. They argue that the proposed restrictions could disproportionately affect their party's ability to campaign effectively.

As the government prepares to respond to the Lords' decision, the debate continues to highlight the broader issue of political funding and the role of trade unions in the UK's democratic process. The outcome of this legislative battle will have significant implications for the relationship between unions, political parties, and the electorate.

In the coming weeks, the government will need to decide whether to attempt to push the bill through again, possibly with amendments, or to seek alternative measures to achieve its objectives. The situation remains fluid, with both sides of the debate preparing for further negotiations in this complex and politically sensitive issue.

prompt: German police have carried out nationwide dawn raids on more than 200 mosques, apartments and offices associated with an Islamist group.
HWT: The raids came as the government banned the group, which it accused of trying to recruit fighters for so-called Islamic State (IS). An Interior Ministry spokeswoman said there was no indication DWR (True Religion) was planning attacks itself. She said the group had breached the constitution and incited hatred. There was no immediate statement from the group. Some of those who have gone to fight for IS in the Middle East had contact with the organisation before they left. Officials estimate that almost 900 people in total have so far left Germany to join IS in Syria or Iraq. "The message to the radical Islamist scene is clear: we do not tolerate fanatics who try to radicalise young people and send them to jihad," said Peter Beuth, interior minister for Hesse state, where some of the raids took place. "By banning this organisation, a major source of radicalisation has been eradicated nationwide. Those who spread hate messages can't hide behind freedom of religion."
MGT:
In a significant crackdown on Islamist extremism, German police have conducted nationwide dawn raids targeting more than 200 locations, including mosques, apartments, and offices linked to an Islamist group. The coordinated action, involving thousands of officers across the country, marks one of the largest operations of its kind in Germany’s recent history.

The raids, which took place simultaneously across several states, came after extensive investigations by German intelligence agencies. Authorities suspect the group of preparing acts of terror and spreading extremist ideology. The operation aims to dismantle the network and prevent potential attacks on German soil.

Among the locations targeted were several prominent mosques and community centers, raising concerns about the impact on the broader Muslim community. Police have emphasized that the measures are directed solely at those involved in extremist activities and not the wider community.

Several individuals have been detained for questioning, and a number of weapons and materials that could be used for making explosives have been seized. The German government has reiterated its commitment to combating extremism while ensuring the protection of civil liberties. Justice Minister Christine Lambrecht stated that the operation underscores Germany's resolve to address threats to national security.

prompt: A Cumbria zoo is closing after councillors raised concerns about the potential for baboons to escape using a pile of rhino dung.
HWT: South Lakes Safari Zoo in Dalton said it would be closed from 9 January. Barrow Borough Council raised several concerns about the zoo, including the closeness of the rhino dung to a fence, and the safety of walkways. Zoo bosses said they felt "harassed" by the council and were unable to continue under such conditions. On Thursday Barrow Council's licensing committee issued an order to the zoo to prove within 28 days that the aerial walkways were safe. Zoo inspector Matthew Brash showed the council pictures of rotting timbers and said he and his colleagues had noted 20 slips and trips on them from the zoo's accident book. But Karen Brewer, from the zoo, said there was only one accident listed in 2015 and two in 2014. The council also said a pile of rhino dung was too close to a fence, providing a possible escape route for baboons, although the zoo said there had never been a baboon escape in 16 years of the dung being piled there. In a statement, the zoo said: "We assure everyone that the zoo is safe and there is no evidence whatsoever to say otherwise. "We are being subjected to an unprecedented attack and attempt to undermine our credibility and professionalism at every chance created. "The management team cannot work under these conditions and hence the decisions made."
MGT:
In a surprising turn of events, a popular zoo in Cumbria has announced its closure following concerns raised by local councillors. The primary issue centers around the potential risk of baboons escaping, utilizing a pile of rhino dung as a makeshift ladder. This unconventional escape route has sparked fears about both animal welfare and public safety.

The zoo, which has been a cherished part of the community for years, has been the subject of scrutiny after routine safety inspections revealed the baboons' ingenuity in using the dung pile to scale their enclosure. Councillors expressed serious reservations about the zoo's ability to address and rectify this issue, leading to the decision to close its doors.

The council's primary concern is the welfare of the animals, ensuring they are housed in secure and appropriate environments. They also cited potential dangers to visitors if the baboons were to escape, highlighting the need for stringent safety measures.

In response to the closure, zoo management has stated their commitment to addressing the concerns raised and ensuring the wellbeing of the animals during the transition. They have assured the community of their dedication to finding alternative solutions, including relocating the animals to facilities with the necessary infrastructure to prevent such incidents.

Local animal rights groups have welcomed the decision, emphasizing the importance of prioritizing animal welfare and safety. Meanwhile, zoo visitors and supporters have expressed disappointment, recalling fond memories of their experiences there.

The council is currently working on a plan to manage the transition, ensuring that the animals are relocated to suitable environments. They have also committed to reviewing future safety protocols for any similar establishments in the region.

prompt: Tottenham showed a "lack of desire" to win the Premier League with their first-half display in the 2-0 loss at Liverpool, says manager Mauricio Pochettino.
HWT: Media playback is not supported on this device Sadio Mane scored twice in the space of 138 seconds as second-placed Spurs disappointed at Anfield. "If you start a game like we start then it is very difficult," said Pochettino. "It is difficult to fight for the Premier League if you show that lack of desire to play for a win." Chelsea can extend their lead at the top if they beat Burnley at Turf Moor on Sunday, and Pochettino added: "If Chelsea go 12 points clear, it is a big problem." Spurs have won just twice on the road since 24 September, including defeats at Chelsea and Manchester United in addition to draws at fellow top-six rivals Arsenal and Manchester City. In their past 17 meetings with the other top-six sides away from home, Pochettino's team have won just once. "In the first 45 minutes you saw a team that is not ready to fight for the Premier League," the Argentine told BT Sport. "We are in a position that is up to us. But if you show like today that you cannot cope with the pressure then it is difficult to challenge and fight for the Premier League." Former Liverpool and Spurs midfielder Danny Murphy on Match of the Day "I couldn't believe what I was watching, they had the best defensive record last season and the joint best this year, but they were all over the place. Against the big sides they have played with a back three but they had a back four today, but I think they should have stuck with what they have done against the big sides - play with a three. "It was so unlike Spurs, they do so well at home, but the contrast is amazing. There's a lack of pace, and a different mindset when they go away from home. They have to improve and quickly."
MGT:
Tottenham Hotspur faced a disappointing 2-0 defeat at Anfield against reigning Premier League champions Liverpool, a result that has prompted a candid assessment from manager Mauricio Pochettino. The Argentine coach expressed his concerns about his team's "lack of desire" to win the league, particularly highlighting their underwhelming performance in the first half.

The match, which took place on Sunday, saw Spurs fall behind in the 14th minute when Mohamed Salah capitalized on a defensive error to open the scoring. Liverpool's dominance continued, and their efforts were rewarded in the 45th minute when Roberto Firmino, following a quick counter-attack, rounded the goalkeeper to make it 2-0 at halftime.

Pochettino acknowledged that the first half was "unacceptable" and that his players did not exhibit the necessary ambition to challenge Liverpool effectively. "We didn't show the desire to win the game," he told reporters post-match. "When you play against top teams, you have to be ready to fight and compete, but we were not at the level we need to be."

The manager emphasized that while the defeat was a setback, it was crucial for the team to analyze their performance and regain their focus. "This kind of result can happen in football, but we need to learn from it and improve," Pochettino said. "We have to address our mentality and attitude in these crucial matches."

Liverpool, on the other hand, showcased their strength and tactical discipline throughout the match. Jurgen Klopp praised his players for their performance, noting that their ability to execute a well-planned strategy was key to their victory. "We were ready and focused," Klopp remarked. "The team showed great determination and executed our game plan perfectly."

The loss leaves Tottenham in a precarious position in the league standings, further complicating their quest for a top-four finish. With several tough fixtures looming, Pochettino stressed the importance of bouncing back quickly. "We have to regroup and prepare for our next game with a positive mindset," he said. "We need to show more desire and commitment."

As Spurs look to recover from this setback, the focus will be on addressing the issues highlighted by Pochettino and ensuring that the team displays the necessary hunger and determination in their upcoming matches. The manager remains confident in his squad's ability to overcome adversity and maintain their pursuit of European qualification.

prompt: A woman in the Indian state of Uttar Pradesh who survived an alleged gang-rape and four separate acid attacks has been targeted again by an acid-thrower.
HWT: She was attacked outside a women's hostel in Lucknow while getting water from a hand pump, police said. The woman, 35, had been receiving round-the-clock police protection because of the previous attacks, which were linked to a property dispute. Anger is growing at the authorities' inability to protect her. She was allegedly gang-raped and first attacked with acid by two men in 2008, over a property dispute, the details of which are not clear. The same two men are then accused of throwing acid at her twice more - in 2012 and 2013 - to try and get her to drop the criminal charges against them. In March, she was attacked again while travelling on a train with her daughter. This time she was forced to drink acid. Two men are facing trial for all of the attacks but were released on bail in April, the AFP agency reports. According to government figures, there are hundreds of such attacks involving acid each year in India, although campaigners say the real figures are much higher. Despite a Supreme Court ruling in 2013 to regulate the sale of acid, critics say it is still widely and easily available.

This latest attack underscores the ongoing challenges faced by survivors of violence and the imperative for societal change and legal reforms.

prompt: (Close): Shares in the DIY group Travis Perkins weighed on the FTSE 100 after the company issued a profits warning.
HWT: Travis Perkins shares were 6% lower at close after it said summer trading was slower than expected, and that full-year profits would be at the lower end of City expectations. The FTSE 100 was up by 0.44%, or 27.86 points, at 6376.28. Shares in Debenhams rose by 3.27% after the retailer reported a rise in full-year profit to £113.5m. The company also said its chief executive, Michael Sharp, would step down in 2016 as planned, following reports that the board was planning a management shake-up. On the broader share market, the FTSE 250, the estate agent Foxtons fell by more than 8% after it said the central London property market would take time to recover. The company also reported an 8.8% rise in turnover to £43.5m for the three months to September. prompt: Tottenham boss Mauricio Pochettino is yet to concede the title to Chelsea, but admits it will be "difficult" for his side after defeat at West Ham.
HWT: Media playback is not supported on this device Spurs remain four points behind Chelsea after Manuel Lanzini's goal gave the Hammers a 1-0 win at London Stadium. Chelsea, who host Middlesbrough on Monday, need two wins from their final four games to be crowned champions. "It is not over. We have to wait but are thinking that it will be difficult to catch Chelsea," said Pochettino. "I feel calm. But I'm disappointed, of course, that we missed the opportunity to reduce the gap." Chelsea have long looked on course to win their second Premier League title in three seasons, having led since mid-November. But Spurs' nine-match winning streak in the league, coupled with defeats for the Blues by Crystal Palace and Manchester United, gave them hope of a first title since 1961. They could have narrowed the gap on the Blues to just one point by beating West Ham, but produced a below-par performance. Antonio Conte's men will open up a seven-point gap if they beat Boro - and could win the title on Friday, 12 May. "Seven points will be difficult with three games to play, but in football have to try your best. It is true it will be difficult," said Pochettino. "When you have the chance to reduce the gap to one point and you lose it's hard to find the positives."
MGT:
Tottenham Hotspur manager Mauricio Pochettino remained resolute in the title race despite acknowledging the challenges ahead following a disappointing 1-0 defeat at West Ham United. The loss has effectively put the Premier League title beyond Tottenham's reach, putting Chelsea in a commanding position to clinch their first league title in over a decade.

Despite the setback, Pochettino refused to concede the title to Chelsea, emphasizing the importance of finishing the season on a high. "We are not ready to say Chelsea are champions," he stated. "We have to keep fighting until the end. Our focus is on finishing the season strong and giving our fans a reason to be proud."

The defeat at the London Stadium was a tough pill to swallow for Tottenham, who had been in contention for the title until recently. West Ham's lone goal came from a well-taken strike by Michail Antonio, who capitalized on a defensive error in the first half. Despite dominating possession and creating several chances, Tottenham were unable to break down West Ham's resilient defense.

Pochettino praised his team's effort but admitted the outcome was difficult to accept. "We played well and created plenty of opportunities, but football can be cruel," he said. "We have to learn from this and keep our heads up."

With just a handful of games remaining, Tottenham's focus shifts to securing a top-four finish, which would guarantee Champions League football for the 2019-20 season. The team's performance in these final fixtures will be crucial in determining their final league position.

As for Chelsea, the win extends their lead at the top of the table, leaving them just a few more victories away from a long-awaited title triumph. Manager Frank Lampard and his squad are aware of the significance of their remaining matches, but they understand the importance of maintaining focus and consistency.

Tottenham, meanwhile, will look to bounce back against Wolverhampton Wanderers in their next league match. Pochettino and his squad are determined to end the season with dignity, showing the resilience and fighting spirit they have displayed throughout.

The relegated Seasiders remain bottom of the Championship while the Terriers stay 16th finishing on 55 points. As well as deciding on a verdict for the charge, a Football Disciplinary Committee will also be asked to consider compensation for Huddersfield and ticket refunds to supporters. Before the match, 2,000 Blackpool fans protested outside the ground against the club's owners, the Oyston family.

prompt: One of the best-known figures in the anti-Putin protest movement, Sergei Udaltsov, has been placed under a travel ban by investigators in Moscow.
HWT: Russia's FBI-style Investigative Committee (SK) confined him to Moscow after questioning him about an alleged plot to seize power in Russia. Mr Udaltsov denied the allegations and said a "new repression" was under way. Elsewhere, President Vladimir Putin sacked one of his ministers after publicly criticising him last month. No reason was given for dismissing Regional Development Minister Oleg Govorun and replacing him with Igor Slyunyayev. However, last month, in a dressing-down broadcast on TV, the Russian leader rebuked Mr Govorun for failing to deliver on his election promises to help people living in sub-standard housing in the regions. An unnamed Kremlin source quoted by Russian business newspaper Vedomosti said the main reason for Mr Putin's dissatisfaction was Mr Govorun's poor handling of the Krymsk flood disaster clean-up. Along with Mr Udaltsov, at least two other people were also placed under investigation by the SK. In Twitter messages, Mr Udaltsov, a radical leftist, said his apartment had been searched and he had been taken to SK headquarters for interrogation. "This is lawlessness and provocation and I hope that society will not be silent," he was quoted as saying by Russia's Interfax news agency. A documentary last week on Russia's NTV channel, which is seen as close to the Kremlin, showed what it said was footage of the activist meeting officials from Georgia to discuss mounting a coup in Russia. In a statement released on Wednesday, the SK said it had begun an investigation into Mr Udaltsov, Leonid Razvozzhayev, Konstantin Lebedev and others on the basis of the allegations made in the documentary, Anatomy Of A Protest II. If convicted, Mr Udaltsov and the others face prison sentences of between four and 10 years. Correction, 19 October 2012:This story originally said that Mr Udaltsov had been placed under house arrest but it has now been clarified that he has been barred from leaving Moscow.
MGT:
In a significant development within Russia's political landscape, Sergei Udaltsov, a prominent figure in the anti-Putin protest movement, has been placed under a travel ban by investigators in Moscow. This move underscores the ongoing tensions between the Russian government and opposition activists, who have been increasingly vocal in their criticism of President Vladimir Putin's administration.

Udaltsov, known for his leadership in organizing large-scale protests against government policies, has long been a thorn in the side of Russian authorities. His activism, primarily focused on advocating for democratic reforms and opposing alleged corruption within the Kremlin, has made him a central figure in Russia's opposition movement. The imposition of the travel ban is seen by many as a strategic effort to limit his influence and mobility, thereby curtailing his ability to participate in or organize protests both domestically and internationally.

The travel restrictions were reportedly imposed as part of an investigation into the activities of the Left Front movement, which Udaltsov co-founded. The authorities have accused the movement of involvement in organizing unauthorized demonstrations and engaging in activities that allegedly incite social unrest. Udaltsov and his supporters, however, contend that these charges are politically motivated, aimed at suppressing dissent and stifling opposition.

This development has drawn sharp criticism from human rights organizations and Western governments, who view it as a further erosion of political freedoms in Russia. The travel ban is perceived as part of a broader pattern of crackdowns on opposition figures, including arrests, detentions, and the use of legal proceedings to silence critics.

Despite the travel restrictions, Udaltsov remains defiant, using social media platforms to communicate with his supporters and continue his activism. He has called on his followers to remain united and persistent in their demands for political change. Udaltsov's resilience in the face of government pressure highlights the enduring spirit of the opposition movement, even as it faces increasing challenges.

The situation underscores the complex dynamics at play in Russia, where the government continues to tighten its grip on political dissent while opposition figures like Udaltsov strive to maintain momentum in their struggle for democratic reforms. As the investigation proceeds, the international community will be closely monitoring the implications of this travel ban on the broader landscape of Russian politics and civil liberties.

prompt: The £400m dual carriageway on the A6 between Londonderry and Dungiven has been given the go ahead, but only if the money becomes available.
HWT: The scheme will also include a bypass around Dungiven. The confirmation follows a lengthy public inquiry which has now concluded. Northern Ireland's transport minister Michelle McIlveen said that up to £400m will be spent on the 18 mile stretch between Derry and Dungiven. It is expected to be allocated during the budget period up to 2021. There is no indication as to when the work will begin. Ms McIlveen said on Wednesday that the announcement is good news for the north-west. "The A6 is a key transport route and the construction of a new dual carriageway will help to reduce journey times and improve road safety," she said. "There is no doubt that this scheme represents a significant investment in our economy and will create hundreds of jobs." Sinn Féin MLA Cathal Ó hOisín said the announcement was a tremendous boost for the entire region. "The campaign to have the A6 transformed into a dual carriageway and the creation of a bypass at Dungiven has taken many years but we are now seeing light at the end of the tunnel. "It will be a major factor in improving the economic fortunes of the region and the bypass of Dungiven will have a major environmental impact on the town." Last month, Ms McIlveen said work would start later this year on on dualling the section of the A6 between Randalstown and Castledawson.
MGT:
The long-awaited £400 million dual carriageway project on the A6 between Londonderry and Dungiven has been officially given the green light, albeit with a crucial condition: the availability of funding. This significant infrastructure development aims to transform the route, reducing congestion and enhancing safety for drivers traversing the scenic but often busy stretch of road.

The approval comes as a promising development for local communities and businesses, who have long advocated for improved transportation links in the region. The new dual carriageway is expected to significantly cut travel times and improve connectivity between Londonderry and Dungiven, potentially boosting economic growth and tourism in the area.

Transport Minister confirmed that while the project has received approval in principle, its commencement hinges on securing the necessary financial resources. The government is exploring various avenues to secure funding, including potential contributions from the UK Government and European Union funds, to ensure the project can move forward.

Local representatives have welcomed the announcement, emphasizing the positive impact the dual carriageway will have on daily commutes and long-distance travel. However, they remain cautious, urging swift action to secure the funding needed to prevent further delays. The project is also expected to create numerous jobs during its construction phase, providing a much-needed economic boost to the region.

Environmental assessments have been conducted to minimize the impact on the surrounding landscape, with plans to incorporate green corridors and wildlife crossings. The project remains a key priority for the Northern Ireland Executive, with hopes that the necessary funds will be secured in the coming months, allowing work to begin imminently.

prompt: An exhibition at Brighton Museum is celebrating Brighton Royal Pavilion's history as a military hospital.
HWT: World War One amputees were treated there and this month marks the 100th anniversary of the first admission of 6,000 patients. Servicemen received treatment, rehabilitation and training there. Pavilion Blues: Disability and Identity has brought together patients' experiences with photographs, poetry and objects from the hospital. One of the patients was Albert Clay, a corporal in Sherwood Foresters (Nottingham & Derbyshire) Regiment. He was seriously injured by shrapnel at Ypres and lost his right leg. Researcher Jo Palache said letters and telegrams from France told his long and difficult journey to the Pavilion Military Hospital. She said he was first treated at a dressing station bunker and then he had a blood transfusion at a clearing station but still had his leg amputated. He went on to be treated at a hospital in Boulogne before he was moved to Brighton. There he had three more operations. His granddaughter Yvonne Clay visited the exhibition on Saturday. She said 6,000 amputees stayed on the Pavilion estate and urged relatives of World War One servicemen to get in touch with their stories. "My granddad was there for six months and we had no idea he was there, that he stayed in a palace," she added. The exhibition runs until 20 November. The 100th anniversary of the first World War One admission is on 20 April.
MGT:
Brighton Museum is hosting a captivating exhibition that delves into the lesser-known history of the iconic Brighton Royal Pavilion as a military hospital. This exhibition shines a light on the Pavilion’s significant role during wartime, particularly during World War II, when it was transformed into a crucial healthcare facility for injured soldiers.

The exhibition, titled "Healing Architecture: The Pavilion as a Military Hospital," explores how this luxurious, Oriental-inspired palace was repurposed to serve as a haven for recovery and rehabilitation. Visitors are invited to step back in time and walk through the halls that once echoed with the footsteps of dedicated medical staff and recovering soldiers. The display features a rich collection of artifacts, photographs, and personal stories that paint a vivid picture of life within the Pavilion during its time as a hospital.

Among the highlights are original medical equipment, personal letters from soldiers, and photographs capturing both the grandeur of the Pavilion’s architecture and the intimate moments of healing. The exhibit also includes interviews with veterans who recall their experiences of treatment and convalescence within its walls.

Curators have meticulously reconstructed scenes to provide an immersive experience, allowing visitors to appreciate the juxtaposition of the Pavilion’s opulent design with its wartime utilitarian purpose. This exhibition not only celebrates the architectural and historical significance of the Brighton Royal Pavilion but also honors the resilience and sacrifice of those who found solace and recovery within its storied halls.

Through this exhibition, Brighton Museum offers a poignant reminder of the Pavilion’s versatile history and its enduring legacy as a symbol of care and refuge during one of the most challenging periods of the 20th century.

prompt: The former leader of Swansea council has been found guilty of fly-tipping.
HWT: David Phillips, 67, had denied a single charge of tipping waste in a garage opposite his home in Mount Pleasant in March last year. But he was convicted at a trial at Swansea Magistrates' Court on Wednesday. He claimed he believed he was the owner of the garage as the issue had not been challenged in over 20 years. He was fined £200. He was also ordered to pay £250 in compensation to the legal owner of the garage who had registered it with the Land Registry, unlike Phillips. He must also pay £2,000 in legal costs and a surcharge of £20 after being found guilty of depositing wood without an environmental permit. Defence barrister Ben Blakemore called on a number of witnesses, including residents of Oakfield Terrace who admitted to assuming Phillips was the only user of the garage but that they had not known who legally owned it. In mitigation, Mr Blakemore added: "What we have here is not an offence being committed but a matter of ignorance." District Judge, Sophie Toms, told Phillips: "I accept your good character and your role in the community and desire to improve it."
MGT:
In a surprising turn of events, the former leader of Swansea Council has been found guilty of fly-tipping, a serious environmental offense. The verdict was delivered after a thorough investigation that revealed the former leader's involvement in illegally dumping waste in several locations across the city. 

This case highlights a significant breach of trust, as the individual was responsible for overseeing environmental regulations and community cleanliness initiatives during their tenure. The severity of the crime is underscored by the environmental damage and community disruption caused by the illegal waste dumping.

The court proceedings revealed that the former leader orchestrated the disposal of large quantities of construction and household waste over several months. The waste was found in various unauthorized sites, including public parks and residential areas, leading to considerable cleanup efforts by the council and local authorities.

The former council leader has been sentenced to six months imprisonment, suspended for two years, along with a substantial fine and community service. This sentence reflects the court's stance on the gravity of the offense and its impact on the community. The guilty verdict serves as a stark reminder of the importance of adhering to environmental laws and the consequences of such violations.

The council has expressed its commitment to restoring public trust and has pledged to review its waste management policies to prevent future incidents. This case has sparked a broader discussion on accountability and governance within local authorities, emphasizing the need for transparency and integrity in public service.
