prompt: A media advocacy group has called for the release of an independent Syrian journalist who has been detained in Turkey.
HWT: The Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ) said Rami Jarrah - who met the Turkish president last month - was held while applying for a residence permit in the city of Gaziantep. The CPJ said Syrian journalists should be protected rather than detained. Turkey has come under criticism for its treatment of journalists. Mr Jarrah founded the independent citizen journalist group ANA Press, providing reports to international media, after leaving Syria. Rami Jarrah: 'Total chaos and crisis in Aleppo' He was initially held in a detention facility for foreign citizens, but was moved to a different facility on Thursday and it was not clear where he was currently being held, the CPJ said. He was questioned about his work, but was given access to a lawyer and had not been charged with any crime, the group added. "Syrian journalists like Jarrah, who have turned to Turkey for safe refuge, should be protected rather than subjected to detention and harassment," said CPJ co-ordinator Nina Ognianova. Mr Jarrah's father, Nouri al-Jarrah, said he was "surprised and concerned" by his son's arrest and called for his immediate release. He said his son and other Syrian journalists had earlier met Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, who promised that the Turkish authorities would support them in their work. Ms Ognianova said Mr Jarrah was known for his independent reporting, which she said was carried out at great personal risk. Mr Jarrah, who was brought up in the UK, fled Syria with his wife and child in 2011 fearing that he was in danger but continued to go back to report. The CPJ says independent reporting such as that conducted by ANA Press is increasingly rare in Syria, with more and more journalists working under the protection of armed groups or being members of those groups. Press freedom 'a major concern'
MGT:
In a recent development, a prominent media advocacy group has urged Turkish authorities to release an independent Syrian journalist who has been detained in the country. The journalist, whose identity has not been disclosed, reportedly went missing while covering the ongoing developments in Syria’s neighboring regions. Concerns have been raised about his wellbeing and the circumstances surrounding his detention.

The advocacy group, which champions press freedom and the protection of journalists worldwide, has highlighted the critical role that independent journalists play in providing unbiased news and holding powers accountable. They argue that the journalist's detention not only threatens his personal safety but also undermines the broader mission of free and independent journalism.

The Syrian journalist, known for his courageous reporting from conflict zones, has been a vocal critic of both the Syrian government and extremist factions operating within the region. His reports have often shed light on the humanitarian crises affecting civilians, drawing international attention to the plight of those caught in the crossfire.

The advocacy group has called on the international community to pressure Turkey into ensuring the journalist's safe release, emphasizing that his detention may violate international laws protecting journalists. They have also urged Turkey to clarify the reasons behind the detention and to allow family members and representatives to communicate with him.

This incident comes at a time when press freedom is increasingly under threat globally. In Turkey, journalists have faced significant challenges, including arrests and censorship, particularly those covering sensitive topics related to Syria and the broader Middle East. The advocacy group has pointed out that such actions create a climate of fear and self-censorship among journalists, further restricting the free flow of information.

The group has promised to continue monitoring the situation closely and to work with other international bodies to advocate for the journalist’s release. They have also called on media organizations and human rights groups to join them in this effort, highlighting the need for solidarity in the fight for press freedom.

As the situation unfolds, the advocacy group remains hopeful for a positive resolution, underscoring the importance of protecting journalists who risk their lives to report the truth. Their efforts reflect a broader commitment to ensuring that independent voices are not silenced in the face of adversity.

prompt: The Australian Football League (AFL) has condemned fans who hung up an anti-mosque banner during a game in Melbourne on Friday.
HWT: The banner - seen during the game between Collingwood and Richmond - also featured the insignia of the United Patriots Front, a far right group. It was eventually taken down and the fans responsible removed. The AFL has previously seen racism rows over the widespread booing of an Aboriginal player. Far right group 'used me for propaganda' How anti-Muslim sentiment hit one Australian AFL chief Gillon McLachlan said the banner was "divisive, ignorant and deeply offensive". Collingwood president and TV host Eddie McGuire said he was "sick to death" of people using the sport to promote "vile hatred". Mr McGuire apologised in 2013 after making a joke about indigenous player Adam Goodes on a radio show. Last year, Mr Goodes took time out of the game after being repeatedly booed, which he said was racially motivated. Muslims make up about 2% of Australia's population. Last November, a survey suggested that Australian Muslims experienced three times the average amount of racism faced by other groups.
MGT:
The Australian Football League (AFL) has condemned the actions of fans who displayed an anti-mosque banner during a football match at the MCG in Melbourne last Friday. The incident occurred during the game between the Collingwood Magpies and the Brisbane Lions, drawing widespread criticism from both the public and the AFL.

In a statement, the AFL expressed its strong disapproval, emphasizing that such acts of discrimination have no place in the sport or in society. The league reaffirmed its commitment to fostering an inclusive and respectful environment for all players, fans, and communities. “We stand against any form of racism or discrimination,” the AFL said, adding that they are investigating the incident to identify those responsible and take appropriate action.

The banner, which was quickly removed by security, sparked outrage on social media, with many calling for swift repercussions against the perpetrators. The AFL has urged supporters to report any hateful behavior, ensuring that the sport remains a welcoming space for everyone.

The incident has led to discussions about the need for increased education and awareness regarding diversity and inclusion within sports. The AFL plans to enhance its community programs to promote these values further and prevent similar occurrences in the future.

prompt: More than 200 engineers at Southern rail are to be balloted for industrial action over issues including new rosters and "impossible work targets".
HWT: Rail, Maritime and Transport union members will vote in the coming weeks amid claims that industrial relations have "comprehensively broken down". The union is also seeking a four-hour cut in the working week to 35 hours. A Southern spokesman said the rail operator was aware of the issues and "dialogue with the union is ongoing". He added that it had received no formal notification from the RMT union that it intended to ballot its members. RMT general secretary Mick Cash said the union would not stand by while "agreed policies, procedures and agreements are unilaterally ripped up by Southern". "Southern is a company intensively under the spotlight over its performance at the moment and RMT will not have our members scapegoated for failures at the top by outrageous and intimidatory demands to meet impossible work targets and through attacks on working conditions. "The union is in no doubt that the pressure on these staff to deliver impossible targets compromises safety in what is clearly a safety-critical environment," he said. Southern runs services between London, Sussex, Surrey, Hampshire and Kent.
MGT:
Over 200 engineers at Southern rail have been set to vote on industrial action following disputes over new roster plans and what have been described as "impossible work targets." The engineers, represented by the Rail, Maritime and Transport (RMT) union, are voicing concerns that the proposed changes to their working conditions are unsustainable and detrimental to their well-being and job performance.

The union has highlighted that the new rosters would significantly disrupt the work-life balance of its members, demanding longer hours and more frequent shifts. This, they argue, could lead to increased fatigue and reduced safety standards. Additionally, the union claims that the work targets set by management are unattainable without compromising the quality and reliability of rail services.

RMT's general secretary, Mick Lynch, stated that the union stands firmly with its members and is committed to fighting for fair working conditions. "We cannot allow our members to be subjected to these unreasonable demands," Lynch said. "Our engineers are essential to maintaining the safety and efficiency of Southern rail services, and they deserve respect and reasonable working conditions."

Southern rail defended its position, asserting that the proposed changes were necessary to improve service reliability and meet passenger demands. However, the company emphasized its willingness to engage in dialogue with the union to find a mutually acceptable solution.

The outcome of the ballot will determine whether the engineers proceed with industrial action, potentially impacting rail services across the region. Both parties are urged to return to the negotiating table to prevent disruption and ensure the continued safety and reliability of rail operations.

prompt: A town's "dismal" Christmas lights have prompted disgruntled residents to brand the local council Scrooges.
HWT: Previous displays in Boston, Lincolnshire, have featured clusters of lights and miniature trees along its cobbled shopping streets. But this year's simpler offering has been compared unfavourably to a living room Christmas tree by some. Councillor Paul Skinner said the authority could no longer justify the Â£40,000 annual cost. More on this and other local stories from across Lincolnshire He said Boston Borough Council's Christmas lights contract came to an end this year, and it voted not to renew it. In previous years, as pictured below, trees were lit up along the length of Church Street, with clusters of lights used to illuminate the sections across the street. Posting on Facebook, one resident described the authority as "a bunch of miserable scrooges". While one caller to BBC Radio Lincolnshire said her four-year-old daughter "absolutely cried her eyes out because there was nothing to look at". She said her own personal Christmas tree had as many lights as the town centre display. On social media, Frank Slater described the council as "a bunch of miserable scrooges" while Gina Tilling described the lights as "dismal". Others said it looked as though Christmas had been cancelled, and Boston was "dark and joyless". Barry Brackenbury joked that the council was doing its bit to "slow global warming". Responding to the comments, Mr Skinner said: "It could have been better, but people shouldn't be surprised." He said: "We've taken Â£2m out of the budget, and for the next four years we've got to take another Â£2m out." The authority said it will look again at what can be done in future years.
MGT:
Residents of the small town of Pineville have expressed their dismay over what they describe as "dismal" Christmas lights, which have sparked a wave of frustration directed at the local council. The decorations, which were supposed to bring cheer and festive spirit to the community, have instead been labeled as lackluster, leading some to brand the council members as Scrooges for their apparent lack of festive spirit.

The controversy erupted after this year's decorations went up, drawing immediate criticism from locals who were expecting a more vibrant display. The lights, which traditionally illuminate the main street and public areas, have been described as dim and sparse, lacking the usual festive flair that Pineville is known for. Social media platforms have been abuzz, with residents sharing images and expressing their disappointment over the lackluster spectacle.

Community members have voiced their concerns, arguing that the council's budget cuts have severely impacted the quality of the decorations. Some have pointed out that previous years featured more elaborate displays with colorful lights, animated figures, and themed decorations that attracted visitors from neighboring towns. This year, however, the decorations are seen as a mere shadow of their former glory.

Council representatives have responded to the backlash, stating that financial constraints have necessitated a more modest approach this year. They have emphasized that while they understand the community's disappointment, they had to prioritize essential services and infrastructure over festive embellishments. The council has invited suggestions and ideas from residents to improve future displays and has committed to working closely with the community to enhance the town's festive atmosphere.

In response to the feedback, some residents have organized their own efforts to boost the town's festive spirit. Local businesses and community groups have begun decorating their premises, hoping to compensate for the council's shortcomings and bring some cheer to the town. These grassroots initiatives have been met with enthusiasm, with many appreciating the community's resilience and creativity in the face of disappointment.

As Pineville approaches the holiday season, the debate over the Christmas lights continues, highlighting the delicate balance between financial prudence and community expectations. The situation has brought the town together, fostering a sense of unity and determination to overcome the challenges and ensure a brighter, more festive future.

prompt: Ken Weatherwax, who played Pugsley in the original Addams Family, has died at the age of 59.
HWT: The actor suffered a heart attack and was found at his home in California on Sunday. Pugsley was the oldest child of Gomez and Morticia Addams in the 1960s TV series. The show featured a family of macabre oddballs who believed they were normal, and was famed for its catchy finger-snapping theme song. The dysfunctional family were first created by cartoonist Charles Addams in the New Yorker magazine. The characters were made into a TV show, which aired on ABC from 1964 to 1966, had a total of 64 episodes. Weatherwax, who also voiced the role of Pugsley in an animated version of the series in the 1970s, played Pugsley senior in a TV special Halloween With the New Addams Family in 1977.. Three films based on the show were made during the 1990s. The first two starred Anjelica Huston, the late Raul Julia and Christopher Lloyd, while the third, released for TV in 1998, featured Darryl Hannah and Tim Curry. Following his role in The Addams Family, Weatherwax featured in several TV commercials and served in the army. He also worked for Universal Studios as a grip - providing support to camera operatives - according to his niece Shanyn Viera. In a 2007 interview on Fox News, Weatherwax said he enjoyed taking on the role of Pugsley but found it hard to find work because of typecasting. Weatherwax also said he had been teased at school about his character's name. He retired a few years ago for medical reasons, Ms Vieira added.
MGT:

Weatherwax brought the mischievous and endearing character of Pugsley to life on the iconic show that aired from 1964 to 1966. His portrayal captivated audiences with its unique blend of innocence and mischief, capturing the essence of the Addams family's unconventional charm.

Born on November 5, 1963, in New York City, Weatherwax was discovered by casting agents at a young age. His career took off when he landed the role of Pugsley at only five years old. The show, created by cartoonist Charles Addams, became a cultural phenomenon, beloved by fans for its dark humor and quirky characters.

Beyond his work on "The Addams Family," Weatherwax appeared in various other television shows and movies, including a memorable role in "The Munsters." Despite these appearances, Pugsley remained his most enduring and cherished role, and he continued to be recognized for it throughout his life.

Weatherwax's passing has left a void among fans of the series, who fondly remember his performances. Tributes have poured in from admirers and colleagues alike, celebrating his contribution to television and his joyful spirit on and off the screen.

His legacy lives on in the hearts of those who grew up with the show and in the countless reruns that continue to entertain new generations. Weatherwax's impact on the world of television comedy remains undiminished, as Pugsley Addams remains a beloved figure in the annals of pop culture history.

prompt: Toulon head coach Diego Dominguez says he is confident Wales and Lions full-back Leigh Halfpenny will stay at the club next year.
HWT: Halfpenny has been at Toulon since 2014 but is out of contract in the summer. And while the 27-year-old may opt to return home to Wales, Dominguez is adamant he should stay in France if he is to keep developing his game. "We speak very often with him about [his future], and I am confident he will stay," Dominguez said. "I think for him it will be the best decision to be outside [Wales], to challenge the best every week. "I respect him as a person so I have told him this, not as a coach, but as personal advice." Halfpenny joined Toulon from Cardiff Blues from the 2014-15 campaign and was a Heineken Cup winner at the end of his first season with the club. Under the terms of the Welsh Rugby Union's senior player selection policy, Halfpenny will have to rely on a wildcard pick if he is to play for the national side. Interim head coach Rob Howley hopes the ruling will encourage those based overseas to return to a region. It is understood Halfpenny remains open-minded about his future, and is concentrating on reaching peak form and fitness after missing the bulk of last season with a serious knee injury. However Dominguez, the former Italy fly-half, believes the player will soon be back to his best. "It is never simple to come back but Leigh is coming back very well. He is very professional. I have no doubt he will come back 100% as he was before the injury," Dominguez told BBC Radio 5 live. "He is happy at the club, he is having a good time. This year he is much more open, he is making new friends in France, speaking French. "He hasn't made the decision yet, but I will be very happy if he stays and the club will be very happy if he stays." Halfpenny confirmed in September he will be available for the British and Irish Lions tour of New Zealand next summer. He said Toulon will allow him to miss the Top 14 finals to join up with the Lions should he be selected.
MGT:
Toulon head coach Diego Dominguez has expressed confidence that Welsh international and Lions full-back Leigh Halfpenny will remain with the club next season. Halfpenny, who joined Stade Français in 2016, moved to Toulon in 2019, quickly becoming a pivotal player for the Provence-based team. Known for his accurate goal-kicking and tactical acumen, Halfpenny has played a significant role in Toulon's recent successes, including their Top 14 title in the 2021-2022 season.

Dominguez, speaking at a press conference ahead of their upcoming fixtures, highlighted Halfpenny's impact on both the field and in the locker room. "Leigh has been instrumental in our journey over the past few seasons," Dominguez said. "His experience, leadership, and skill set have been invaluable. We're thrilled to have him as part of our team and are confident that he will continue to be with us next year."

The coach emphasized the strong relationship Halfpenny has developed with the team and the club’s management. "Leigh has shown great commitment and passion, and we believe in maintaining continuity to build on our current momentum," Dominguez added. "He understands the club’s vision and is excited about the opportunities ahead."

Halfpenny, who has been a key figure in Toulon’s attacking strategy, has also been praised for his versatility and professionalism. His ability to adapt to various positions on the field has made him a favorite among fans and teammates alike. In addition to his club commitments, Halfpenny remains a crucial player for Wales and was part of the British and Irish Lions' tour last year, further showcasing his top-tier talent.

Toulon’s management is also reportedly working on securing new contracts for other key players, aiming to strengthen their squad for the next season. The club is looking to build on their recent successes and continue competing at the highest level in European rugby.

Dominguez expressed optimism about the upcoming season, citing the team's cohesion and the strategic planning in place. "Our focus is on maintaining our competitive edge and pushing for more titles," he stated. "With Leigh and the rest of the squad committed to our goals, I am confident we have a strong foundation for the future."

As the rugby season progresses, Toulon fans eagerly await confirmation of Halfpenny's continued presence, hopeful that his leadership and skill will guide the team to further triumphs. The club's management reassures supporters of their intent to build a formidable team capable of challenging for domestic and European honors alike.

Kavanagh won three Ulster titles, a 2012 All-Ireland medal and a National League crown under Jim McGuinness. The high point of his career so far was winning the Sam Maguire Cup in 2012 thanks to a victory over Mayo, a triumph which came 10 years after he made his Ulster SFc debut. Gallagher's first year in charge in 2015 yielded an Ulster final appearance against Monaghan, before an All-Ireland quarter-final reverse at the hands of Mayo. Donegal will open their Football League campaign with a Division One game against Down on Saturday 30 January.

Environmental health officers are investigating the cover's maintenance schedule, which caused Miss Martin's fatal head injuries, the inquest heard. A small part of the cover that struck Miss Martin broke off before she was hit, the inquest heard, while a second cover is believed to have been blown on to a lower roof. Mr Garbett confirmed formal contact had not yet been made with the owner of the building. prompt: The artist behind the Tower of London poppy exhibition received death threats, he has revealed.
HWT: Paul Cummins received threats by email, phone and letter over plans for services charities to benefit from the Â£10m raised, he told the Sunday Times. The Derbyshire artist said he believed it was because some people felt the charities were "involved in war". Blood Swept Lands And Seas Of Red saw 888,246 ceramic poppies "planted" in the moat. Each poppy represented one British or colonial military death during World War One. The installation culminated on Armistice Day when the final poppy was planted by 13-year old cadet Harry Hayes from Berkshire, before the guns were fired 21 times and a two-minute silence was observed. Mr Cummins said: "The threats came, I suppose, because they felt that the money was going to charities which in some way were involved in war." He added that police had been called in over the matter. It is thought about five million people visited Blood-Swept Lands and Seas of Red, the title of which was inspired by a line from the will of a Derbyshire serviceman who died in Flanders. He had described "the blood-swept lands and seas of red, where angels fear to tread". The following day a team of 8,000 volunteers started removing the 888,246 poppies and sending them to the people who bought them for Â£25 each. The net proceeds plus 10% of every sale generated the Â£10m being shared between Help for Heroes, the Royal British Legion, Combat Stress, Cobseo, Coming Home and SSAFA. Mr Cummins also told the paper he was working on a new British-based project involving ceramic tulips, although the location is yet to be disclosed. He added that he had had offers to work on projects elsewhere in Europe as well as another "distant part of the world". World War One Centenary

The exhibition, which was unveiled in 2014 to commemorate the centenary of the outbreak of World War I, featured 888,246 ceramic poppies, each representing a British or colonial fatality during the conflict. The visually striking display filled the Tower of London’s moat and quickly became one of the most visited and emotionally impactful art installations in recent history.

Paul Cummins, the artist behind this moving tribute, explained that the threats emerged in the aftermath of the exhibition, which had initially received widespread acclaim for its powerful symbolism and emotional depth. The installation not only served as a memorial but also as a catalyst for public reflection on the immense sacrifices made during the Great War. The poppies were eventually sold, with proceeds going to six service charities, further extending the exhibition's legacy of support and remembrance. The final poppy was ceremonially removed by Prince Harry, underscoring the significance of the installation and its enduring impact on national consciousness.

Reflecting on the experience, Cummins emphasized the importance of art as a means of exploring complex emotions and historical narratives. He hopes that the exhibition will continue to inspire future generations to engage with history thoughtfully and empathetically. Despite the challenges faced, the Tower of London poppy display remains a testament to the power of art in shaping public discourse and commemorating shared histories.

prompt: The police ombudsman is to rule on allegations of collusion between police and a loyalist gang that killed six Catholics 22 years ago.
HWT: The men were watching a World Cup game in June 1994 when gunmen burst into the Heights Bar in Loughinisland, County Down, and opened fire. Five others were wounded in the attack carried out by the loyalist paramilitary Ulster Volunteer Force. No-one has ever been convicted of the attack. Families of the victims have persistently accused the police of failing to properly investigate the killings, claiming they wanted to protect informers. They have alleged there was collusion between some police officers and those who carried out the attack. The men who died were Adrian Rogan 34, Malcolm Jenkinson, 53, Barney Greene, 87, Daniel McCreanor 59, Patrick O'Hare, 35, and Eamon Byrne, 39. Mr Greene was one of the oldest people to be killed in the Northern Ireland Troubles. Five years ago the previous police ombudsman, Al Hutchinson, published a report which said the police had not properly investigated the killings. But his report said there was insufficient evidence of collusion between the police and the Ulster Volunteer Force. The families took legal action and in December 2012 the report's findings were quashed. Mr Hutchinson resigned shortly afterwards and his successor, Dr Michael Maguire, re-opened the investigation. The families and their lawyers were briefed about the findings in Loughinisland on Wednesday. Dr Maguire's report will contain thousands of words, but for the families of those killed and seriously injured in the Heights Bar, the focus will be on whether he uses just one word - collusion. South Down MP, the SDLP's Margaret Ritchie, told BBC Radio Ulster's Good Morning Ulster programme: "We want to see Dr Maguire call it for what it is. It is collusion. ""But we also want him to say quite clearly, who did it, how many were involved in it, was there local involvement in this heinous crime?"
MGT:
Twenty-two years after the tragic event that claimed the lives of six innocent Catholics, the long-standing allegations of collusion between the police and a loyalist gang are set to be addressed by the police ombudsman. This case, shrouded in controversy and pain for the families and the community affected, has remained a focal point in discussions about justice and accountability within law enforcement.

In the early hours of that fateful day, the six individuals were ambushed by a loyalist gang, leading to their untimely deaths. The attack was not only brutal but also appeared to be well-coordinated, raising suspicions about possible foreknowledge or assistance from law enforcement agencies. Over the years, various investigations have been conducted, but definitive conclusions on the allegations of collusion have remained elusive.

The families of the victims have tirelessly campaigned for truth and justice, often facing setbacks and frustrations throughout their journey. Their persistence has kept the issue in the public eye and has pressured authorities to re-examine the case with a more critical lens.

The police ombudsman's decision to rule on these allegations marks a significant step forward. This independent body will conduct a thorough investigation, examining all available evidence and testimonies to determine whether there was indeed any collusion between the police and the perpetrators of the crime. The ombudsman's findings are expected to provide much-needed clarity and potentially pave the way for further legal and institutional reforms.

Community leaders and human rights organizations have welcomed the ombudsman's involvement, emphasizing the importance of transparency and accountability in maintaining public trust in law enforcement. They argue that this case is not just about the past but also about setting a precedent for how similar allegations are handled in the future.

As the investigation unfolds, there is a palpable sense of hope among the victims' families and their supporters that justice will finally be served. The community holds its breath, anticipating the ombudsman's verdict, which could bring closure to a painful chapter in their history and ensure that such breaches of trust do not occur again.

The ruling is expected to be announced soon, and whatever the outcome, it is clear that this case will remain a pivotal moment in the ongoing dialogue about justice, accountability, and reconciliation in the region.

prompt: The makers of a tumble dryer present in a flat where two people died in a fire have been ordered to supply information about any known problems with that model.
HWT: Bernard Hender, 19, and Doug McTavish, 39, died in a flat fire in the centre of Llanrwst in the Conwy Valley in the early hours of 1 October 2014. An investigation found the fire started in a Whirlpool tumble dryer. A pre-inquest review hearing was held in Ruthin on Monday. It was attended by the only survivor of the fire, funeral director Garry Lloyd Jones, the partner of Mr Hender and business partner to Mr McTavish. Also at the hearing were representatives of Whirlpool UK Appliances Ltd. David Lewis, Assistant Coroner for North East Wales and Central, has ordered Whirlpool to supply information on how many TVM tumble dryer models have been produced and sold in the UK and abroad, how many times instances have arisen with a door switch mechanism on that model and how many such instances have involved a Trading Standards body. A further hearing will be held on 19 May.

prompt: A student on a work placement at a Port Talbot nursery said she saw a child get "flung" by the wrist by a member of staff, a court has heard.
HWT: Swansea Crown Court heard Bright Sparks in Taibach closed last year after concerns were raised. Former owner Katie Davies, 32, employee Shelbie Forgan, 22, and assistant manager Christina Pinchess, 31, deny causing cruelty to a person under 16. Sarochka Khadiri said she was upset by what she saw. Ms Khadiri told the jury she had been on a work placement at Bright Sparks for about five months in 2015 as part of a health and social care course. She said Ms Pinchess forced food into one child's mouth who was "crying and really distraught". The court also heard Ms Pinches "flung" another child after picking them up by the wrist for not listening. The defence claim the child threw themselves on the floor in a tantrum. Ms Khadiri said this behaviour happened "every time" during her placement, but she did not make a complaint to the nursery or her lecturers because she felt "scared" to speak out. Bright Sparks opened in 2014 and catered for babies as well as children up to the age of eight. The alleged offences are said to have taken place over a four-month period starting in late 2015. Ms Davies, of Port Talbot, is accused of one count of causing cruelty to a person under the age of 16. Pinchess, of Cwmavon, faces six charges of the same offence and Forgan, of Port Talbot, is accused of three counts of the charge. The trial continues.

prompt: There are 94,000 fewer smokers in Wales since a ban on lighting up in enclosed public places came into force 10 years ago, Welsh Government data shows.
HWT: Sunday marks a decade since the law came in and 19% of adults in Wales now smoke compared to 24% before the ban. There are also 6% fewer teenage boys and 14% fewer teenage girls smoking. Campaign charity Ash Wales said there had been a "major cultural shift" but smokers' group Forest said the ban had hit pubs and clubs. The only group that saw an increase in smokers was the unemployed, where the level has risen from 41% to 43% in the last 10 years. Ash Cymru said other measures had contributed to the fall in smoking, such as the ban on sales from vending machines, uniform packaging, and the rise in the age limit to buy tobacco from 16 to 18. Chief executive Suzanne Cass said: "The smoking ban has resulted in the most positive improvement in the nation's health in decades. "The significance of this legislation should not be underestimated. "Thousands more children now live in a smoke-free home, and hundreds of thousands of people are no longer subjected to the deadly effects of passive smoking." Ms Cass also said she supported the increased use of e-cigarettes, with 141,000 users in Wales, saying they are "95% less harmful than traditional cigarettes". The charity's research showed 81% of people in Wales supported the ban - including three quarters of smokers themselves. However, in its own survey of 1,000 people, pro-smoking group Forest found 58% of people think pubs and private members' clubs should be allowed to provide well-ventilated smoking rooms, with 37% opposed. Forest director Simon Clark said: "The suggestion that the smoking ban is hugely popular has been exposed as a myth. "The smoking ban hit pubs and working men's clubs really badly." He called on the Welsh Government to commission an independent review on the full impact of the ban including public health, the hospitality industry and local communities. It will comment on the figures on Monday.
MGT:
Over the past decade, public health measures in Wales have made significant strides in reducing smoking rates. A landmark achievement was marked as recent data from the Welsh Government revealed that there are now 94,000 fewer smokers in the nation since the implementation of a ban on lighting up in enclosed public places ten years ago.

The smoking ban, introduced in 2007, was a groundbreaking initiative aimed at protecting the public from the harmful effects of secondhand smoke and encouraging smokers to quit. Initially met with skepticism by some sectors, the legislation has since been hailed as a major success in public health campaigns.

The decline in smoking rates can be attributed to a combination of factors, including heightened awareness of smoking's health risks and improved access to smoking cessation resources. Public health campaigns have continuously emphasized the dangers of smoking, not only to individual health but also to public well-being, highlighting issues such as increased risks of lung cancer, heart disease, and respiratory problems.

Health officials in Wales have praised the ban for creating a smoke-free environment that has reshaped social norms around smoking. The restrictions have not only reduced exposure to secondhand smoke but have also made smoking less socially acceptable, further encouraging smokers to kick the habit.

The Welsh Government's data indicates that the reduction in smoking prevalence is particularly significant among younger demographics, suggesting that the legislation has had a lasting impact on future generations. This is seen as a promising trend, as reducing smoking among young people is crucial for long-term public health improvements.

While the ban on smoking in enclosed public places has been highly effective, challenges remain. Public health officials continue to emphasize the importance of supporting smokers who wish to quit, through accessible cessation programs and resources. The government has been investing in initiatives aimed at helping smokers quit by providing counseling services, nicotine replacement therapies, and other support systems designed to aid in the process.

The success in Wales serves as an inspiring example for other regions and countries grappling with high smoking rates. Public health authorities worldwide are taking note of the positive outcomes associated with strict smoking bans and are considering similar measures to improve health outcomes in their jurisdictions.

In conclusion, the Welsh Government's data underscores the effectiveness of comprehensive smoking bans in reducing smoking rates and improving public health. As Wales continues to build on this success, the focus remains on ensuring that every individual has the opportunity and support needed to lead a smoke-free life, ultimately aiming for a healthier future for all its residents.

prompt: Three people have become the first confirmed to find 24-carat gold treasure buried on a beach in Kent.
HWT: Kevin Wood, his partner Kirsty Henderson and her sister Megan found a £500 gold bar in Folkestone after digging for an hour at low tide. German artist Michael Sailstorfer buried £10,000 worth of bullion as part of Folkestone Triennial arts festival. The trio travelled from their home in Canterbury to join the gold rush on Friday. Describing the moment he struck the precious metal, Mr Wood, 28, said: "My legs went from under me and I started shaking. "I put it quietly in my pocket. We left the beach and half-way home, we pulled over for a drink." The Folkestone Digs project is part of the town's arts festival which has included work by artists including Tracey Emin, Jeremy Deller and Martin Creed in previous years. Artists including Yoko Ono are taking part in this year's festival which runs until November 2. Mr Wood said the couple first thought they might sell the gold straight away and go on holiday to Paris. "Now we're thinking we might keep hold of it because of all the interest," he said. "We are not going to rush into anything." Curator Lewis Biggs said the beach had been full since it was announced on Thursday the gold had been buried. "There are always people digging on the beach but there's a lot more digging on the beach now," he said. "When it's at high tide there are maybe 50 people, when it's low tide maybe 1,000. "There are a lot of people coming and going of all ages - families, dedicated people with metal detectors, people with lights on their heads all night. "It's been fun down there." It is not known how many other people may have found the gold bars. "What you find is yours and you can tell other people or not," said Mr Biggs. "You can stick it in your sock and take it home so we will never know if they have all been found or not."
MGT:
Three individuals have made an extraordinary discovery on a Kent beach, unearthing a treasure trove of 24-carat gold coins buried beneath the sands. This remarkable find marks the first confirmed treasure discovery in the region, sending waves of excitement through the local community and beyond.

The trio, who have chosen to remain anonymous for legal reasons, stumbled upon the cache during a casual walk along the shoreline. Initially mistaking the glint for pebbles, they soon realized the significance of their find. The coins, estimated to be worth hundreds of thousands of pounds, date back to the Tudor period and are believed to have been lost over 400 years ago.

Experts from the British Museum and local historians have been called in to assess the find. According to Dr. Emily Waters, a numismatist at the museum, "The coins bear the hallmark of King Henry VIII, suggesting they were part of a royal treasury that may have been lost at sea during a storm in the 16th century." This theory aligns with historical records of a shipwreck reported off the Kent coast around that time.

The discovery has reignited interest in the area's rich maritime history, with locals and historians eager to uncover more about the ship's journey and its cargo. The beach, known for its stunning views and historical significance, has become a focal point for treasure hunters and archaeologists alike.

Under the Treasure Act of 1996, the finders are required to report their discovery to the local coroner. The Act stipulates that the treasure, once declared, becomes the property of the crown, with the finders eligible for a reward based on the value of the hoard. This legal process ensures that significant historical artifacts are preserved for public benefit and scholarly study.

The local community has rallied around the finders, celebrating what many see as a once-in-a-lifetime discovery. Local businesses are reporting increased foot traffic, and there are plans to organize public exhibitions showcasing the coins once they have been thoroughly documented and conserved.

While the exact reward remains to be determined, the finders' legal representatives have expressed hope for a fair settlement that reflects both the monetary and historical value of the treasure. In the meantime, the discovery continues to captivate the imagination of people far and wide, serving as a reminder of the hidden histories that lie just beneath the surface.

Three individuals have made an extraordinary discovery on a Kent beach, unearthing a treasure trove of 24-carat gold coins buried beneath the sands. This remarkable find marks the first confirmed treasure discovery in the region, sending waves of excitement through the local community and beyond.

The trio, who have chosen to remain anonymous for legal reasons, stumbled upon the cache during a casual walk along the shoreline. Initially mistaking the glint for pebbles, they soon realized the significance of their find. The coins, estimated to be worth hundreds of thousands of pounds, date back to the Tudor period and are believed to have been lost over 400 years ago.

Experts from the British Museum and local historians have been called in to assess the find. According to Dr. Emily Waters, a numismatist at the museum, "The coins bear the hallmark of King Henry VIII, suggesting they were part of a royal treasury that may have been lost at sea during a storm in the 16th century." This theory aligns with historical records of a shipwreck reported off the Kent coast around that time.

The discovery has reignited interest in the area's rich maritime history, with locals and historians eager to uncover more about the ship's journey and its cargo. The beach, known for its stunning views and historical significance, has become a focal point for treasure hunters and archaeologists alike.

Under the Treasure Act of 1996, the finders are required to report their discovery to the local coroner. The Act stipulates that the treasure, once declared, becomes the property of the crown, with the finders eligible for a reward based on the value of the hoard. This legal process ensures that significant historical artifacts are preserved for public benefit and scholarly study.

The local community has rallied around the finders, celebrating what many see as a once-in-a-lifetime discovery. Local businesses are reporting increased foot traffic, and there are plans to organize public exhibitions showcasing the coins once they have been thoroughly documented and conserved.

In the meantime, the discovery continues to captivate the imagination of people far and wide, serving as a reminder of the hidden histories that lie just beneath the surface.

prompt: Former world champions Ben and Tom Birchall have completed a sidecar TT double on the Isle of Man.
HWT: The brothers from Mansfield finished 26.598 seconds ahead of John Holden and Lee Cain with Conrad Harrison and Andrew Winkle completing the podium. Ben, who together with his brother set a lap record in Monday's opening race, said it was a "dream come true to win their sixth TT." Manx duo Dave Molyneux and Daniel Sayle retired at Sulby crossroads on lap one. "To race around this course is an honour and to race and win people of this quality is a big deal," Ben said. Their sixth win means they have now won as many TT races as Geoff Duke, John Surtees and Rick Long. Lewis Blackstock and Patrick Rosney finished fourth, with Karl Bennett and Maxime Vasseur in fifth. Earlier on Friday, Team Mugen racer Bruce Anstey won the TT Zero race for electric powered machines. The 48-year-old from New Zealand completed the one-lap sprint of the 37-mile (60km) Mountain Course at an average speed of 117.710 mph. It was his 12th Isle of Man TT title since making his debut in 1996 and his second consecutive victory in the class for electric bikes. Anstey's team-mate Guy Martin finished second, 48.417 seconds behind. Anstey said: "A win is a win and I'm made up with it. The bike was amazing." Martin, who will not compete is the Senior TT later on Friday, added: "It is the future in some way or other. I've got loads to learn but it was class." Daley Mathison completed the podium 48.41 seconds down on Martin for the University of Nottingham team. Dean Harrison finished fourth, with Antonio Maeso fifth and James Cowton sixth. Six of the eight machines that started completed the one-lap race.
MGT:
In a thrilling display of skill and teamwork, former world champions Ben and Tom Birchall have achieved a remarkable sidecar TT double on the Isle of Man, continuing their legacy as icons in the motorsport world. The Isle of Man TT, known for its challenging 37.73-mile course along public roads, has once again proven to be a stage where legends are made and dreams are realized.

Ben Birchall, an established name in the world of sidecar racing, teamed up with his son Tom, marking a significant moment as they both clinched victory. This achievement not only highlights the prowess of each rider but also underscores the deep familial bond and shared passion for motorsport that has propelled them to the top of their field.

The duo’s performance on the Isle of Man's treacherous roads was nothing short of spectacular. The course, characterized by its steep inclines, sharp corners, and unpredictable weather conditions, demands the utmost precision and courage. Ben and Tom navigated the course with exceptional skill, maintaining a flawless pace and demonstrating their superior handling and strategic acumen.

For Ben, this win marks another milestone in an already illustrious career, further cementing his status as one of the sport's greatest. Tom, on the other hand, has not only followed in his father's footsteps but has also carved out his own path to success, proving that the Birchall legacy continues to thrive.

The victory was celebrated as a testament to their hard work, dedication, and the seamless synergy between father and son. Fans and fellow competitors alike have lauded their achievement, recognizing the technical mastery and mental fortitude required to conquer the infamous TT course.

This sidecar TT double is particularly significant as it marks one of the few occasions where a father-son duo has triumphed together at such a prestigious event. The Birchalls' success has added a new chapter to the storied history of the Isle of Man TT, inspiring a new generation of racers and reaffirming the event's status as a pinnacle of motorsport achievement.

As the racing community celebrates this remarkable accomplishment, Ben and Tom Birchall have once again shown that their combination of talent, experience, and familial unity makes them a formidable force on the track. Their victory is not just a personal triumph but a moment of pride for the entire sidecar racing community.

prompt: Dundee defender Darren O'Dea believes team-mates Kane Hemmings and Greg Stewart would be "virtually impossible" to replace in the short term.
HWT: Stewart, 26, netted a hat-trick and Hemmings, 24, scored twice as Dundee beat Dumbarton 6-2 on Saturday. The attacking pair were also regular scorers for the Dark Blues last season, Hemmings notching 25 goals, Stewart 11. "They are fantastic players. Hopefully we can keep hold of them for a bit longer," O'Dea, 29, told BBC Scotland. "They are obviously two good pals of mine and it is about getting the right move, it's not moving for the sake of it. "If you go to England you will probably earn more money but the two of them can really progress and go on to a very high level in the game. It's important if they did move, it's the right move. "To replace them, it's virtually impossible, because you don't have the money to go and replace them." Former Rangers youth player Hemmings and Stewart played together at Cowdenbeath and have scored almost 60 goals between them for Paul Hartley's side in the last two seasons. "You need to have recruitment, which Dundee do have, and you need to have an eye for a player, which our manager does have," added Republic of Ireland cap O'Dea, who headed Dundee's other goal against Dumbarton. "These two lads came from lower league clubs. Credit to the manager, he's found talent in lower leagues, which there is an abundance of. "But to actually go and replace them straightaway is virtually impossible." Rangers, Aberdeen and Leeds United are among the clubs rumoured to be keen on prising Stewart away from Dens Park. "There's going to be interest in Greg the way he's performed over the last two years," said manager Hartley after what he called a "sublime" performance from the attacking midfielder on Saturday. "But we don't want to sell him. There's no way we could replace him - no danger about that."
MGT:
Dundee defender Darren O’Dea has expressed his belief that it would be “virtually impossible” to replace team-mates Kane Hemmings and Greg Stewart in the short term. The duo has been instrumental in the club’s efforts this season, contributing significantly to both their defensive and offensive strategies.

O’Dea emphasized the unique qualities that Hemmings and Stewart bring to the team, highlighting their experience and understanding of the game. Hemmings, with his leadership and tactical awareness, has been pivotal in organizing the midfield, while Stewart’s versatility and creativity have provided the team with a constant attacking threat. Their absence would undoubtedly be felt, particularly as Dundee continues to navigate a challenging fixture schedule.

The defender’s comments come at a time when Dundee is facing a congested run of matches, with both Hemmings and Stewart sidelined due to injuries. The team will have to adapt quickly if they are to maintain their form and secure crucial points in the league. O’Dea acknowledged the difficulty of the situation but expressed confidence in the squad’s depth and the ability of other players to step up.

O’Dea praised the squad’s resilience and the coaching staff’s ability to prepare the team for any eventuality. He pointed out that while Hemmings and Stewart are irreplaceable in the short term, the team has always thrived on unity and adaptability. This spirit, he believes, will be crucial as they face upcoming challenges.

The club’s management has been considering various strategies to mitigate the impact of the absences, including potential loan signings and giving younger players more game time. O’Dea expressed optimism about the emerging talent within the squad, noting that this could be an opportunity for them to prove their worth on a larger stage.

As Dundee looks to recover from their setbacks, the focus remains on maintaining momentum and securing positive results. O’Dea’s comments serve as a rallying cry for the team, emphasizing the importance of collective effort and determination. With the support of the fans and a strong team ethos, Dundee aims to overcome the challenges posed by the loss of key players and continue their pursuit of success in the league.

prompt: A woman has been burgled while she was in hospital with her dying husband.
HWT: The 63-year-old, who wants to stay anonymous, had spent all night and all day with her husband, who died on Wednesday evening. When she returned to her home in Stourbridge, West Midlands, in the early hours of Thursday she found her house had been burgled. Items taken included a digital camera and an iPad containing irreplaceable family photographs. Jewellery and piggybanks containing cash were also stolen. Updates on this story and more from the Black Country The victim said: "After a seven month battle with cancer I said goodbye to my husband, the man I love so much. To find our home broken into, a home that we had built together, there are just no words. "I haven't been able to grieve for my husband. I've not only lost him, but I've lost so much of 'us' in everything they've taken." Police are appealing for information about the break-in, which happened in Avon Road in Oldswinford, at some point between 10:00 GMT on Wednesday and 01:15 on Thursday. West Midlands Police have released CCTV images taken from the area which show a young man and a van they want to trace in connection with the burglary. Det Con Shelley Punshon said: "I can't even begin to understand how painful it must be to return home to a burglary just hours after the death of your husband. "Someone is going to know who did this, but they may not know the full circumstances of what the home owner was going through. I'd urge them to do search their conscience and do the right thing."
MGT:
In a shocking turn of events, a woman was burgled while her husband lay dying in a nearby hospital. The incident occurred last night in their suburban home when the couple's teenage daughter, who was supposed to be home alone, was out with friends. 

The woman, who has chosen to remain anonymous, rushed to the hospital upon hearing her husband's health had significantly deteriorated. As she navigated the emotionally charged environment of the emergency room, her thoughts were with her husband, whose condition was worsening by the hour.

Meanwhile, the family home was broken into. The burglars gained access through an unlocked back door, taking advantage of the absence of any adult supervision. They made away with jewelry, electronics, and several valuable items. The family's sense of security was shattered as they returned to a home that had been violated during one of life's most vulnerable moments.

The daughter arrived home in the early hours of the morning, only to find the aftermath of the break-in. Distraught, she immediately contacted the police to report the crime. Officers arrived promptly, securing the scene and initiating an investigation.

The timing of the burglary has left the family devastated. The wife is grappling with the dual burden of her husband's critical condition and the violation of their home. "It's hard to describe the feeling of being robbed while your loved one is fighting for their life," she said, visibly shaken. "It's like the world is against us."

Local authorities are urging residents to remain vigilant, especially during times when homes are likely to be unoccupied. The police are appealing for any information that could lead to the identification of the culprits.

Neighbors have expressed their sympathy and support for the family, offering to help with security measures and providing emotional support in these trying times. The community is rallying together, determined to help the family navigate this difficult period. 

As the woman continues to stand by her husband's hospital bedside, the family is left to deal with the aftermath of the burglary, hoping for justice and a swift resolution.

prompt: The troubled health board which serves north Wales has appointed a new chief executive.
HWT: The former head of Betsi Cadwaladr University Health Board, Prof Trevor Purt, stepped down in October after it was placed in special measures for two years. On Monday, the board announced Gary Doherty would take up the role. Mr Doherty has held the equivalent post at  Blackpool Teaching Hospitals NHS Trust since April 2013. Chair of the board, Dr Peter Higson, said he was "confident" Mr Doherty could "build on the improvements" made by Simon Dean, who took over as interim boss in June, after Prof Purt's suspension. "Gary is hugely capable and experienced and has led an extensive programme of improvement at Blackpool with success. "He possesses the skills and qualities that we were seeking and that are so important in a chief executive, and on behalf of the board, I warmly welcome him to north Wales." Betsi Cadwaladr has been under the highest level of Welsh government intervention for six months. A report in May found "institutional abuse" at the Tawel Fan mental health ward Denbighshire's Glan Clwyd Hospital. In June, it emerged there was a fraud investigation into aspects of the board's spending plans. Two weeks ago the board announced contentious plans to suspend consultant-led maternity care at Glan Clwyd Hospital had been scrapped. Mr Doherty, who has worked at the NHS for 20 years, said he was "very proud" to have come through the "tough" recruitment process, adding: "While we face many challenges I know that we have many strengths to build on." He said his "key focus" would be listening to the voices of patients, staff, the public and partners to keep up the "rapid improvements" while also building a "long-term vision for the future". His start date is yet to be agreed.
MGT:
The Betsi Cadwaladr University Health Board, which oversees healthcare services in north Wales, has announced the appointment of a new chief executive amidst ongoing challenges and reforms. The health board, which has faced significant scrutiny over issues such as waiting times and leadership disputes, is hopeful that this change will bring fresh perspectives and renewed momentum to its operations.

The new chief executive, a seasoned health professional with extensive experience in both clinical and administrative roles, is expected to take the helm in the coming weeks. While the board has not yet released the full details of the appointment, it is understood that the selection process was rigorous, involving multiple candidates with diverse backgrounds in healthcare management.

This appointment comes at a critical time for the health board, which has been under the spotlight following a series of reports highlighting systemic issues. Over the past year, the board has been the subject of a major review by the NHS Improvement, which identified failures in leadership, governance, and delivery of services. The review led to the suspension of several senior executives and a comprehensive overhaul of the board's structure and processes.

The new chief executive will be tasked with implementing the recommendations from the review, focusing on improving patient care, reducing waiting times, and restoring public confidence in the health board's ability to deliver quality services. This includes enhancing transparency, accountability, and collaboration across the various departments within the health board.

In a statement, the board expressed optimism that the new leadership will drive the necessary changes to address longstanding issues. They emphasized their commitment to working closely with staff, patients, and the community to rebuild trust and deliver better outcomes for everyone in north Wales.

The appointment has been welcomed by local politicians and healthcare professionals, who see it as a positive step towards resolving the challenges faced by the health board. However, they also acknowledge that significant work lies ahead, and the success of the new chief executive will depend on their ability to foster a culture of continuous improvement and engagement.

As the health board embarks on this new chapter, stakeholders are keenly watching to see how the new leadership will navigate the complexities of healthcare delivery in north Wales and ultimately improve the quality of care for its residents.

prompt: Cole Stockton's second-half header proved enough as Tranmere beat Dover at Prenton Park to move level on points with National League leaders Lincoln.
HWT: The away side had the first chance of note, but Joe Healy sent his long-range thunderbolt wide 12 minutes in before Andy Cook found the side netting from Liam Ridehalgh's cross at the other end. Rovers were awarded a penalty three minutes after the break when Connor Jennings was brought down in the box but James Norwood failed to convert as former Brighton goalkeeper Mitch Walker denied him an opener. Tranmere's pressure finally paid off as they broke the deadlock in the 68th minute when substitute Stockton found space at the far post and got his head on the end of Ridehalgh's free-kick to hand his side their third straight win. Match report supplied by the Press Association. Match ends, Tranmere Rovers 1, Dover Athletic 0. Second Half ends, Tranmere Rovers 1, Dover Athletic 0. Andy Mangan (Tranmere Rovers) is shown the yellow card. Substitution, Tranmere Rovers. Adam Mekki replaces Connor Jennings. Lee Vaughan (Tranmere Rovers) is shown the yellow card. Liam Ridehalgh (Tranmere Rovers) is shown the yellow card. Connor Jennings (Tranmere Rovers) is shown the yellow card. Substitution, Dover Athletic. Ross Lafayette replaces Moses Emmanuel. Goal!  Tranmere Rovers 1, Dover Athletic 0. Cole Stockton (Tranmere Rovers). Aswad Thomas (Dover Athletic) is shown the yellow card. Substitution, Dover Athletic. Sam Magri replaces James Hurst. Substitution, Dover Athletic. Aswad Thomas replaces Loui Fazackerley. Substitution, Tranmere Rovers. Andy Mangan replaces James Norwood. Substitution, Tranmere Rovers. Cole Stockton replaces Andy Cook. Second Half begins Tranmere Rovers 0, Dover Athletic 0. First Half ends, Tranmere Rovers 0, Dover Athletic 0. Andy Cook (Tranmere Rovers) is shown the yellow card. James Hurst (Dover Athletic) is shown the yellow card. Joe Healy (Dover Athletic) is shown the yellow card. First Half begins. Lineups are announced and players are warming up.
MGT:
Tranmere Rovers secured a crucial victory over Dover Athletic at Prenton Park, thanks to a pivotal second-half header from Cole Stockton. The win propelled the Super Whites to a tie on points with National League leaders Lincoln City, boosting their promotion hopes ahead of the final stretch of the season.

The match kicked off at a brisk pace, with both teams eager to claim the three points. Early on, Tranmere displayed their intent, with Stockton and the forward line creating several promising opportunities. However, Dover's solid defensive setup kept them at bay, repelling the Super Whites' advances with a series of excellent clearances and blocks. Despite their efforts, Tranmere struggled to break through the resilient Dover defense, which saw out the first half without conceding a goal.

The second half saw a more assertive Tranmere, with the home side pushing for an equalizer and ultimately a winner. The deadlock was finally broken in the 63rd minute when Cole Stockton rose highest to meet a sweeping cross from the right flank. His powerful header found the back of the net, sparking jubilation among the home supporters and sending the team into a higher gear.

Dover responded with renewed vigor, looking to salvage a point from the encounter. They tested Tranmere's keeper with a series of shots, but the home side's defense remained resolute, repelling each attempt with determination and skill. The visitors' best chance came in the 78th minute when a misdirected clearance almost fell to their feet, but Tranmere's goalkeeper made a crucial save to keep the clean sheet intact.

With the clock ticking down, Tranmere focused on maintaining their lead, absorbing pressure and making strategic fouls to disrupt Dover's rhythm. Their efforts paid off as the final whistle blew, securing a much-needed three points.

This victory places Tranmere level with Lincoln City on points, reigniting their hopes of securing a top-two finish and an automatic promotion spot. The team now looks ahead to their upcoming fixtures with confidence, knowing that every point will be vital in their push for the title.

Manager Micky Mellon praised his team's performance, particularly highlighting their resilience and determination to secure the win. "It was a hard-fought victory," Mellon said. "We knew it was going to be a tough game, but the lads showed great character to come back and get the win. The goal from Cole was crucial, and the defense did a fantastic job in holding on to the lead."

The win at Prenton Park was a significant boost for Tranmere Rovers as they continue their campaign for National League glory. With only a few games remaining, every point becomes increasingly valuable, and the Super Whites will be hoping to maintain their momentum as they push towards the finish line.

prompt: A new method of delivering data, which uses the visible spectrum rather than radio waves, has been tested in a working office.
HWT: Li-fi can deliver internet access 100 times faster than traditional wi-fi, offering speeds of up to 1Gbps (gigabit per second). It requires a light source, such as a standard LED bulb, an internet connection and a photo detector. It was tested this week by Estonian start-up Velmenni, in Tallinn. Velmenni used a li-fi-enabled light bulb to transmit data at speeds of 1Gbps. Laboratory tests have shown theoretical speeds of up to 224Gbps. It was tested in an office, to allow workers to access the internet and in an industrial space, where it provided a smart lighting solution. Speaking to the International Business Times, chief executive Deepak Solanki said that the technology could reach consumers "within three to four years". The term li-fi was first coined by Prof Harald Haas from Edinburgh University, who demonstrated the technology at a Ted (Technology, Entertainment and Design) conference in 2011. His talk, which has now been watched nearly two million times, showed an LED lamp streaming video. Prof Haas described a future when billions of light bulbs could become wireless hotspots. One of the big advantages of li-fi is the fact that, unlike wi-fi,  it does not interfere with other radio signals, so could be utilised on aircraft and in other places where interference is an issue. While the spectrum for radio waves is in short supply, the visible light spectrum is 10,000 times larger, meaning it is unlikely to run out any time soon. But the technology also has its drawbacks - most notably the fact that it cannot be deployed outdoors in direct sunlight, because that would interfere with its signal. Neither can the technology travel through walls so initial use is likely to be limited to places where it can be used to supplement wi-fi networks, such as in congested urban areas or places where wi-fi is not safe, such as hospitals.
MGT:
In a groundbreaking experiment conducted in a bustling office environment, researchers have successfully tested a new method of data transmission that uses the visible light spectrum, rather than traditional radio waves. This innovative approach, known as Li-Fi (Light Fidelity), promises to revolutionize the way data is transmitted, offering faster speeds and enhanced security.

The experiment, conducted in a real-world office setting, demonstrated the practicality and efficiency of Li-Fi technology in everyday environments. By leveraging the ubiquitous presence of LED lighting, Li-Fi can transmit data at speeds that surpass conventional Wi-Fi. The technology works by modulating light beams at frequencies imperceptible to the human eye, allowing for high-speed data transfer without any interference with existing radio-based communication systems.

One of the key advantages of Li-Fi is its potential for increased bandwidth. Radio waves, which are limited in frequency, can become congested in densely populated areas. In contrast, the visible light spectrum offers a far greater range of frequencies, allowing for significantly higher data transfer rates. This makes Li-Fi an attractive option for environments where data demand is high, such as offices, airports, and urban centers.

Security is another significant benefit of Li-Fi. Since light cannot penetrate through walls, the data transmission is confined to the physical space illuminated by the light source. This containment reduces the risk of data interception, providing a more secure alternative to traditional wireless communication methods.

During the office trial, employees experienced seamless connectivity while engaging in routine tasks such as video conferencing, file transfers, and internet browsing. The system was integrated into the office’s existing LED lighting infrastructure, requiring minimal modifications. This ease of integration highlights Li-Fi's potential for widespread adoption, as it can be implemented without the need for extensive overhauls of current lighting systems.

Despite its promising advantages, Li-Fi does have limitations. Its reliance on light means that it cannot penetrate through opaque surfaces, limiting its range to the illuminated area. Additionally, any obstruction between the light source and the receiver can disrupt the data connection. However, these challenges are being addressed through ongoing research and development, with the aim of enhancing the technology's robustness and reliability.

The successful office trial marks a significant milestone in the development of Li-Fi technology. As researchers continue to refine and expand its capabilities, Li-Fi is poised to become a viable alternative to Wi-Fi, offering faster, more secure, and more efficient data transmission in a variety of settings. With its potential to alleviate the growing demand for wireless connectivity, Li-Fi represents a promising frontier in the evolution of communication technology.

prompt: Newport Gwent Dragons forward Ed Jackson has revealed he suffered a serious spinal injury after diving into the shallow end of a swimming pool.
HWT: He was injured at a friend's barbecue on 8 April and remains in hospital. Jackson, 28, underwent neck surgery for what his region at the time described as a "non-rugby related injury." "After hitting my head on the bottom I realised I couldn't swim to the surface because I'd lost movement in my legs and power in my arms," Jackson said. Jackson, who has also played for Bath, Wasps, London Welsh and Doncaster Knights, said his father - a retired GP - and a friend realised immediately something was wrong. They pulled him to the surface and stabilised him until the ambulance arrived to take him to Southmead Hospital in Bristol. "After a number of MRI scans and X-Rays the Drs decided to operate at 2am to stabilise my neck as pressure was being put on my spinal cord," Jackson added in a Facebook post. "In surgery they removed my shattered disc, relocated my vertebrae and fixed it in place with a metal plate. "I woke up in ICU, luckily completely coherent, however no feeling below my neck other than limited movement in my right arm." Bath-born Jackson has made 36 appearances for the Dragons since joining from Wasps in 2015 and signed a contract extension with the region in December.
MGT:
Newport Gwent Dragons forward Ed Jackson has bravely shared the harrowing details of a near-fatal accident that left him with a serious spinal injury. The 24-year-old rugby player was diving into a swimming pool when the injury occurred. In a recent interview, Jackson recounted the incident, emphasizing the gravity of his situation and the long road to recovery he has faced since.

Jackson explained that he was at a friend's house when the accident happened. Unbeknownst to him, the water depth was insufficient for diving, leading to a severe impact that resulted in spinal damage. The immediate aftermath was terrifying for Jackson, as he was unable to move and faced a life-changing moment. Emergency services were called, and he was swiftly transported to the hospital.

In the hospital, Jackson underwent surgery and spent weeks in intensive care. The medical team worked tirelessly to stabilize his condition and mitigate the damage. Despite the severity of the injury, Jackson displayed an extraordinary resilience and determination to recover. During his rehabilitation, he faced numerous challenges, including physical therapy and mental health struggles. However, his passion for rugby and his strong support network propelled him forward.

Jackson's journey has been marked by both physical and emotional hurdles, but he has shown remarkable perseverance. He has expressed immense gratitude to the medical staff, his family, and friends for their unwavering support. While acknowledging the uncertainty of his rugby future, Jackson remains hopeful and committed to pursuing his passion for the sport, no matter the outcome.

His story serves as a powerful reminder of the risks associated with everyday activities and the importance of safety awareness. Jackson's courage and positive outlook have inspired many, highlighting the strength of the human spirit in the face of adversity.

prompt: Aerospace giant BAE Systems is to close a research facility in Bristol, affecting about 130 members of staff.
HWT: The Advanced Technology Centre in Filton specialises in areas such as situational awareness systems and high-powered computer modelling. The company said it was "disbanding" the centre to "embed the skills and capability in our business areas where it can be best utilised". It is to consult with employees over potential redeployment or redundancies. The company's other research facilities at Filton, specialising in maritime and combat vehicles, are unaffected by the closure. Labour councillor Ian Boulton said it was important the local manufacturing economy was "resilient" to the changes to ensure the area remained a "world centre of excellence" for the aerospace industry. Ian Waddell, from the Unite union, said it will be "pressing BAE" to ensure "vital skills and knowledge are not lost" and people are deployed to "secure jobs" elsewhere within company. BAE Systems shut down Filton airfield in 2012.
MGT:
Aerospace giant BAE Systems has announced the closure of its research facility in Bristol, a decision that will impact approximately 130 staff members. The closure marks a significant shift in the company's operational strategy as it seeks to streamline its research and development operations across its global network.

The facility, which has been a cornerstone of BAE Systems' research efforts in the UK, has played a critical role in advancing aerospace technologies. The company cited the need to focus resources on its most efficient and strategically valuable research centers as the primary reason for the closure.

BAE Systems has committed to working closely with affected employees to provide support and assistance during this transition. This includes offering comprehensive redundancy packages, relocation opportunities within the company, and outplacement services to help staff find new roles in the industry.

While the closure is a blow to the local community and the broader aerospace research landscape in Bristol, BAE Systems emphasized its ongoing commitment to innovation and maintaining a strong presence in the UK. The company plans to redirect investments towards emerging technologies and projects that align with its future growth objectives.

prompt: The Great British Bake-Off's Mary Berry is pitted against X Factor's Simon Cowell at this year's National Television Awards (NTAs).
HWT: They face Cowell's Britain's Got Talent co-star David Walliams alongside his X Factor colleague Cheryl Fernandez-Versini in a new TV judge category. Game of Thrones, The Walking Dead, Geordie Shore and Celebrity Juice will compete for the new multichannel prize. The awards will take place on 21 January at the O2 in London. Acting stars Dame Maggie Smith, Benedict Cumberbatch, Sarah Lancashire and Sheridan Smith are up for best drama performance for their roles in Downton Abbey, Sherlock, Happy Valley and Cilla respectively. Downton, Sherlock and Cilla also go head-to-head for best drama, alongside Doctor Who. NTA favourites Ant and Dec are nominated in the entertainment category for Saturday Night Takeway and I'm a Celebrity... Get Me Out of Here!, along with Through the Keyhole and Celebrity Big Brother. Gogglebox is among the runners for best factual show, while X Factor, Strictly Come Dancing, The Voice UK and Britain's Got Talent will do battle for best talent show. Ratings hit Mrs Brown's Boys takes on Benidorm, Outnumbered and The Big Bang Theory in the coveted comedy category. Dermot O'Leary will present the awards live on ITV. Last year's winners included Doctor Who, Coronation Street and Paul O'Grady: For the Love of Dogs. The NTAs are voted for by the public.

Berry, renowned for her longstanding role in "The Great British Bake-Off," and Cowell, a fixture in the music industry known for his tenure on "X Factor," are both scheduled to vie for the prestigious title of Best TV Personality.

The NTAs, held annually to celebrate excellence in television, have long been a platform for TV's biggest names to shine. This year's event promises to be especially electrifying, with the rivalry between Berry and Cowell drawing significant public interest. Berry, affectionately known as the nation's grandmother, has charmed audiences with her warm and encouraging demeanor, while Cowell's sharp wit and critical eye have earned him both fans and detractors over the years.

As they prepare to compete for the coveted award, both personalities have expressed their enthusiasm for the event. Berry praised the NTAs for their celebration of talent and dedication, while Cowell, known for his competitive spirit, admitted to relishing the challenge.

The NTAs will not only highlight this clash of titans but also feature a stellar line-up of presenters and performances. The event is set to take place in London, promising a spectacular evening filled with surprises, laughter, and, as always, an acknowledgment of the outstanding contributions made by television personalities to the industry. Fans eagerly await to see who will emerge victorious in this unexpected culinary versus music showdown.
